webTitle: MPs join battle to save branches

fields.headline: MPs join battle to save branches
fields.standfirst:
As Barclays, NatWest and Lloyds TSB keep up their policy of closures, angry customers have found a new group of allies, reports Rupert Jones
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: As Barclays, NatWest and Lloyds TSB keep up their policy of closures, angry customers have found a new group of allies.
fields.body:
With just days to go until another 86 communities are left high, dry and bankless, MPs from all parties have united to fight bank branch closures and rip-off cash machine fees.

This week saw the launch of a new parliamentary group on community banking, which is promising to put pressure on the government, and to "embarrass the hell out of the big banks", if necessary, to secure a better deal for customers.

The initiative comes just a week after the high street banks were savaged in a report from former telecoms regulator Don Cruickshank, who accused them of overcharging the public by up to £5bn year, and failing to deliver a decent service.

That attack left the banks bloodied but unbowed. Despite howls of protest from towns and villages up and down the land, Barclays is axing 172 branches this coming Friday, 86 of which are the last or only bank in their communities. Lloyds TSB is shutting 400 branches this year, and 60 NatWest branches have closed recently or are closing.

This follows the announcement of record profits by the banks - more than £13bn for the "big four" alone last year - and also coincides with plans to bring in new charges for people who use cash machines. Barclays has really rubbed salt in the wounds by choosing now to launch a hugely expensive TV advertising campaign extolling its virtues and featuring Sir Anthony Hopkins.

The 40-strong group of MPs plans to lobby the banks and the government in a bid to turn back "the tide of financial exclusion engulfing many vulnerable communities". The MPs will be seeking a meeting with Treasury economic secretary Melanie Johnson and may ask the government to consider bringing in regulations to ensure the presence of at least one high street bank in a community - or perhaps even see if there are any financial penalties that can be imposed.

Virtually every MP at the launch had a story to tell about how bank branch closures were devastating communities. Paul Marsden, Labour MP for Shrewsbury and Atcham, highlighted the village of Pontesbury in his constituency, which is losing its last bank - a Lloyds TSB branch - later this month. A petition of almost 2,000 signatures failed to make any impact on the bank's bosses, leaving villagers facing a round trip of nearly 20 miles to the nearest branch in Shrewsbury.

Julian Lewis, Conservative MP for New Forest East, said three villages in his constituency had lost local bank branches within just a couple of months. Lloyds TSB has pulled out of Dibden Purlieu and Blackfield, both near Southampton, while Barclays has pulled the plug on its branch in the New Forest town of Lyndhurst.

Guardian reader Derek Pollard wrote in to publicise the plight of Reeth, a North Yorkshire village that is one of the communities Barclays will leave bankless when it closes the local branch. There has been coverage on TV and in the local press, there have been petitions and meetings, and the matter has even been raised in the House of Lords, but all to no avail.

"The Reeth branch is the only branch in this area. It covers at least 300 square miles and serves villages throughout Swaledale and Arkengarthdale as well as outlying faming communities," says Mr Pollard, who lives in the village. "The nearest branches will be in Leyburn, Richmond or Hawes - a round trip of 15 to 40 miles depending on where you live."

It's not just rural communities that are being hit. Residents of upmarket Hampstead, north-west Lon don, are up in arms at the decision to close their Barclays branch in South End Green.

However, it's not all doom and banking gloom. HSBC (formerly Midland) has closed "only" 53 branches in the last seven years and this week it actually opened a new one. The chosen location is the Waitrose supermarket in Twyford, Berks, a town that has just one other bank branch. It will be open the same hours as the supermarket (seven days a week, for a total of 73 hours) and HSBC indicated that if it is a success, it may open branches in other Waitrose stores. A spokeswoman described the venture as "a toe in the water to see how the service goes down".

This week also saw the banks and building societies that belong to the Link cash machine network vote to ban double charging for cash machine withdrawals - a decision that was expected, and which they hope will defuse the simmering row over ATM charges.

While it is clearly good news that people using other banks' machines definitely won't face both a disloyalty charge from their own bank and a surcharge from the institution owning the machine, the decision leaves the picture far from clear. There was no agreement on how much people might be charged or on which charge will be imposed - in both cases it will be up to individual banks and societies to decide.

fields.headline: Isa deadline looms
fields.standfirst:
Companies will be burning the midnight oil as they deal with a rush of last-minute investors next week, reports Tony Levene
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Companies will be burning the midnight oil as they deal with a rush of last-minute investors next week.
fields.body:
With fewer than 120 hours to go before the first individual savings account deadline, investment firms are stocking up on drinks and sandwiches to keep staff at their posts to take in last minute Isa applications.

Many firms are ready to work until the stroke of midnight on Wednesday April 5 when the curtain comes down on 1999-2000 Isas. Those who miss the deadline - even by a minute - will lose out on the chance to invest up to £7,000 in shares and equities.

Cash Isa purchasers will have until normal closing time at banks and building societies on Wednesday. But the stocks and shares Isa can be more complicated. There is a legal requirement to send clients key features and other information.

This year investors can surf the net. Search engines will lead you to company sites where you can download application forms and key feature details.

You can also invest directly over the net with a significant, but growing, minority of companies. Firms are also accepting faxed and phone applications - banned for Peps. You need a debit card - Switch or Delta - to pay. Credit cards are banned.

Gartmore is staying open until the final second with telephone purchasing on 0870 6016103 and online applications (www.gartmore.com). It has also arranged for former parent NatWest to accept forms during office hours until closing time on Wednesday.

Henderson has forms on www.henderson.com and has set up 11 collection points across the country in locations ranging from the Birmingham Motor Cycle Museum to the Europa Hotel in Belfast. These are open on Tuesday and Wednesday until 6pm. Most of the Henderson drop- off points are shared with Invesco and Aberdeen Prolific.

Legal & General has a website www.landg.com where Isas can be purchased with a debit card. L & G promises "128 bit encrypted security" which, it claims, is "the highest available for public use".

M & G's website, www.mgisa.co.uk is not staying open until midnight; it shuts at 11.30pm on April 5. But if you miss that, you could rush to M & G's headquarters in Chelmsford, Essex, where the doors do not shut until midnight.

Many investment trust Isas have already closed due to rules which insist customers have a seven day cooling off period. But many remain on offer until late on Wednesday.

Investment trusts are generally less switched on to net or fax trading but each has its own rules. It is best to contact each trust individually. Some will require investors to waive cooling off rights.

Trusts open to April 5 - usually normal office hours include: Alliance Trust (01382 210 900) which features low charges, split level specialists BFS Investments (01483 237 773), Fidelity which has a range of geographical trusts (0800 41 41 10), Finsbury whose funds include pharmaceutical and biotech trusts (0990 502 017), Foreign & Colonial which has the UK's biggest trust (020 7454 1415), general and split level group Gartmore (0800 289 336), Henderson (0800 082 2345) which has a separate line for its big general trust Witan (0800 082 8180) and Schroder with specialities in emerging markets on 0800 718 777.

fields.headline: Life in the real world
fields.standfirst:
Darren Bender, who started out making gritty films focusing on the darker side of life, is the new head of Channel 4's late-night programming. Martyn Seal talks to him
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Darren Bender, who started out making gritty films focusing on the darker side of life, is the new head of Channel 4's late-night programming.
fields.body:
Back in the early 90s, before finishing his film degree, Darren Bender, newly made head of Channel 4's late-night programming, was in Sarajevo shooting a documentary which resulted, six months down the line, in him being nominated for a BAFTA.

"It was called A Sarajevo Diary," he recalls. "We took a teacher who was English and had lived there for 27 years and used him as a vehicle to show what was going on. It was an anti-news, personal story and it worked a treat. We shot it ourselves, did a rough cut, then convinced C4 to buy it. We thought at that point we'd made it - a foot in the door, a BAFTA nomination - but it wasn't the case. We found it very hard to build on that success and continue getting commissioned."

His career as a documentary maker has seen him direct, edit and produce programmes on such diverse subjects as children being brutalised on the streets of Rio de Janeiro to the success of Vids, the late night Channel Four programme that reviews off-the-wall video releases with equally off-the-wall presenters.

He has a wide range of work to look back on, which makes him well suited to his current position, selecting innovative, low-budget programmes to fill the night-time slot. And it was his experience as a producer, gained from the hard graft of making programmes he believed in, which has led to his present success.

"I come from a low-budget world where there was no money," he explains. "In fact, I've built a reputation on it. I think in something like four or five years after Sarajevo Diary we've only ever got properly commissioned once. I was on the dole for that time but making films constantly. We were making stuff we wanted to make and although we never got all the wages we probably got about 10 hours of documentary programmes broadcast."

And his determination to make his own kind of programmes has meant he's had to show a remarkable courage, since some of his work has been done in lethal situations. "At least in Sarajevo you knew who was shooting at you, whereas in Brazil you were confronted with a 13-year-old holding a Japanese sub-machine gun who you wouldn't really think of as a bad guy, but he was threatening your life."

So with such a tenacity for documentary film making, was this the line of work he alway knew he'd get into? "No, I thought I'd be making movies," he admits. "In the first year of college I was looking for a summer job so I went to a place where I knew Ken Loach was editing his film Riff Raff and David Munro was working on a Cambodia documentary. I just went in there and said: 'Is Ken Loach or David Munro in?' and they said, 'They're both in, who do you want to see?' and by some subconscious trigger I said 'David'. I ended up becoming the assistant editor on his documentary.

"It was an amazing film and it had my name on the credits. So from that point on I started concentrating my work at college on factual programmes rather than drama. Which was good, because everyone wanted to be a film director."

He spent four years making programmes covering human rights issues - Shadows on the Street, about street kids in Brazil, Strangers in a Homeland, about artists in Kazakhstan, and a film about an island off the coast of New Guinea where local people were being killed due to their opposition to an open-cast copper mine.

"Often these kinds of stories were not in the media much. I always saw it as my job to try and get a story that was important into the mainstream. We were constantly pitching them to the broadcasters, constantly brought in for meetings and constantly rejected. The hardest part is to care about the people in your story and not be able to get the programme made. Being turned down by commissioning editors is the most painful and gruelling part of the process."

Now his ambitions are to reinvent 4 Later, his new late-night programme, putting it on the television map and, sometime in the future, returning to the his idea of making a feature. "I've gone full circle. I went to film school wanting to make a movie but that got knocked out of me, it made me feel it was a bogus ambition. Since then I've realised that telling stories is what my whole career has been about."

webTitle: One for all and all for the right solution

fields.headline: One for all and all for the right solution
fields.standfirst:
The Centre for Tomorrow's Company aims to help businesses become more effective through using their people's talents. Roger Cowe reports
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Centre for Tomorrow's Company aims to help businesses become more effective through using their people's talents.
fields.body:
When the Tomorrow's Company report was published in 1995 the "inclusiveness" recipe prepared by the senior business people behind it stirred up a modicum of interest. It helped to move business thinking on from the wreckage of "downsizing" and contributed to the pre-election debate on stakeholding.

But the attention of most business leaders soon moved on, and, as stakeholding was ditched by Tony Blair, it seemed likely that most businesses would remain untouched by the ideas of partnership and involvement which lay at the heart of the "inclusive" concept. The Centre for Tomorrow's Company has continued the work as an organisation to develop the ideas and proselytise for inclusiveness, however. And it has spawned Tomorrow's Company Limited, a commercial network set up to use the ideas to help companies become more competitive.

Nick Obolensky, a former cavalry officer, consultant and manager, is its part-time chief executive. "Our aim is to take the Tomorrow's Company message out in a commercial way, enabling people to become more inclusive in their approach to business," he explains. This is done through traditional consultancy and training by the couple of dozen members of the network, most of whom are self-employed advisers. But Mr Obolensky is uncomfortable with the "consultancy" tag because he sees that profession traditionally maintaining the myth of ex clusiveness - of handing down solutions from on high.

"Traditionally, strategy is created by people at the top and then cascades down, with the people at the top responsible for motivating or empowering employees. It assumes the people at the top know what to do. That model is hopelessly out of date. It is a charade. The people at the top know they don't know, the people at the bottom know the people at the top don't know, but everybody pretends, and the people at the bottom say 'they' ought to be doing something." The Tomorrow's Company approach, on the other hand, is to find the answers among the people most able to develop them - employees, customers, suppliers and other "stakeholders".

As Mr Obolensky puts it: "Most companies have the answer to their problems within themselves. It's a matter of putting the people who know the answers together with the people who know the right questions." In practice this is much more rigorous, and much harder work, than that touchy-feely common sense approach suggests. Mr Obolensky dismissed any suggestion that this is anything other than hard-headed business sense. "It's not about democracy," he insisted. "It's about the most effective way of getting to a solution a company needs to compete more effectively. Participation isn't a choice any more - it's essential."

Steve Parsons is currently testing the prescription. He is chief executive of Redcliffe Magtronics, a small Bristol-based technology business which he is currently trying to turn round. Its history is as a manufacturer of nuclear engineering instrumentation, mainly for the marine division of Rolls-Royce. He believes its future is in magnetic technology, which he describes as "the next silicon chip". Mr Parsons signed up for the Tomorrow's Company treatment as part of a process of transforming the business and developing a new strategy supported by all participants. "We had a fairly significant strategic review and now a strategic plan which I wanted to engage the whole workforce in. I am very big on teams and trying to involve people. This seemed to be an effective way of doing that."

This has been a significant investment for Redcliffe, in staff time, rather than in fees to Tomorrow's Company. (Mr Obolensky insists that its input is as brief as possible, in marked contrast to traditional consultants.) The process began in earnest at Bristol Rovers training ground a couple of months ago.

The entire staff gathered to develop a consensus on the company's vision and values and to begin the process of developing a corporate strategy. That has continued through five working groups, each focusing on a key stakeholder constituency - employees, suppliers, customers, shareholders and the community. Each group has a project manager and facilitator, both trained in these roles, and a mentor from the management team.

Mr Parsons hopes this process will develop a strategy which can be pursued with greater vigour and success because it is well understood and broadly supported - and because it comes from those who know the answers, not those (like him) who only know the questions. Mr Obolensky hopes the experience at Redcliffe and other client companies will help to spread inclusiveness throughout British industry.

fields.headline: A ghost to you now
fields.standfirst:
Prefab Sprout
Royal Concert Hall, Nottingham
****
fields.trailText:
Prefab Sprout
Royal Concert Hall, Nottingham
****
fields.body:
If you remember the last time Prefab Sprout had a public profile, you're probably an elephant. That was 10 years ago, when Margaret Thatcher was PM and critics were raving over an ambitious concept album called Jordan: The Comeback.

Then Paddy McAloon, the band's singer, songwriter and guitarist, went off to sit on a hill near Newcastle, and the record label resigned itself to producing best-of compilations. The only blip came in 1997, with the all-new album Andromeda Heights and a lip-synching appearance on the National Lottery Live.

So there was a lot riding on this gig, the first date in the first tour since 1990. webTitle: The charge: overdrawn and under pressure

fields.headline: The charge: overdrawn and under pressure
fields.standfirst:
Whether it's pence or thousands, the banks are getting heavy with customers straying into the red. Tony Levene reports
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Despite mounting criticism over branch closures and excessive profits, and the quadrupling of the Barclays chairman's salary, high street banks are still hitting vulnerable customers with huge charges for being just a few pounds in the red.
fields.body:
Despite mounting criticism over branch closures and excessive profits, and the quadrupling of the Barclays chairman's salary, high street banks are still hitting vulnerable customers with huge charges for being just a few pounds in the red.

Some of those hardest hit by the banks' tough charging regime are the elderly, who can least afford penalties which can mount up faster than their pensions.

And the situation could worsen if those on state benefits are persuaded by the government to receive cash through bank accounts instead of taking it at the post office counter.

Currently, the target date for paying social security via banks is 2005 and while the government says no one will be forced to abandon cash at the post office, it is not clear whether those who have still to make their first pensions claim will be exempt.

Banks can charge up to £10 a day for "unauthorised overdrafts" - often relatively small sums which may have been run up inadvertently. On top of that, there are penal interest rates, fees for sending out a letter saying you are overdrawn and further charges each time a cheque or standing order is bounced.

All banks charge fees but figures from Moneyfacts magazine show a great variety of possible fees for someone dropping into the red without prior agreeement.

Some of the highest charges come from Lloyds TSB, NatWest, Abbey National, Alliance & Leicester, the Co-op Bank, Woolwich, Yorkshire Bank and Smile, the Co-op's new internet-based service.

Most of their penalties come from daily fixed-rate fines which impact far more on those who run up small debts than those who go into the red in a big way. Banks with less penal charges include Barclays, posh person's bank Coutts, HSBC, and Royal Bank of Scotland.

Elderly bank victims we spoke to insisted on anonymity. Ms A, a pensioner from Yorkshire, relies on the state pension which is paid in once every four weeks at the rate of £265. Just after Christmas she ran up a £63 overdraft with NatWest at Whitby, North Yorkshire.

Her punishment was a "fine" of around £63 - £5 per month plus £3.50 a day . This was virtually as big as her overdraft and almost equal to a week's state pension income.

She says: "That works out around 100% interest a month, but because it is made up of fixed charges, they can get away without showing the true rate. I had to live on bread and potatoes and cut down on heating to pay it off - otherwise the debt would have just gone on growing by £3.50 a day." The annualised cost of this borrowing would exceed 1,000%.

The bank threatened to bounce cheques and take back her plastic cards. And the "Lending Centre Help Desk" also wrote to her to say it was going to bounce two direct debits - one for £30 to BT and a £60 payment to a gas and electricity company. Each failed debit would incur a further £27.50 fine. "That's just adding insult to injury," she says.

NatWest says: "All our charges are clearly laid out on our statements. We allow all current account customers a £50 buffer zone before charges start - and the daily fees are not levied until the fifth day. In this case, we have decided to cut the fees as a goodwill gesture."

Barclays Bank's elderly customers get off lightly by comparison - but still incur effective annual interest rates of up to 50%.

When a north-west London customer ran up a £200 overdraft for a few days, he was charged a "usage fee" of £5 plus interest of £2.93.

He is still paying off his debt so he does not wish to be named. But he says: "I'm afraid of what would happen if they knew I was complaining publicly. I am a disabled OAP, virtually housebound and living on £78 a week income support. I can't take the risk of the bank hitting me with charges."

Sussex-based Simon Ranger is not a pensioner. But he is so incensed by the way NatWest treated his small business account that he is moving to the Co-op.

He imports and markets seaweed-based health foods and diet supplements. He says: "I've had a business account with NatWest since 1989 but my relationship goes back further - my father was a NatWest employee. I have a £10,000 agreed overdraft limit. On March 21, when I was £2,200 in the red, the Curzon Street, Mayfair branch wrote to me asking for partial repayment within 10 days. Failing that, they threatened to withdraw my borrowing limit and make me pay back the whole loan at once. It was out of the blue - in fact, the overdraft was well within my limit."

Removing the overdraft facility would mean a £3.50 a day fine plus other charges and interest at 29.5% until he repaid the loan. He protested to NatWest. The bank excused its conduct by claiming "the profile of the business account does not show regular credits" but conceded "the letter sent on this occasion would seem inappropriate".

NatWest regards business accounts as "dormant" when there has been no withdrawal or deposit in 45 days. But it would usually send out a non-committal letter.

Mr Ranger says: "The bank can't even apologise without appearing mealy-mouthed. They've become an automated bureaucracy which seems to make inane decisions they regret 24 hours later. I can look after myself. But if I was a pensioner on a fixed income I would be worried by these attitudes."

fields.headline: Portman sees off carpetbaggers
fields.trailText: Directors of Portman building society were yesterday barracked by angry members who accused them of running a dictatorship after the expulsion of 377 customers who supported a proposal that it convert to a bank.
fields.body:
Directors of Portman building society were yesterday barracked by angry members who accused them of running a dictatorship after the expulsion of 377 customers who supported a proposal that it convert to a bank.

At a stormy annual meeting there were cries of "shame" and "out" as the chairman, John Roques, defended the decision to throw out the members who backed a conversion campaign coordinated by the website carpetbagger.com.

Bournemouth-based Portman terminated their membership in January, saying they had mounted a "carefully coordinated attack on the society" which had disrupted the business.

While Mr Roques was keen to draw a line under the affair, it emerged later that the leader of the conversion campaign, Richard Yendall, has drawn up resolutions for next year's annual meeting condemning the society's actions as "anti-democratic" and calling on the board to apologise personally to each of those expelled.

One of these, David Hawkins, of Bampton, Oxfordshire, disclosed he had been offered £50 compensation by the Portman after he complained about the society's actions and threatened to take the matter to court. Mr Hawkins said he had rejected the offer and wanted the society to reinstate him as a full member.

During the meeting at the Paragon hotel, in Earls Court, London, one man told the board that in throwing out hundreds of members because they did not like the resolution put forward, they were "acting as if you were in the Soviet Union in the old days".

All but one of the 377 had been offered the chance to become members again, provided they sign away to charity the right to any future windfall, said Mr Roques. It is understood the one person not invited to rejoin was Mr Yendall, of Solihull, who runs carpetbagger.com.

In the election and re-election of directors, all four of the society's candidates standing were voted on to the board with the voting ranging from 87% to 90% in favour.

fields.headline: Norwich CGU union is agreed
fields.standfirst: Small shareholders outvoted by big guns
fields.trailText: Norwich Union shareholders voted-through their merger with fellow insurer CGU by an overwhelming majority yesterday, but not before television investment programme presenter Bernice Cohen had tried to organise a small shareholder rebellion against the deal.
fields.body:
Norwich Union shareholders voted-through their merger with fellow insurer CGU by an overwhelming majority yesterday, but not before television investment programme presenter Bernice Cohen had tried to organise a small shareholder rebellion against the deal.

Many are disgruntled at what they perceive to be lack of share-price action and falling with-profits policy bonuses.

Holders of more than 91% of Norwich Union shares neverthless voted in favour of the merger with CGU to create CGNU. The combined group will be Britain's largest insurer, with 25m customers worldwide, annual premium income and retail investments of £26bn, and a stockmarket value of nearly £20bn.

Around 200 of the insurer's 1.1m shareholders turned up for yesterday's meeting at Wembley conference centre.

Virtually all major institutional investors had already backed the deal, which offered no takeover premium to either side in the merger.

They see it as "strategically sound" - especially as the rumoured counter-bid from a European insurer such as Italy's Generali or Germany's Allianz failed to materialise.

Analyst Andrew Pitt at stockbrokers Salomon Smith Barney believes "potentially, both sets of shareholders can win". And Eamonn Flanagan, insurance analyst at CCF Charterhouse, said he was positive about the merger.

He said: "Looking forward, the combined group will be one of the best positioned life companies in the European life and pensions market. The current valuation of the two companies does not reflect that positioning."

But analyst optimism was not shared by Channel 4 finance show presenter Mrs Cohen, who used her Mrscohen.com website to drum up opposition to the deal.

She waved banners outside the conference centre and organised small-shareholder dissent at the meeting which lasted some two hours with 12 small-shareholder activisits continually questioning the board.

Richard Harvey, NU chief executive, denied suggestions the company had needed to merge because of financial difficulties. "We are entering into this from a position of strength," he said.

Most private investors were more interested in questioning Mr Harvey about the performance of their with-profits endowments and pension funds rather than the deal itself. They are angry over bonus-rate cuts which have left policyholders with 25-year endowments maturing now getting almost 9% less than investors with similar plans a year ago.

Mrs Cohen has set up Snub - Slate Norwich Union Bonuses - to co-ordinate opposition.

The merger is predicted to generate annual savings of £250m - partly financed by 5,000 job cuts worldwide out of a combined workforce of 70,000 with around 4,000 due to go in the UK.

webTitle: Never a frown with Gordon Brown...

fields.headline: Never a frown with Gordon Brown...
fields.standfirst:
Who's giving one of the best interest deals on deposits after tax? The answer, according to John Crace, is rather surprising
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Lord giveth and the Lord taketh away, but the taxman only taketh away. Right? Er... not exactly. Gordon Brown may be helping himself to more and more of your money, but he is also, with uncharacteristic generosity, offering one of the very best rates of return on your savings.
fields.body:
The Lord giveth and the Lord taketh away, but the taxman only taketh away. Right? Er... not exactly. Gordon Brown may be helping himself to more and more of your money, but he is also, with uncharacteristic generosity, offering one of the very best rates of return on your savings.

For those who pay their tax by self-assessment rather than PAYE there's a small fortune to be made out of the Inland Revenue. Trust me. Now, here's the deal.

Everyone knows that the self-employed are totally hopeless at personal financial management and can't be trusted not to spend every penny they get as soon as it comes in. So, the standard advice is to keep a separate account for your tax, and every time you get paid for a job you divvy up 25-45% for tax and national insurance and transfer it to your tax account.

Here it remains untouched until the Grim Reaper examines your year-end accounts and relieves you of it. Apart from an end of January peace of mind, this little piece of husbandry also brings its own little financial bonus in the form of interest earned on your tax account.

Just how little depends on who you bank with. The Abbey National InstantPlus account will give you a return of a staggering 0.1% per annum. Gross naturally. So, just say you've got £5,000 salted away, you're going to be £5 -£3.85 after-tax-richer per year. The Halifax is offering a bumper 0.25% on their card cash account, or £12.50 a year on £5K.

The NatWest First Reserve account and the Barclays Instant savings accounts are positively falling over themselves to attract your business. On £5,000 savings they offer a positively generous 2.5%, which equates to an annual gross return of £125.

However, let's assume you're far too savvy to fall for any of these duff deals. In fact, let's assume that you pay attention to our weekly round-up of a few of the best deals we've found. Take last week, for instance. On no-notice accounts, Legal & General Bank were offering 6.26%, Northern Rock 7%, First Active 6.45%, Abbey National Instant telephone account 6.55% and the Bristol & West 7.05%. On notice accounts and bonds, Scottish Widows offered 6.3% and the Chelsea Building Society 6.7%, both for a 60-day notice period, while the Alliance & Leicester would give you 7%, but only if you had 10K and could wait 75 days for it.

To which I say "Peanuts". Because the Inland Revenue is paying 7.16%. You heard me, 7.16%. If, rather than putting your dosh in a transit account prior to divvying up with the Treasury, you give the money directly to them in advance, they will give you 7.16% return. And there are no catches. You don't have to guarantee to make a certain number of fixed payments and you don't have to pay a minimum sum. You don't even need a sum.

All you need to do is to ring up the IR's local-charge rate debit card line - they even answer almost instantaneously - give them your tax reference and tell them how much you want to pay, from £1 to whatever your card can stand - and you're in.

Quite why the IR offers such a good rate is not exactly obvious, but it's not hard to speculate. To avoid charges of excessive profiteering, the chancellor has to keep the differential between interest paid and interest charged relatively small. And how many people are there to be caned for paying late compared to those smart enough to pay in advance? It's no contest really.

Now suppose you have an aversion to giving money to the Inland Revenue, and you'd rather be £5.50 worse off by keeping the money in the Bristol & West where you can see it. Fine.

But you're much more than £5.50 worse off, because your designated tax account has to be declared on your annual tax return. In most cases this will involve more paper shuffling and your accountant whacking an extra £50 or so on his or her bill for the hassle. Saving with the IR is far simpler - and cheaper - because they work it all out for you. For nothing.

How do I know all this? Well, at present I'm £2,581 in credit with the IR. Or, to put it another way, the taxman owes me £184.80 in interest.

fields.headline: Mobile bids top £10bn
fields.trailText: The auction for licences to operate the next generation of mobile phones burst through the £10bn mark yesterday and showed no sign of easing.
fields.body:
The auction for licences to operate the next generation of mobile phones burst through the £10bn mark yesterday and showed no sign of easing.

All 13 bidders that lined up at the beginning of the process four weeks ago are still competing and analysts whose predictions have been dramatically outstripped are reluctant to forecast where it will stop. A price of at least £3bn per licence seems realistic which would take the total to £15bn.

At least half the winning bids must be paid immediately to the Treasury with the remainder due over 10 years.

The next generation networks, which use the universal mobile telecommunications system (UMTS) standard, will enable high-speed internet access and high-quality video over handsets. The value of the licences is underscored by predictions that mobile phones could overtake personal computers as the main means of accessing the web.

At the close of round 91 the Virgin-led SpectrumCo headed the bidding for licence A, the largest licence which has been reserved for new entrants, with an offer of £2.1bn. In licence B, Vodafone had tabled a bid of £2.23bn.

MCI WorldCom, the aggressive US telecoms company is leading the auction for licence C with a £1.88bn bid while Spain's national telephone company, Telefonica, tops bids for licence D with £1.89bn. NTL, Britain's biggest cable company, backed by France Telecom, is leading the bids for licence E with a £1.95bn offer.

None of the current highest bidders is allowed to make an offer in the next round.

"It's like a game of poker where no one has yet blinked," one telecoms analyst said. "Bidders are moving from one licence to another and it is difficult to unpick anyone's strategies."

Original analyst estimates suggested the licences would go for a combined £1.5bn-£2bn. The government's combined reserve price for the licences, £500m, now seems laughably low.

There have been suggestions that existing operators were driving up prices to offset damage caused if an new entrant won a licence. "It may seem cynical but even if you aren't going to win you can make sure all the value of getting a licence disappears from the company that secures them," the analyst said.

Because of the public nature of the auction, none of the participants wants to be the first to crumble, however.

Some observers believed bids have reached a level that could impede take-up of third generation services because of the costs which could be passed on to consumers. The price of building up a network for an existing operator is likely to be around £3bn .

Orange, One2One and BT Cellnet remain in contention, along with Canada's TIW, Crescent Wireless, a vehicle for Global Crossing of the US, Nomura subsidiary Epsilon, OneTel, backed by Kerry Packer and Rupert Murdoch, and Eircom subsidiary 3GUK.

In April last year the US government raised $4bn from one auction of mobile licences. However, it was forced to repeat the entire process after a number of the winners defaulted on their payments.

The second time round the auction raised $412m - just one-tenth of the original closing price.

fields.headline: Bred and Bath
fields.standfirst:
The Rivals
The Swan, Stratford-upon-Avon
***
fields.trailText:
The Rivals
The Swan, Stratford-upon-Avon
***
fields.body:
Watching Lindsay Posner's pretty, pleasing, picturesque revival of Sheridan's infallible comedy, I had a strange sensation that I was sitting at the Haymarket or even Chichester. The audience purred its approval. But, after the cutting-edge brilliance of Steven Pimlott's Richard II, which is playing in the Other Place, it struck me that the RSC was cushioning its exploration of Shakespeare's Histories with nice, safe, reassuring theatre.

Mrs Malaprop warns us against "delusions to the past". But Ashley Martin-Davis's set design, with its detachable blocks of miniaturised Bath houses, triggered a memory of John Gunter's similar sets for Peter Wood's National Theatre revival in the 80s. The key difference is that Wood placed Sheridan's comedy of intrigue in the context of real life: we saw the tetchy Anthony Absolute at breakfast or glimpsed tailors' apprentices beavering away in upstairs rooms.

Given that Sheridan's play derived directly from his own Bath-time experience of elopement and duels, this seemed precisely right. However, Posner's production, with its footlights, false proscenium and preliminary dance, takes its cue as much from period theatre as from life.

I don't wish to sound too curmudgeonly: some attempt has clearly been made to reassess the characters. Lydia Languish, who sees life in terms of romantic novels and who embraces her lover as a penniless ensign but rejects him as an established captain, is played by Emily Raymond as a pampered, pouting brat. Even better, Wendy Craig treats Mrs Malaprop not as a conscious grotesque, but as a woman whose verbal slips stem, perversely, from an overwhelming passion for language. This is a seriously good performance and when her romantic follies are mocked, you get a hint of the harsh cruelty underlying Bath's fashionable glitter.

David Tennant is dullish as the disguised Jack Absolute, but Benjamin Whitrow makes no mistake with his tyrannical father: like Michael Hordern, he stresses the character's bubbling lechery and reveals an underlying compassion, as he alone comforts the discarded Mrs Malaprop.

Des McAleer lends the deluded Hibernian, Sir Lucius O'Trigger, a twinkling charm even if Ian Hughes is too ploddingly sane to get to the heart of the erotically tormented Faulkland. But the general impression was of a decent, decorative revival of Sheridan's dazzling first play that clearly sent the audience away happy. Is it ungrateful to expect of the Swan something more challenging than amiable diversion?

 In rep until October 5. Box Office: 01789-403403.

fields.headline: ATMs become more versatile
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The humble cash machine - recently at the centre of a bitter war over charges - is set to get a new string to its bow.
fields.body:
The humble cash machine - recently at the centre of a bitter war over charges - is set to get a new string to its bow.

While multi-function ATMs that do more than just dispense cash are a common sight in other countries, the UK has lagged behind on this front, but proposals discussed by banks and building societies this week are set to change all that.

Plans are underway to allow the growing army of people with pre-paid mobile phones to top up their talk time at cashpoints. This means that instead of having to buy vouchers from shops, they could effectively load credit on to their mobiles at an ATM at the same time as they take out money.

It is understood the scheme would involve banks and building societies teaming up with the major mobile phone companies, which would issue their customers with special plastic cards. You would insert your debit card into the ATM, select the pre-paid phone option on the screen, and then insert your plastic card. You would then be able to transfer money from your current account on to this card, thereby increasing your call time.

Pre-paid mobile packages are popular because they allow people to buy phone handsets without paying monthly bills. Instead, customers buy vouchers. Customers have to ring the phone company's credit line and enter the number on the card, which tops up the phone with the amount of credit purchased.

Vodafone says of the cash machine plan that "it is certainly something we are working towards", while Link, the cash machine network, says a whole range of ideas are under discussion generally about increasing the services offered by ATMs. In the US cashpoints that dispense store coupons and stamps have been around for years now.One scheme already up and running in this country involves Nationwide cashpoints in Marks & Spencer stores which dispense M&S gift vouchers. At the moment Nationwide has 184 machines in 175 M&S branches, and the aim is to have 350 in-store machines by August.

Cash dispenser company NCR says the UK public can also look forward to the arrival of machines that offer "intelligent cash acceptance". At the moment, most banks have credit points allowing people to pay in cash without queueing up at the counter, but they are rather primitive - you put your money in an envelope and post it through a slot. With the new "intelligent" facility, you could put £100 in £10 notes on to the machine's tray which will count it and then ask for your confirmation that you have deposited £100.

webTitle: Leadership: the movie... on a screen near you

fields.headline: Leadership: the movie... on a screen near you
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Good films go beyond entertainment; they contain lessons on effective management and leadership, says John Clemens, professor of management at Hartwick College in Oneonta, New York.
fields.body:
Had enough of scouring management literature, attending seminars, listening to consultants spouting variations on the same well-trodden themes of leadership, team building, quality control and employee empowerment? Take a break. Go to the movies or hire a video. Good films go beyond entertainment; they contain lessons on effective management and leadership, says John Clemens, professor of management at Hartwick College in Oneonta, New York.

Apollo 13 is the story of a "successful failure." The movie shows how teamwork and improvisation can turn a spectacular failure into a success. The film shows how common sense, creativity and optimism in the face of a crisis are as important as technology. The film is an object lesson in drawing people together in a calm co-operative problem solving mode.

To turn any movie into a management tool, the scenes to look for are those where something remarkable happens between leaders and their followers.

 In the current new economic paradigm e-commerce is king. But in the new, new economy coming after the tech bubble bursts, there will be f-commerce - firms with fleets of lorries. Companies that are f-enabled can distribute more products. The trucks can carry other companies' ads on their sides, generating revenue. A tipsheet from stockbrokers Oversell & Vanish estimates that the market will value the f-economy at 300 times 2005 earnings.

 As more companies begin to market their products through the web workers with foreign language skills are in great demand, according to Global Reach the internet-based international marketing consultancy. In the last four years the number of non-English speaking net users has gone from less than 10% to nearly 50%. By 2002, Global Reach estimates that 66% of internet use and 40% of e-commerce revenue will come from outside the English-speaking world. At present 46% of all internet users are non English-speakers.

For those who want to brush up their language skills there are free courses on the Language and Culture for Business programme run by the universities of North London, Luton, Sheffield Hallam, Wolverhampton and Bolton Institute. For booking details tel; 0845-6033322.

fields.headline: Fuel for a hot market
fields.standfirst:
As house prices go on rising lenders are coming up with deals designed to tempt the Easter buyer, says Nick Pandya
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: As house prices go on rising lenders are coming up with deals designed to tempt the Easter buyer.
fields.body:
When estate agents are smiling, homeowners should beware. And just at the moment they are grinning from ear to ear. House prices are rising by 16% a year on average. The housing slump that was to many Britons the most unexpected and painful aspect of the early 90s recession can now be consigned to the history books.

But have we learned from history and changed our attitudes to housing? Or is yet another housing boom to be followed by repossessions and negative equity? Don't bother to ask moneylenders, for they are falling over each other to fuel the market. Figures from the Bank of England shows mortgage approvals jumping to 105,000, the highest for over two years and well above the average of about 98,000 in the previous three months.

Today marks the start of the Easter house-hunting season, with several lenders launching new home loan packages with cheque book grabbing rates. Britannia Building Society has come up with a two-year discounted deal that trims 2.1% off its standard variable rate of 7.64% for buyers with a down payment of at least 10%.The society is even more generous to cash-rich borrowers with a deposit worth at least 25% of the value of the property. They will have repayments pegged at 2.15% below the current variable rate of 7.64% at 5.48% for the next two years.

The Bank of Ireland's UK offshoot, Bristol & West, is wooing buyers with a conscience. Its new mortgage package offers a one-year fixed-rate home loan at 5.99% followed by a 1% discount off base mortgage rates for the next two years. Successful applications then trigger a charitable donation equivalent to 1% of the total advance. The three charities it supports are Cancer & Leukaemia in Childhood, the Bristol Children's Hospital and Cancer Research.

Birmingham Midshires, is switching to the daily method of charging interest on mortgage balances.This approach means that the mortgage balance on which interest is calculated is immediately reduced when capital is repaid, cutting the outstanding debt more quickly.

John Charcol is offering a discounted mortgage whereby the discount drops from 1.75% to 1.55% over three years on a sliding scale. At present borrowers will repay the mortgage at 6% without any penalties for switching lenders in the future. The mortgage adviser has worked out that on a loan of £100,000 the deal would save around £145 a month in the first year.

And another mortgage broker, Chase De Vere has launched a new mortgage offering a cocktail of a fixed rate, a discount and a flexible redemption penalty policy. Its Three-way Mortgage, which has an upfront fee of £300, comes with a one-year fixed rate of 5.99% until May 1, 2001, a 1.25% discount stretching to May 1, 2003 and no redemption penalties on 25% of the original loan.

But watch out for the 2% early redemption levy on any amount above 25% of the mortgage that you might repay before that date. This is a charge made by your mortgage lender which is payable on certain types of loan - usually discounted or fixed interest rate loans - and is applied if the loan is paid off or part-redeemed within the specified period.

This, the lenders argue, is the quid pro quo of benefiting from the constant rates or the low-cost mortgage offered by discounted rates.

For the self-employed, the Mortgage Operation has launched two special deals. Its Multi-Purpose Discount deal offers a 1.5% discount until February 1, 2002, with an initial payable rate of 6.28%. And its SelfCert Base Tracker, aimed at borrowers with adverse credit, has a 0.4% discount to March 1, 2002 with an underlying rate which tracks base rate, giving an initial payable rate of 7.24%.

 Money Unlimited, the Guardian's internet operation, is running a competition whereby readers can win a year- long mortgage repayment holiday worth up to £100,000. The winner can also visit Money Unlimited for some straightforward advice on how to invest the cash they've saved. Details on www.moneyunlimited.co.uk

fields.headline: Pick your market carefully
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Anybody still tempted to buy into dot.com shares even after the recent sell-off of stocks such as lastminute.com should be very cautious about which market the company is traded on.
fields.body:
Anybody still tempted to buy into dot.com shares even after the recent sell-off of stocks such as lastminute.com should be very cautious about which market the company is traded on.

Ring a stockbroker and ask for some of the favourite internet shares - such as Geo Interactive Media or BATM Advanced Technology - and you may find the broker refuses to deal. Both are on the "restricted list" of 17 shares that the biggest on-line broker, Charles Schwab, refuses to deal in, because they produce a time-consuming paperchase before the broker can settle.

Many of the new start-ups trade first on the Ofex market, a fringe stock exchange which is much less demanding than the London Stock Exchange about listing requirements. There are currently around 20 internet hopefuls queueing up to list on Ofex, but some brokers such as Killik & Co tend to steer clients away from them. This is because the shares have little liquidity, are risky, poorly researched and have huge "spreads".

Spread is the term given to the difference between the buying and selling price of a share, and on Ofex the spread is usually 10%, and in many shares much more. In contrast, FTSE 100 stocks have typical spreads of 1-2%.

There are three tiers of market in the UK; the LSE, Aim (the alternative investment market) and Ofex. As a rule of thumb, LSE is the premier league, Aim the first division and Ofex the second. Riskiness and volatility of the shares tends to increase as you go down the leagues.

Big fund managers rarely buy stocks which are not listed on the LSE and often shy away from Aim stocks. Barclays Stockbrokers is more relaxed about the Ofex market, but warns investors to be wary.

fields.headline: Chill wind blowing through Scotland
fields.standfirst:
Another mutual insurer has come under attack in the non-stop 'consolidation' of the financial services industry. Rupert Jones reports
Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: After failing to squeeze any cash out of Standard Life, carpetbaggers seeking windfalls this week mounted an assault on another north-of-the-border mutual life insurer: Scottish Provident.
fields.body:
After failing to squeeze any cash out of Standard Life, carpetbaggers seeking windfalls this week mounted an assault on another north-of-the-border mutual life insurer: Scottish Provident.

A group of rebel members have submitted a resolution calling on the company to let its 750,000 policyholders have a say on whether it should demutualise. They claim that if Scottish Provident converted to a public limited company, or was put up for sale and taken over by a bigger player, this could unlock payouts of at least £1,000 per eligible policyholder. However, one industry observer said any windfalls would be more likely to average £500-£600.

The challenge to the 163-year-old company's status came as another Scottish institution, its rugby team, prepared for its crunch Calcutta Cup game with England tomorrow. It also comes just weeks after Standard Life threw out a similar attempt by Monaco-based carpetbagger Fred Woollard to force it into holding a demutualisation ballot.

This latest demutualisation resolution has been submit ted by a 40-strong group calling themselves the Scottish Provident Members Alliance Group, led by 50-year-old Gordon Hart, a company director living near Edinburgh who has been a Scottish Provident member for more than two decades.

fields.headline: American batty
fields.standfirst:
The Tender Land
Barbican, London
***
fields.trailText:
The Tender Land
Barbican, London
***
fields.body:
The Tender Land was Aaron Copland's only full-length opera. The premiere - in New York in 1954 - wasn't a success, and little has been heard of it since. The Barbican has unearthed it for the start of Copland's centenary celebrations but, despite the best efforts of all concerned, its flaws are glaringly apparent.

The title is ambiguous: on one level it is the vast American subcontinent, with the potential for exploration and exploitation; on another it represents the adolescent human body, anticipating first sexual experience. The libretto, by Copland's lover Erik Johns, belongs to the 50s style of half-closeted gay writing. Like Terence Rattigan, William Inge and Tennessee Williams, Johns sends his heroine to discover herself after an overwhelming experience with an alluring bit of rough. When the teenage Laurie Moss meets Martin, a hunky drifter, she abandons her restricted Mid-West background to search for personal freedom.

Throughout there are hints of the American dream souring. Women in Laurie's community have been attacked by two strangers. Martin and his friend Top are suspected - but even after the real perpetrators are apprehended, the community still judges Martin and Top guilty because they are different. The McCarthy witch hunts - and perhaps also a suggestion of pre-Stonewall homophobia - hang over the piece.

The problems lie less with the text than with the score. Copland's theatrical imagination was fired primarily by dance, as if the thought of swirling bodies generated the dramatic propulsion that characterises his best music. The tone of The Tender Land, by contrast, is meditative. The score is hampered by an unremitting sameness of pace, and the political overlay isn't given enough clout. The love scenes are unraunchy. Only in the big choral dances in Act II does the score come to life and then we get vintage Copland.

This performance, with Richard Hickox conducting the City of London Sinfonia, was characterised by a dogged, if vain, determination to make the piece succeed. Arresting orchestral textures made up for dramatic paucity on occasion. Laura Claycomb voiced Laurie's yearnings with a shimmery radiance, while Richard Coxon's Martin was dreamy rather than heftily imposing. The performance won't, however, put the score back on the map. The Tender Land has for years been consigned to an operatic limbo - which, is, perhaps, where it really belongs.

fields.headline: MacLaurin sees no red faces
fields.trailText: Lord MacLaurin yesterday denied that the delay by the 12 selected England players in signing their central contracts was an embarrassment, claiming he remained confident that an agreement would be reached.
fields.body:
Lord MacLaurin yesterday denied that the delay by the 12 selected England players in signing their central contracts was an embarrassment, claiming he remained confident that an agreement would be reached.

"The players will sign the contracts in good time," the England and Wales Cricket Board chairman insisted. "It is only right and proper they look at the contracts thoroughly.

"It's not embarrassing. Anybody who is given a contract of any sort looks through it and takes advice. But I have no doubt they will sign - and whether that is tomorrow or on the second, third or fourth makes no difference."

None of the players has signed the contracts, which come into effect on Sunday, because of a dispute over the loss of county bonuses and image rights. But the ECB yesterday said a resolution was close.

Lord MacLaurin said he was "totally against" raising the quota of overseas stars to compensate counties for losing their contracted players.

Meanwhile Australia have brought Matthew Hayden in for the out-of-form Greg Blewett for the final Test against New Zealand, which starts in Hamilton today, and Pakistan have recalled Mushtaq Ahmed for next month's triangular one-day series in the West Indies.

 Australia's coach John Buchanan has revealed his vision for a future where players will be able to play both right- and left-handed as the game evolves. "Certainly in fielding," he said. "Potentially, I reckon we could have some batting and, in the end, I think we will find the odd player who can actually bowl either arm."

webTitle: War on racism renewed after Heskey ordeal

fields.headline: War on racism renewed after Heskey ordeal
fields.standfirst:
FA pledge to carry on the fight at home and wherever England play
Leader comment
The match that reignited the row
fields.trailText: Uefa came under pressure yesterday to condemn the verbal and physical abuse that Emile Heskey suffered against Yugoslavia on Wednesday night as the FA pledged to carry on the fight against racism at home and wherever England play.
fields.body:
Uefa came under pressure yesterday to condemn the verbal and physical abuse that Emile Heskey suffered against Yugoslavia as the Football Association pledged to continue to fight racism at home and wherever England play in the world.

The football anti-racist group, Kick It Out, immediately called for official action after Heskey was subjected to monkey chants in the first half.

The young black striker claimed he was also "spat at twice" by the opposition in England's 3-0 win over the Yugoslavs in their Under-21 play-off in Barcelona on Wednesday.

Uefa will be obliged to investigate if the German referee Hartmut Strampe's report refers to the attacks on Heskey but yesterday it confirmed there had been no mention of any incidents in the report already received from one of their delegates at the game at the Mini Estadi, in the shadow of Barcelona's vast Nou Camp ground.

Nevertheless, Uefa's delegates were made fully aware of the FA's concern over the verbal abuse of Heskey when, at half-time, the executive director David Davies personally complained. After that a security guard was placed in the stand and the problem disappeared in the second half.

The FA spokesman Adrian Bevington said of that action: "We were satisfied our complaints to the Uefa delegates were taken up and we won't be taking the matter any further."

Davies said: "'We were acutely aware of racist chanting, Kevin Keegan particularly because it was nearer him. We did complain and it did stop.

"Thankfully racism like that is not commonplace in England and to see it so blatantly these days comes as quite a shock. It was the worst example for some time. The fact it was so systematic made it worse."

Whatever Uefa's response, Davies stressed the FA would not tolerate any outbursts of racism wherever England are represented. It was a clear message before this summer's European Championship in Belgium and the Netherlands, where England are expected to include several black players in their squad.

Davies said: "We have played a prominent part in using football to fight racism in our own country and we shall do that wherever we are, and Uefa know our views."

Kick It Out called for any Yugoslav player who spat at Heskey to be banned from European games by Uefa and the Yugoslavian football authorities to punish any fans guilty of racial abuse.

The Kick It Out spokesman Piara Powar said : "Some of the most recent cases of racial abuse have happened in the context of European club football. Lucas Radebe of Leeds suffered when they played Slavia Prague, while Andy Cole and Dwight Yorke were targeted when Manchester United faced Fiorentina.

"However, we are concerned that historically Uefa have not taken any action. There has been a wall of silence.

"It should be the same throughout Europe but you suspect Uefa don't recognise the problem the way Fifa [the world governing body] would."

Neverthless, Powar cited the case of the FA being fined £28,000 by Uefa after England fans chanted abuse at the Celtic striker Henrik Larsson during Sweden's 2-1 victory in the European qualifier in Stockholm in 1998.

fields.headline: Van Nistelrooy England-bound
fields.trailText: The £20m-rated striker Ruud van Nistelrooy will join Manchester United or Arsenal in the summer. That is the view of the PSV Eindhoven coach Eric Gerets, who is resigned to losing his prolific goalscorer after the club promised not to stand in the way of the 23-year-old's ambition.
fields.body:
The £20m-rated striker Ruud van Nistelrooy will join Manchester United or Arsenal in the summer. That is the view of the PSV Eindhoven coach Eric Gerets, who is resigned to losing his prolific goalscorer after the club promised not to stand in the way of the 23-year-old's ambition.

United and Arsenal have both had the player watched, and Leeds and Chelsea have also shown interest. But Gerets thinks Van Nistelrooy's signing is a two-horse race.

"I have learned about Manchester United's interest in Ruud from a number of people on the football circuit," he said. "Arsenal are also showing serious interest in him and my gut feeling is that his next club will be one of these two."

Despite recently being sidelined with a knee injury, Van Nistelrooy has scored 29 goals this season after knocking in 31 in 32 games last season.

The Newcastle manager Bobby Robson is lining up a summer deal for Manchester City's Nicky Weaver that would make him the most expensive goalkeeper in England.

If City reach the Premiership Weaver may stay, but if their promotion bid fails it would strengthen Newcastle's bargaining hand for a player with international ambitions.

Sunderland's Swedish international midfield player Stefan Schwarz is expected to be out for up to six months after undergoing an operation yesterday on a ruptured achilles tendon sustained in Wednesday night's friendly in Austria.

Bradford City's fight against relegation suffered a blow yes terday when Jamie Lawrence was ruled out for the rest of the season after breaking his jaw in a training collision with his team-mate Gunnar Halle.

Karlheinz Riedle was yesterday confirmed as caretaker manager of Fulham. The former German international will take temporary charge of team affairs until the end of the season.

The Wolves striker Ade Akinbiyi has been given a further one-match ban for refusing to leave the field promptly after his sending-off against Nottingham Forest. He has already been fined £2,000 and served a three-match suspension for violent conduct.

West Brom's manager Gary Megson has been charged with bringing the game into disrepute after being ordered to leave the Portsmouth dug-out.

webTitle: Warning shots from the front line

fields.headline: Warning shots from the front line
fields.standfirst:
Giving cash directly to key services hands Whitehall too much power

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Giving cash directly to key services hands Whitehall too much power.
fields.body:
Who can argue against more cash going straight to head teachers, doctors on the ward and bobbies on the beat?

Downing Street has reported it wants to deliver additional resources to "frontline services" and that this will be a key theme of today's special cabinet meeting to discuss the next general election and the second-term manifesto. How can a commitment to deliver cash to frontline services be anything other than a winner?

But it is important to peer behind the spin around "frontline first", a theme which emerged from Downing Street last week in the wake of the allocation of more money for health and education in the Budget. The danger is that it masks a real shift of power away from local government and back to control by Whitehall. We could, unless we are careful, be witnessing the strange death of local democracy.

"Cut out the middle man" is the message coming from government briefings, with local councils, NHS trusts and chief constables all in the firing line. Yet this gung-ho approach to improving services marks a dramatic retreat from one of the truly innovative and radical features of the Blair government.

Up until now, this administration has recognised, in a way that no previous government has, that the most pressing problems facing society are messy and complex. There is no easy answer to issues such as low educational attainment, drug addiction, crime, high mortality rates and social exclusion. Old-fashioned, blinkered single-service approaches simply don't work. They dig the kind of public expenditure black hole which ministers quite rightly want to avoid.

This government has called for the end of departmentalism in Whitehall. A year ago the Modernising Government white paper committed the government to delivering a big push on obstacles to what they have described as joined-up government. The paper encouraged initiatives to establish partnerships in delivering services, by all parts of government, local, regional and central, in ways that fit local circumstances.

More recently the Performance and Innovation Unit, the prime minister's intellectual hit squad, has pressed the same theme. Reaching Out, the unit's report on government activity at a local level, argues unequivocally that improved delivery of government objectives - especially on education, health, crime competitiveness, sustainable development and social exclusion - hinges on better mechanisms to link different policies at the local level.

The report pointed out that the proliferation of action zones epitomises departmentalism at its worst. Health action zones, employment zones, education action zones and the New Deal for Communities have each been promoted by different camps in the Whitehall jungle with little or no coordination.

But the fact is that "frontline first" and the general move toward more ring-fencing of resources are pushing relentlessly in the direction of greater central control.

Some say the government is now doing to health what it has already done to education - sending in inspectorates with a mandate to name and shame. In fact what is happening is the other way round, with education beginning to resemble the health service. If more and more money for schools is distributed direct from Whitehall, education will become a national service, as health has been since Bevan prevailed over Morrison's municipalism in 1947.

The gist of David Blunkett's case for funding schools directly is the inequalities that are allegedly built into the current arrangements. Yet the issue currently at the heart of the health debate is the postcode lottery, with frightening variations in service standards and outcomes across the country.

The history of the health service shows how difficult it is to run responsive local services from Whitehall. Bevan claimed that every time a bedpan was dropped in a hospital ward the clang echoed around Whitehall. Between them Tony Blair and David Blunkett are creating a regime in which every time a mouse mat, or a piece of chalk falls onto a classroom floor, the sound also reverberates around Whitehall.

The belittling of the role of local councillors by government is not confined to local funding decisions. Their role in leading local communities and representing the interests of their constituents is also under concerted attack.

The government is right to want to get funds to these front lines, but it must be done in a way that ensures priorities can be set locally in consultation with local communities. The result will be less control in Whitehall, but the chance of real improvement on the ground. Which is the more important?

 Sir Jeremy Beecham is Labour chairman of the Local Government Association

webTitle: Ashcroft told: end exile or lose title

fields.headline: Ashcroft told: end exile or lose title
fields.standfirst: Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: March 31 2000: The Conservative party treasurer, Michael Ashcroft, last night suffered the public indignity of having his long-coveted peerage explicitly made conditional upon his return from tax exile to live permanently in Britain - by the end of this year.
fields.body:
The Conservative party treasurer, Michael Ashcroft, last night suffered the public indignity of having his long-coveted peerage explicitly made conditional upon his return from tax exile to live permanently in Britain - by the end of this year.

The Florida-based billionaire, who has pumped £1m a year into William Hague's defeated Tory party since 1997, is the most eyecatching name on the list of 33 working peers announced this morning.

Twenty are Labour, including the economist Richard Layard, the publisher Matthew Evans of Faber & Faber, the academic and race relations expert Professor Bhikhu Parekh, and five hereditary grandees restored to the Lords by Downing Street patronage.

With the Conservatives confined to four newcomers and the Liberal Democrats to nine, Labour now has more life peers than the Tories in the half-reformed Lords, 198 to 184. No party has a majority.

In imposing unprecedented conditions on the Ashcroft honour, the three-strong public honours scrutiny committee (PHSC), which vetoed the controversial financier's nomination last year, insisted that a foreign-domiciled tycoon could hardly be a working peer, willing to turn up regularly and vote on the legislative treadmill.

In last-minute wrangling the committee - Lord Hurd (Tory), Lady Dean (Labour), and its chairman, Lord Thomson (Lib Dem) - did not reject Mr Hague's nominee outright. But they demanded his "clear and unequivocal assurance" that he will come home to live and pay his taxes. "That really is quite unprecedented," said one insider.

The struggle follows prolonged newspaper criticism of his business track record last year, including claims of money-laundering, leading to an Ashcroft libel suit against the Times, settled out of court.

Senior Tories deny claims that Mr Hague had to plead directly with Tony Blair for his candidate. Downing Street said discussions were "nothing to do with us", but confined to the PHSC.

The dispute was only resolved this week.

Last night Labour and Liberal Democrats denounced the new Lord Ashcroft as a "conditional peer" for whom the rules had been bent because he had given £3m from his £1bn fortune to shore up the Tories.

The Labour MP Peter Bradley warned that Mr Hague would regret his "coronets-for-cash deal" on behalf of a tax exile who had been Belize's UN ambassador. Mr Ashcroft has now resigned that post, senior Tories revealed last night.

Mr Ashcroft himself said that he was "thrilled and honoured" to be able to make a contribution to the Lords "as a businessman, a campaigner against drugs and as a political party fundraiser".

So close and important is Mr Ashcroft's relationship to Tory party financial affairs that some Labour experts believe his elevation breaches the 1925 Honours (Prevention of Abuses) Act, which explicitly forbids attempts to procure honours in return for "gifts, money or valuable considerations".

The legislation followed the Liberal prime minister Lloyd George's blatant sale of honours. Some Tory MPs and peers are privately appalled, but party HQ loyally stood by the man who pays the bills.

The Tories pointed to Labour's nomination of the retired TV executive Alexander Bernstein as a known £5,000 Labour donor, and again accused Mr Blair of "packing the Lords full of cronies". In fact No10 found it hard to find people of talent willing to do the work and reputedly trawled the City and academia.

Daniel Brennan QC, chairman of the bar council, is on the Labour list. So is the TUC veteran Bill Jordan, and Janet Cohen, an ex-BBC governor and banker. Among the Lib Dem nominees, picked by Charles Kennedy from a list voted for by his party conference, is the grassroots activist and troublemaker Tony Greaves.

In his long career as the epitome of bearded and uncompromising Liberalism, untainted by the fleshpots of London, few colleagues would ever have seen Mr Greaves accepting ermine.

fields.headline: Ashcroft and the pedigree chums
fields.standfirst: Cash and coronets are linked by long tradition. As the Tory treasurer  is finally offered a seat on the Lords' red banquettes, Derek Brown looks at the rich history of political preferment.
fields.trailText: March 31 2000: Cash and coronets are linked by long tradition. As the Tory treasurer is finally offered a seat on the Lords' red banquettes, Derek Brown looks at the rich history of political preferment.
fields.body:
Michael Ashcroft's elevation to the House of Lords, along with 32 other new peers, belongs to a long tradition of preferment for the rich and influential.

The Tory treasurer, who has given £1m to his party each year since 1997, has long coveted a seat on the red leather benches of the upper house. His nomination was vetoed last year by the public honours scrutiny committee, which objected to his residency in, and citizenship of, the Central American tax haven Belize.

Now he has been accepted into the nation's top club, but only on condition that he returns from tax exile to make his permanent home in Britain. The three-member scrutiny committee, unprecedentedly, demanded a "clear and unequivocal assurance" that Mr Ashcroft will come home and start paying his taxes, by the end of this year.

According to Conservative sources, he has already given up his other plum public appointment, as Belize's ambassador to the United Nations, although it seems he will retain his joint citizenship of Belize and the UK.

Some senior Tories are reportedly dismayed by William Hague's promotion of the self-made billionaire banker, who has built his enormous fortune through ruthless business dealing. Others are simply relieved that the party's most generous benefactor is still on board.

There is nothing particularly novel about a peerage going to a political patron. For hundreds of years monarchs and party bosses have granted the coveted coronets of privilege to their supporters and backers. In remote times, the king would reward his generals, fund-raisers, relatives and mistresses with land and titles. Most of the hereditary peers of Britain can claim descent, in the memorable phrase of the republican Labour MP Willie Hamilton, from mercenary soldiers, cattle thieves, and whores.

Peer-creation has often been a nice little earner for the throne. King James I was an enthusiastic seller of honours in the early 17th century. He even invented a new rank of not-quite-noble baronets, the hereditary knights. So fond was he of dubbing his chosen ones that he even rewarded a particularly choice cut of beef - which is why today we eat "sir" loin. James's penchant for peers was continued by his Stuart successors, particularly Charles II, who handed a clutch of dukedoms to his favourite mistresses.

The old tradition of ennobling great soldiers has survived to our own times. The first world war produced a clutch of military and naval earls. Viscountcies - one rank down - were more commonly distributed to the more distinguished generals of the second world war. More recently, an army chief became a life peer, as Lord Carver.

But for at least two centuries, most peerages have been distributed more or less openly in return for political services rendered. Cronies of successive prime ministers and financial backers of political parties have been particularly favoured. David Lloyd George, the last Liberal prime minister, notoriously amassed a large political slush fund from the contributions made by grateful and gratified new peers. He also famously threatened the old nobility that unless they accepted his radical budget proposals, he would swamp their hallowed house with hundreds of new placemen. They climbed down.

Now that the owners of hereditary titles have been reduced to a rump, the House of Lords is dominated by the life peers, virtually all of whom have been selected by party leaders. Old Labour's distaste for the system meant that from the 1970s, the party was ever more heavily outgunned in the upper chamber. New Labour has no such scruples. The latest intake includes 20 government supporters and nine LibDems.
