fields.headline: Tie die
fields.standfirst: Get ready for 'career casual'. As companies relax their rules on clothes for the office, retailers are pushing a new concept in workwear.  Jess Cartner-Morley reports on the hard sell of dressing down
fields.trailText: Unless you've been hiding in Savile Row for the past few years, you will have noticed that the codes which govern dressing for work have undergone a drastic rewrite. What began in the US as the "dress-down Friday" trend has snowballed. Now, many former suit-clad offices are a sea of Gap khakis.
fields.body:
Unless you've been hiding in Savile Row for the past few years, you will have noticed that the codes which govern dressing for work have undergone a drastic rewrite. What began in the US as the "dress-down Friday" trend has snowballed. Now, many former suit-clad offices are a sea of Gap khakis.

The full force of the shift hit me in Sainsbury's when, unable to find what I was looking for, I instinctively scanned the horizon for a shop assistant wearing patterned nylon. No joy - but, on closer inspection, there was a distinctly higher-than-average number of orange fleeces bobbing around. Orange is, of course, very fashionable this season, but I'm under no illusions that anyone will actually wear it. No: the orange fleeces are the new Sainsbury's uniform.

Now that dressing down for work has spread from ad agency brainstormings to supermarket aisles, the clothing industry has seized the opportunity to sell us a whole new wardrobe to replace those stuffy old suits. Companies such as Gap and French Connection are reaping the benefits of demand for simply-cut trousers, knitwear and good-quality open-collared shirts. So it was only a matter of time before someone came up with a snappy name for it: clear your wardrobes for "career casual".

In the US, which is light years ahead of us in the dressing-down stakes, career casual departments are springing up in every store. (Some brands did try to push "business appropriate", but the less-than-snappy phrase didn't stick.) For men, there are cotton chinos, open-necked shirts, short-sleeved shirts, v-neck sweaters; for women, separates and knitwear but with detailing - a scalloped hem, a three-quarter length sleeve - that demarcates them from old-school office-wear. Brands such as Tommy Hilfiger and DKNY are planning new ranges aimed at the casual office, while Levi's is making inroads on the same market by investing heavily in the chino boom: for many people for whom jeans are still too casual for the office, chinos have become a staple. The clothes themselves are nothing new, but the signposting is - what retailers have realised is that while most of us prefer a casual dress code, we are as yet unconfident as to the precise boundaries of it. Career casual departments take the uncertainty out of the new working wardrobe.

Last week, when New York law firm Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft announced that it was joining Goldman Sachs & Co and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter as part of the first wave of Wall St firms to adopt a casual dress code, it revealed that the company had asked Polo Ralph Lauren to give seminars to its staff on how to dress down. A seminar in the finer points of not doing the top button of your shirt up might seem excessive to those who are comfortable with a casual office, but not everyone is. An employee of a London law firm that has recently gone casual has noticed that "the older people here seem really uncomfortable about giving up suits."

Ten years ago, media had turned casual, while business was still formal - but the dot.com frenzy, which has highlighted twentysomethings in jeans as the new business leaders, is changing this. Additionally, law and management consultancy firms whose clients are increasingly casual are following suit. Robert O Link, managing partner of Cadwalader, says: "A number of our leading clients have gone casual full-time and it is important that they be comfortable around us."

Men are the easiest prey for the career casual hard sell, because they are less well-versed in the infinite steps on the ladder between beachwear and black tie. Women, on the other hand, are on familiar territory: in any changing room you'll hear women discussing whether this suede skirt is acceptable for work if worn with a sober jumper, or whether that skirt could be dressed up with high heels, or if the colour of that jacket makes it a bit too garish for daytime. Office casual is not, after all, a question of swapping a pinstripe suit for jeans and trainers: each office, even each department, has its own often unspoken rules, which might exclude trainers but include jeans, or include both but not together. In such a minefield, men end up playing safe. Just as women inject more variety into their outfits in a formal office than men do, in a casual office there is often a tighter "uniform" among the men - say, khakis and white shirt, or in a more casual office, jeans and a short-sleeved shirt.

As personal shopping manager for Harvey Nichols, Christina Abbott has been besieged with calls from men demanding her help. "Lots of them are the husbands of my clients. Suddenly they've been given a casual dress code at work, and they don't know what to do." Abbott has also been targeted by "lots of city companies" to help them and their staff get to grips with a casual office. She teaches them about colour and fabric, explaining that if you stick to a neutral palette, you can experiment with more outlandish styles. Some men, of course, are adept at this - the hordes of young men who sport purple or green YSL shirts on a Saturday night have clearly figured out the dress-up power of colour. "It's the same for women, of course. I wouldn't send someone to work in a hooded sweatshirt if it was in bright pink, but if it was DKNY, say, in a neutral colour and really beautiful wool, and was paired with perfectly tailored trousers, it might look right."

Despite the pitfalls, most people prefer not having to be suited and booted. A recent US survey found that non-suited workers not only felt happier, but were also perceived by others as "more reasonable" and "nicer". The casualwear companies are even happier: Anita Borzwszkowska, European PR director for The Gap, admits the casual office trend is "a tremendous opportunity for us". Borzwszkowska predicts that the trend will plateau - "We're not going to be wearing tracksuit bottoms to the office" - but that more companies will join in.

Career casual departments may turn out to be a short-lived phenomenon: many in the retail industry predict that we will move towards a homogenised work-to-weekend wardrobe. The most lasting effect of the casual office trend is likely to be to encourage men to think about what they wear. "The nice thing about the drive towards smart casual for men is that it smartens up their weekend wardrobe," says Abbott. Borzwszkowska agrees: when men can't hide behind a suit, they "need to put a bit more effort into what they wear. And having to make an effort has taken the stigma out of making an effort."

webTitle: US growth hits high despite Fed's curbs

fields.headline: US growth hits high despite Fed's curbs
fields.trailText: Economic growth in the United States surged ahead at its fastest pace for nearly 16 years in the final quarter of last year despite repeated attempts by the Federal Reserve to slow it down by raising interest rates.
fields.body:
Economic growth in the United States surged ahead at its fastest pace for nearly 16 years in the final quarter of last year despite repeated attempts by the Federal Reserve to slow it down by raising interest rates.

Confirming expectations of more monetary tightening to come, the commerce department said that gross domestic product growth accelerated to a blistering annual rate of 7.3% between October and December, an upward revision from the previously reported 6.9%.

It was the most vigorous quarterly growth rate since the 9% recorded in the first quarter of 1984 when the American economy was recovering from recession. The figures showed that growth was evenly balanced, with all the main components strongly up.

The Federal Reserve has raised short-term interest rates five times since last summer in an effort to brake the pace of expansion and prevent inflation taking off.

But yesterday's figures reinforced speculation in financial markets of a more aggressive stance in future months.

Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago president Michael Moskow said incremental rate rises had been appropriate so far, but that the Federal Reserve was reassessing that.

Noting that the average US growth rate of 4.5% in the past few years was unsustainable, Mr Moskow said: "It is appropriate for us to move in the fashion we have in order to maximise the chances that our policy is going to be effective."

William McDonough, president of the New York Fed bank, said the US central bank was prepared to keep raising interest rates until it saw clear signs of a deceleration in consumer spending.

fields.trailText: Stacks of discounted Flat Erics might be piling up in toy stores throughout the land, but it hasn't deterred those eager ad folk from coming up with their own versions of the guileless, button-eyed yellow thing. It looks like Eric might have done a spot of mating during his 15 minutes of TV fame. How else to explain the appearance of Harvey and Hibby, two hand- knitted creatures (trendy ecru wool, mind) with crosses for noses and woolly eyes? They front Harvey Nichols' new spring ad campaign, dressed in miniature versions of the latest designer labels.
fields.body:
Stacks of discounted Flat Erics might be piling up in toy stores throughout the land, but it hasn't deterred those eager ad folk from coming up with their own versions of the guileless, button-eyed yellow thing. It looks like Eric might have done a spot of mating during his 15 minutes of TV fame. How else to explain the appearance of Harvey and Hibby, two hand- knitted creatures (trendy ecru wool, mind) with crosses for noses and woolly eyes? They front Harvey Nichols' new spring ad campaign, dressed in miniature versions of the latest designer labels.

Meanwhile, Sony's forthcoming website has Socket, a crude sock puppet agony uncle who offers a stream of bad advice. And new on our TV screens this month is Hoopy McHula, a pale blue critter with saucer eyes whose head sticks out of a Hulp Hoop packet. Like Eric, Hoopy is portrayed as nonchalantly cool - scoring the winning goal on the football pitch and the prettiest girl in the club while his 16-year-old human friend looks on jealously.

Flat Eric fronted what was arguably one of Levi's most successful advertising campaigns: endlessly discussed and analysed, he caught the imagination of pundits and punters alike. At a time when advertising agencies are struggling to find ways of appealing to the fickle youth market, puppets make perfect sense: genderless and mute, they're less likely to rub anyone up the wrong way. Its a furry old world, indeed.

fields.headline: Lara Bohinc 107
fields.trailText: Lara Bohinc 107's conceptual, dynamic jewellery designs in an eclectic mix of materials are way out on their own. Who else would design a braille choker, with inverted lettering so that even blind people can't read it? And how about a pair of sterling silver headphones that you wear over your ears - but can't hear through? Curiouser and curiouser.
fields.body:
Lara Bohinc 107's conceptual, dynamic jewellery designs in an eclectic mix of materials are way out on their own. Who else would design a braille choker, with inverted lettering so that even blind people can't read it? And how about a pair of sterling silver headphones that you wear over your ears - but can't hear through? Curiouser and curiouser.

Those fashion obsessives among you might be experiencing a touch of déjà vu about this name. And rightly so: Bohinc used to design under the aeroplane-inspired moniker Lara Boeing 747. She had to change her name because the real Boeing company objected. Lara has now reverted to her own surname, Bohinc, adding the 107 bit because it was the number on her hospital band when she was a baby. Why, of course.

After moving here from her native Slovenia in the early 90s, Bohinc completed an MA in jewellery and metalwork at the Royal College of Art and then gained recognition by winning the prestigious New Generation Design Award, sponsored by M&S, in 1997. From there she went to London Fashion Week, then tried her hand in Paris. Her jewellery has been used in shows by designers as diverse as Costume Nationale, Kosuke Tsumara, Guy Laroche and Andrew Groves.

Like any restless spirit, though, now that Bohinc has established her name as a jewellery designer (selling in fashion hot-spots including Selfridges, Browns Focus and Vexed Generation), she has decided to move on to her next goal: accessories. Launching later this year is a collection of bags with a difference (see picture below). Leather and metal shells with translucent perspex handles; engraved metal cigarette cases in the spirit of Marlene Dietrich and spherial perspex bags moulded with sterling silver clasps and chains are as out-there as Bohinc's jewellery. Louis Vuitton, watch your back.

Available from Harrods, 0171-730 1234

fields.headline: Most wanted:  Oyster
fields.body: Time was when anyone hailing from the north had to travel grudgingly to London to satisfy their designer cravings. But with the arrival of Harvey Nichols in Leeds and the Trafford centre outside Manchester, northern lasses have never had it so good. More so, it seems, with the opening of Oyster, a new fashion mecca in Manchester's city centre which can be found at 1 Booth Street, Manchester M2 (0161 839 7575). Featuring a selection of the UK's hippest designers, Oyster indulges in the delicious creations of Matthew Williamson, Tracey Boyd, Megan Park, Uniform and Studd, to name but a few. You can also find Claudia Rapisarda knitted hair accessories and feather necklaces along side Noguchi suede aprons and sweet Luna Bi skirts - as obscure a bundle of designers as you'd expect to find in any Notting Hill boutique.

fields.headline: Japanese volcano erupts
fields.standfirst: The site of the eruption: graphic
fields.trailText: Japan's snow-capped Mount Usu volcano erupted today, spewing out a huge column of smoke and ash and hurling a flood of volcanic ash and rock toward a small nearby town.
fields.body:
Japan's snow-capped Mount Usu volcano erupted today, spewing out a huge column of smoke and ash and hurling a flood of volcanic ash and rock toward a small nearby town.

There were no reports of injuries or damage, and the eruption appeared to be abating - at least temporarily - three hours after it sent a huge column of ash and debris shooting into the sky early in the afternoon.

Officials warned that the danger was far from over, however. "It is possible that widespread damage could result from this eruption," chief cabinet spokesman Mikio Aoki said from the government's emergency headquarters in Tokyo. Prime minister Keizo Obuchi was also at the headquarters monitoring the situation.

Roughly 51,000 people live in the coastal city of Date and several smaller towns near Usu, 475 miles north of Tokyo on the island of Hokkaido. Experts had predicted the eruption because of increased seismic activity that began earlier this week, and the evacuation of more than 11,000 people began on Wednesday.

Almost immediately after the eruption, volcanic ash began to rain down on nearby towns. Residents downwind were soon also enveloped by the pungent, rotten smell of sulphur. The coast guard, military and police mobilised to evacuate the town of Abuta, which lies between the volcano and the sea. It has a population of 13,000, but thousands had already been evacuated and it was not immediately known how many people were still there.

Seven ships, two helicopters and several dozen trucks were deployed amid concerns at the possibility of landslides or mudslides caused by melting snow. Before the eruption, snow 1ft deep covered much of the 2,416-ft volcano. There had been no rumbling, no explosion and no screams. Mount Usu erupted in the afternoon in near silence, just a blue-grey plume of rock and ash billowing over the crater and down the snowy slopes.

"I didn't feel anything, I didn't hear anything," said Norimichi Nagao, a resident of nearby Date, which escaped the ash fall. "I didn't know there was an eruption until I saw it on television." With so many residents in the three towns evacuated, the eruption became more of a public spectacle than a threat. People rushed onto the streets and rooftops to take photographs, relaxed and prepared after days of high-level warnings.

Cars coming in from other areas around the mountain were covered in dust, however, and Abuta and Sobetsu were ghost towns. "Some kids and some parents are a bit jittery, but you couldn't call this a panic," said Daisuke Kadoaki, an official at the Abuta town office. He said nearly all of the residents had left.

The number of people in evacuation centres is however expected to rise. Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi has warned that evacuees may have to stay put for a while, and said the government would consider building temporary housing. At the centres, where families are marking off private space with blankets and cardboard partitions, officials are concerned about the effects of stress.

Two people were killed and 200 homes destroyed in mudslides following Usu's last eruptions, which began in 1977 and continued for several months into the following year. Today, the plume rose from the volcano amid generally clear skies. Within two hours, it had risen to a height of 10,560 feet. Mobile phone service was briefly cut off, but was quickly restored. Some domestic flights to Hokkaido were suspended, but international flights were not delayed.

Most of the ash appeared to be wafting northeast over a nearby lake, and not over the more populous areas. "We are worried that the wind direction will change," said Date mayor Hidekichi Kikuya. "We have been spared so far, but that could change."

This is the seventh major eruption of Mount Usu in the past 300 years. Fifty people died when the volcano erupted in 1822 in its most lethal eruption. Japan, one of the world's most eruption-prone countries, has not had a fatal eruption since 1991. An eruption of the 4,459-foot Mount Unzen that year sent avalanches of hot rocks sweeping through the outskirts of the town of Shimabara, in southern Japan, killing 43 people and leaving nearly 2,300 homeless. Officials were concerned that Usu would also spew a similar mix of gas and rocks.

fields.headline: Houses in motion
fields.standfirst: The transfer of housing provision from councils to registered social landlords is a great opportunity, but not without risks
fields.trailText: There has been talk recently - in the media at least - about the strange death of the council house. Local authorities are to lose their 130-year-old role as landlords, providing houses and flats for rent. In fact the green paper on housing due to be published next week will not go so far. A better characterisation of the government's position is that it is agnostic about municipal landlordism. But the curves on the accompanying graph could be extrapolated. It is certain the town hall estate will continue declining.
fields.body:
There has been talk recently - in the media at least - about the strange death of the council house. Local authorities are to lose their 130-year-old role as landlords, providing houses and flats for rent. In fact the green paper on housing due to be published next week will not go so far. A better characterisation of the government's position is that it is agnostic about municipal landlordism. But the curves on the accompanying graph could be extrapolated. It is certain the town hall estate will continue declining.

During the past decade the housing landscape has changed dramatically. As owner-occupation has levelled off and the private rented sector struggled to find its feet, major shifts have taken place within social housing (dwellings provided by public or not-for-profit landlords mainly for people on lower incomes). The 1988 Housing Act allowed housing associations to raise private finance. (In the jargon associations, some charitable, others not-for-profit companies, are called registered social landlords, or RSLs). They quickly became the main providers of new housing for rent, gaining support across the political spectrum. Private funds committed to RSLs now total £16.9bn.

Councils were not given the same access to private money for repairs or new building. At the same time the Tory policy of giving tenants a right-to-buy had cut the stock of council housing. By the end of the 80s, local government's housing role was much reduced.

Since then, the most significant development has been the acceleration of the transfer of council housing to RSLs, either existing housing associations or new trusts created for the purpose. In the decade to 1997, 250,000 council homes were transferred. The Department of the Environment, Transport and Regions (DETR) has just approved the transfer of over 160,000 homes. In the offing is the transfer of the giant estates owned by the city of Birmingham and Sunderland. Whether this rate of transfer can be sustained is debatable. It is a realistic prediction, however, that within five years we will see RSLs becoming the major provider of social housing. On present trends, council housing would then disappear by 2015.

There are good reasons for this shift. Transferring council houses and flats to trusts and associations makes private money available. The RSLs can borrow to deal with the backlog of disrepair, now estimated at some £18-20bn. (Lenders have the security of future rent payments.) The government likes this. Its priorities are health and education; housing money will not come from the public pocket. Councils have for years advocated that they should enjoy a level playing field on which they too might borrow money from the private market without having it scored as public spending. The Treasury has consistently said no and stifled any sensible debate about this alternative.

Now political resistance to transfer is waning among councillors. Many more councils and their tenants are embracing transfer, perceiving it as the only means of accessing much-needed investment. As for Westminster, it is hard to gauge the political appetite for abolishing council housing. Tony Blair's modernising government sees local authorities as enablers and strategists not direct providers of public services, but many MPs have constituents who are happy to remain council tenants.

So will the government like what the end of the road looks like? Transfer is not just a move from public to private ownership; it can be an opportunity for a new approach to involving tenants and communities. In Glasgow there is a proposal to shift all the city's public housing to community-based trusts and groups. Done well, this could allow for much more participation by residents in decision-making about where and how they live.

Yet transfer is a one-off, one-way change of ownership. There is only one chance to get it right. Anxiety about the tenants' role and welfare may explain the caution over the proposed transfers in Birmingham and Sunderland: they have been postponed until better proposals are put forward by the councils. These are, after all, people's homes.

Fundamentally, we should question whether we want to go down the road of a total transfer of the councils' stock. It will put all social housing in the hands of largely autonomous bodies - quangos in fact if not in name. These organisations will have growing financial strength and potentially vast resources. Many RSLs are using their new-found property portfolios positively, but this cannot be guaranteed. Above them sits a regulator in the shape of the Housing Corporation, appointed by the DETR. It is going to struggle to cope with such a rapidly growing sector.

In future councils - if they are still responsible for housing the homeless and ensuring a local supply of rental property - will need to work with a plethora of housing providers rather than relying on their own assets. Will they be able to get their way by persuasion? We may need to resort to more coercive mechanisms. We may regret giving away a necessary public policy tool.

None the less, transfer is a victory of pragmatism over tradition. It will allow access to much needed investment, and if done well offers a chance for innovative approaches to community involvement. It is, however, a step in the dark. The long range consequences of transfer are unknown and we should tread carefully.

 Susan Regan works at the Institute for Public Policy Research

fields.headline: Interview: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau
fields.standfirst: Stephen Moss meets the legendary singer
fields.trailText: Stephen Moss meets the legendary singer
fields.body:
Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, one of the greatest singers of the 20th century, will be 75 in May, but he would rather not think about it. "I don't want too much attention," he says. "Seventy-five is a stupid number anyway." His record company, Deutsche Grammophon, disagrees and is releasing a 21-CD set of his recordings, and on Sunday he makes his belated debut at London's Wigmore Hall, discussing his career with Sir John Tooley at an event to raise funds for young musicians.

Fischer-Dieskau retired in 1992 after a remarkable 50-year career in lieder and opera, but his recorded legacy - he is perhaps the most recorded artist in the world - has ensured that his musicianship lives on. The new DG compilation includes some previously unreleased material, including a recording of Schubert's Die Schöne Müllerin made with Jörg Demus in 1968.

Fischer-Dieskau's house is in a leafy suburb of West Berlin. He has lived here since 1949 and it fits him perfectly: large but not lavish, exuding serenity. He is charming and courteous, serving tea in delicate china cups and apologising for his English (which is very good). He wants no fuss over his birthday - just as, when he retired, he preferred not to have a gala farewell ("far too sad and final") - yet he is by no means self-effacing: he knows the extent of his achievement. He seems to have complete recall of his career - he sang Winterreise about 120 times in public and appears to remember every icy journey.

"I never sang it exactly the same way twice," he says. "I was always glad to find some new aspect. There is so much life in it, so much essence. The songs are full of colours and possibilities: you circle around them and approach the centre, but you never reach it. Schubert provides the perfect union of text and music."

How did he manage to stay at the top for half a century? "I knew how to treat my voice and had a very good understanding of it," he says. He now teaches singing and says that is the first lesson for young singers - protect the voice and develop it at the right pace. "The danger for young musicians is that they can become part of the commercial machine. Very often the natural development of a talent is hindered by that."

Fischer-Dieskau always sang parts when he felt ready rather than when others wanted him to (in his 20s he had the confidence to say no to Sir Thomas Beecham, who wanted him to sing Sachs in Meistersinger). He says that for many years he had no baritone rivals in Germany and thus did not suffer the competitive hothousing that can damage singers.

Two other factors conditioned his career: the aftermath of the second world war and the post-war boom in recorded music. The latter made him an international star, able to reach a wider audience than any singer previously. And the former made him, as a German who had fought in the war and been a teenage POW in Italy, a symbol of reconciliation. When the soloists were chosen for the premiere of Benjamin Britten's War Requiem at the rebuilt Coventry cathedral in 1962, he was the natural choice to represent his nation.

"It was not easy in the beginning," he says. "But it got better every year. I was the symbol of old-fashioned culture because the songs I sang came from former times and meant a great deal to the older people in the audience."

As a lieder singer he built a close relationship with the accompanist Gerald Moore - "a marvellous pianist and the most unpretentious person I have ever met" - that lasted for 25 years and produced recordings that still dominate the repertoire. Later, he sang with Daniel Barenboim, with whom he toured Israel, the first visit to that country by a German-speaking soloist. He also sang at the opening of both the Munich Opera House and the Deutsche Oper in Berlin, emphasising his place in post-war Germany's economic and cultural re-emergence. He sang for the final time at a New Year's Eve concert in Munich, suddenly deciding on the rightness of ending with an aria from his beloved Falstaff - "all the world is an illusion".

He still sees his singing career as part of his present, not his past. "I quite often listen to my recordings, especially to those which were recorded live," he says. "The live recordings bring back the atmosphere to me, so that I can even see the room in which the recital took place and remember the audience filling the hall."

Those audiences adored him - the reason he never sang at the Wigmore Hall was that it was too small for his legion of London fans - yet he did not seek devotion. "Adoration can be a hindrance and get in the way of a performance. It is enough if they want to listen to the music. That means a lot. Members of the audience come as single persons, from different backgrounds, with different thoughts and moods. My objective was to transform them into a whole."

Fischer-Dieskau has only one regret - that he did not begin conducting earlier. fields.bodyText: Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau, one of the greatest singers of the 20th century, will be 75 in May, but he would rather not think about it. "I don't want too much attention," he says. "Seventy-five is a stupid number anyway." His record company, Deutsche Grammophon, disagrees and is releasing a 21-CD set of his recordings, and on Sunday he makes his belated debut at London's Wigmore Hall, discussing his career with Sir John Tooley at an event to raise funds for young musicians. Fischer-Dieskau retired in 1992 after a remarkable 50-year career in lieder and opera, but his recorded legacy - he is perhaps the most recorded artist in the world - has ensured that his musicianship lives on. The new DG compilation includes some previously unreleased material, including a recording of Schubert's Die Schöne Müllerin made with Jörg Demus in 1968. Fischer-Dieskau's house is in a leafy suburb of West Berlin. He has lived here since 1949 and it fits him perfectly: large but not lavish, exuding serenity. He is charming and courteous, serving tea in delicate china cups and apologising for his English (which is very good). He wants no fuss over his birthday - just as, when he retired, he preferred not to have a gala farewell ("far too sad and final") - yet he is by no means self-effacing: he knows the extent of his achievement. He seems to have complete recall of his career - he sang Winterreise about 120 times in public and appears to remember every icy journey. "I never sang it exactly the same way twice," he says. "I was always glad to find some new aspect. There is so much life in it, so much essence. The songs are full of colours and possibilities: you circle around them and approach the centre, but you never reach it. Schubert provides the perfect union of text and music." How did he manage to stay at the top for half a century? "I knew how to treat my voice and had a very good understanding of it," he says. He now teaches singing and says that is the first lesson for young singers - protect the voice and develop it at the right pace. "The danger for young musicians is that they can become part of the commercial machine. Very often the natural development of a talent is hindered by that." Fischer-Dieskau always sang parts when he felt ready rather than when others wanted him to (in his 20s he had the confidence to say no to Sir Thomas Beecham, who wanted him to sing Sachs in Meistersinger). He says that for many years he had no baritone rivals in Germany and thus did not suffer the competitive hothousing that can damage singers. Two other factors conditioned his career: the aftermath of the second world war and the post-war boom in recorded music. The latter made him an international star, able to reach a wider audience than any singer previously. And the former made him, as a German who had fought in the war and been a teenage POW in Italy, a symbol of reconciliation. When the soloists were chosen for the premiere of Benjamin Britten's War Requiem at the rebuilt Coventry cathedral in 1962, he was the natural choice to represent his nation. "It was not easy in the beginning," he says. "But it got better every year. I was the symbol of old-fashioned culture because the songs I sang came from former times and meant a great deal to the older people in the audience." As a lieder singer he built a close relationship with the accompanist Gerald Moore - "a marvellous pianist and the most unpretentious person I have ever met" - that lasted for 25 years and produced recordings that still dominate the repertoire. webTitle: The Carriers are Waiting (Les Convoyeurs Attendant)

fields.headline: The Carriers are Waiting (Les Convoyeurs Attendant)
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A feature debut of enormous charm: a real jewel of a film in a crisp monochrome setting with... its own very distinctive seriocomic address to the audience
fields.body:
Benot Mariage's The Carriers are Waiting is a feature debut of enormous charm: a real jewel of a film in a crisp monochrome setting with something of Bruno Dumont or Ken Loach, but its own very distinctive seriocomic address to the audience.

Roger, an eccentric press photographer (Benot Poelvoorde), maddened by his squalid, dead-end job, harangues his family over dinner that they should make something of their lives - and decides the answer is to enter a local competition for anyone who can beat any existing world record. He forces his hapless son Michel (Jean-François Devigne) to have a crack at the world door-opening record: 40,000 times in 24 hours. Poelvoorde's performance as the tattered paterfamilias is delightful and Michel's practice sessions in the garden, in which a door has been installed, are positively Pythonesque.

webTitle: Lee stops Kiwis in their tracks

fields.headline: Lee stops Kiwis in their tracks
fields.trailText: Australia's latest fast-bowling sensation Brett Lee took another five-wicket haul as New Zealand were dismissed for 232 on the opening day of the final Test in Hamilton. The young strike bowler recovered from an erratic first spell - and a later 17-run mauling by Chris Cairns in one over - to finish with figures of 5-77 off 23 overs.
fields.body:
Australia's latest fast-bowling sensation Brett Lee took another five-wicket haul as New Zealand were dismissed for 232 on the opening day of the final Test in Hamilton. The young strike bowler recovered from an erratic first spell - and a later 17-run mauling by Chris Cairns in one over - to finish with figures of 5-77 off 23 overs.

But the touring team, bidding for their 10th consecutive Test victory, suffered a late setback when Matthew Hayden was out just before the close of play.

After being sent into bat on a relatively benign pitch, New Zealand once again struggled against Australia's opening ball partnership of Glenn McGrath and Lee.

Opener Craig Spearman survived a caught-behind appeal in Lee's first over, before confidently crashing the New South Welshman twice to the extra-cover boundary. But in the ninth over he dabbed at a McGrath outswinger and was caught by Gilchrist for twelve.

There then followed the now familiar capitulation of New Zealand's fragile top order. Within an hour 22-1 had become 53-4, and the home side were staring at a humiliating 3-0 series whitewash.

But once again the Kiwi middle-order managed to make their score respectable, with Brian McMillan and Chris Cairns taking the attack to the bowlers.

Fourth and fifth-wicket partnerships of 78 and 77 brought New Zealand to 208-5, and at one stage Cairns - who had terrorised the Australian bowlers in the second test with a first innings score of 109 and six sixes in a buccaneering 69 in the second - looked set to run riot when he smashed Lee for 17 in one over.

But then Lee struck again. Varying his blistering pace with deceptive slower balls, the New South Wales bowler picked up the wickets of McMillan for 79 and Cairns for 37. McGrath and Shane Warne then finished off the tail, with the last four New Zealand wickets falling for just 24 runs.

Lee, who has been a revelation since his debut against India on Boxing Day, has now taken 28 wickets in less than five full tests - at an average of 16.14.

The Australians were unable to survive the five overs before close of play. In ever-worsening light left-arm swing bowler Shayne O'Connor coaxed Hayden to snick one to keeper Adam Parore.

At the close Australia were 4-1, with Michael Slater on two and nightwatchman Warne yet to score.

fields.headline: April Fool's Day
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the year's funniest day on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the year's funniest day on the net
fields.body:
1. Tomorrow is April Fool's Day, the day when it's OK to tell someone their shoelaces are undone even though they're not.

2. Mischief, even something as simple as sewing a friend or family member's underpants together, is elevated to the iconic status of a prank.

3. Why? One school of thought says it's funny to watch them bite through the cotton with their teeth. Another says it's because April 1 has been this way since 1582.

4. In that year, France switched to the Gregorian calendar and New Year's Day dropped back to January.

5. Some people, however, hadn't heard or didn't believe the date change and continued to celebrate new year on April 1. Others played tricks on them and called them April fools.

6. To this day, French children fool their friends by taping a paper fish to their backs. When the young victim discovers this trick, the prankster yells "poisson d'Avril!" (April fish - but it loses something in translation.)

7. It spread from France, and now there are enough jokes and pranks for everybody to go round - including a cruel genre directed exclusively at computer programmers and net heads.

8. Offline, the world's media enjoy a laugh too. In 1996, the stories doing the rounds included news that Russia's military had developed diamond-studded grenades for nouveau-riche gangsters, Walt Disney had purchased Hadrian's Wall and style-conscious Princess Diana had taken to flying economy class.

9. The Guardian's own prank, a cheeky little ruse telling readers the Queen was setting up a website, turned out to be something of a scoop when www.royal.gov.uk materialised a couple of years later.

10. One word of warning though. If you live in England, you have until midday to perform your prank. The Scots, however, enjoy 48 hours of hunting the gowk (cuckoo) - day two is know as Taily Day and pranks involving the posterior are performed.

fields.headline: The cunning of Kennery
fields.trailText:
Ken's at it again. Mr Livingstone's pronouncements on gay rights this week 
are the sort of thing his supporters love and his enemies loathe. This is 
classic Kennery.
fields.body:
Ken's at it again. Mr Livingstone's pronouncements on gay rights this week are the sort of thing his supporters love and his enemies loathe. This is classic Kennery.

First, there's the headline-making remarks, this time : threatening to take action against Stagecoach if the bus company's boss Brian Souter continues his campaign against Section 28, and offering gay couples the chance to register their relationship in a ceremony that sounds rather like gay marriage.

Then, the next day, there's the mischievous grin, the clarification of remarks he says were slightly misunderstood. But the effect remains. The newspapers lap it up - especially in a relatively quiet week. Who needs a party machine and a million pound advertising budget when you have got his genius for self-publicity?

When I was researching a Guardian article on the case against Ken, people who claimed to share many of his views and his policies said they loathed the way that, when he was leader of the Greater London Council, ill-timed remarks would obscure or harm the good work the GLC was doing.

He might have had a point boycotting the Charles-Diana wedding, they said, but was it worth getting the goat of all the royalists in London? Then there's his ill-timed remarks on Northern Ireland at the height of the bombing campaign. And his naked enthusiasm for what Neil Kinnock calls "an assortment of zany ultra-left fads".

What bothered Labour about Ken in the 80s was the effect it had on middle England, as it shuddered to the sound of the loony left. It matters to Labour in a different way now that Ken is running as an independent. But after the man himself, the person who will be most excited at the prospect of Mayor Ken is William Hague: he can't help but make Tony Blair look bad.

There may also be plenty of people asking: is this really what London's first mayor should be talking about? But a lot of the work Ken supported on gay rights and anti-racism in the 80s is mainstream now. There will be millions of Londoners - generally more liberal than the rest of the country - who agree with him on Stagecoach, and on gay marriage. I reckon it can only help him. So, clearly, does he. Frank Dobson can go ballistic about 'gesture politics', but once more that man Ken is setting the agenda.

fields.headline: Human traffic
fields.standfirst: Death among the wreaths, love on a roll and gravy to go
fields.trailText: Death among the wreaths, love on a roll and gravy to go
fields.body:
Grave matters

If and when you next find yourself at a funeral in Aberdeen, spare a thought not merely for the family of the deceased, but also for the person conducting the service. According to a recent report by the Aberdeen Presbytery, the city's ministers are 'cracking up' under the strain of dealing with so many funerals. "Basically, too many people are dying too fast," said one minister. "We can't keep up with all the services." One funeral had to be cancelled at the last minute because the minister was too exhausted to take it. During another the minister actually passed out in the middle of a service. "He collapsed on one of the floral displays," said a shocked eyewitness. "It spelt 'Angus' in chrysanthemums, but unfortunately he fell on the letter 'g' and squashed it. The widow was very nice about it, but you could tell she was devastated." Church authorities are considering a variety of schemes to alleviate the problem, including the introduction of a special counselling service, and closer co-operation between ministers and undertakers. "They need to do something fast," said one man, "because we're being worked to death. Which of course only adds to the problem."
Aberdeen and District Independent.

All rise

Barnsley, despite many admirable qualities, is not a town one immediately associates with lovemaking. All that could be set to change, however. Thanks to the efforts of one of the town's bakeries, a loaf has been developed that's not only deliciously crusty, but also guaranteed to improve your sex life. After years of producing nothing more arousing than baps and gingerbread men, Fosters of Staincross have started pepping-up their loaves with helpings of the oriental root herb ginseng, a known aphrodisiac. "Things have been hard around here lately," said one insider. "The opposition's been getting increasingly stiff, and morale has dropped. We needed to do something to get it up again." Although initially sluggish, sales of the Love Loaf have gradually risen to the point where the bakery can now no longer keep up with demand. They have recently ordered a ton of new ginseng, and are hoping to introduce it to other baked products, including doughnuts and meat pies. "It's amazing," said one satisfied customer. "A couple of ham sarnies and I feel like Superman. The other day my wife made a bread and butter pudding and my trousers practically exploded."
Barnsley Chronicle

Hot grub

The worlds of theft and cookery came together this week with a series of gastronomic robberies. In Reading thieves broke into a local supermarket and stole 48 bottles of soy sauce, whilst in Manchester 120 frying pans were half-inched from the factory where they had been made. Most outrageous, and mouth-watering of all, was the theft of 450 cartons of gravy granules from a lorry on the A452. The lorry had been parked for the night in a lay-by near Leamington when the robbers struck, breaking into the rear of the lorry and making off with the aforementioned cartons as well as 200 boxes of stuffing. "It was mainly horse-chestnut stuffing," explained a police spokesman, "Although it appears that several boxes of sage and onion are involved as well." Police are appealing to the public for help. "If you know of anyone in the Leamington area who's been giving uncharacteristic lavish Sunday lunches, please contact us immediately," said one officer.
The Warwick Courier

Wings and a prayer

A new item was this week added to the already long list of disincentives to living in Reading: flies. Inhabitants of Whitley, on the outskirts of the Berkshire town, have been plagued by vast swarms of unseasonal bluebottles, which have been infiltrating houses and workplaces and defying all attempts to repel them. "There are millions of the damned things," said one local woman. "It's like something out of the Bible. I've tried sprays and special incense sticks, but nothing seems to have any effect. A few nights ago one of them flew into my mouth whilst I was asleep." Experts have traced the problem to a local building development, where earthmovers have disturbed nests of maggots, causing them to hatch early. Steps are now being taken to tackle the nuisance. Not everyone, however, is impressed with the way the situation has been dealt with. "I called the authorities and told them I was having fly problems," said one man, "And the girl at the other end said: 'What, got your thingy caught in the zipper, have you?' It was less than helpful."
Reading Evening Post

Letter of the Week

"Don't you think all this apologising business is getting beyond a joke, especially when the alleged crimes and misdemeanours happened yonks ago? I see that even the Pope is now at it, referring to past deeds by the Roman Catholic Church. If all the major religions follow suit I reckon all the parsons and pastors, rabis (sic) and ayatollahs will have little time left. Haven't we got enough bother without raking over the past looking for some more. It might be an idea to bring in an annual International Apology Week. Perhaps I might then get an apology from Sgt. Bradley, the drill instructor who gave me such hell on the square at Catterick. How about it Sarge? Mind you, by now he's probably waiting for me on the Other Side, ready to shout at me to get my halo on straight (assuming, of course, I get issued with one!) Sorry if this upsets anyone and I'm not just saying that. Or am I?"
A. Morrell
Lincolnshire Echo.

They have recently ordered a ton of new ginseng, and are hoping to introduce it to other baked products, including doughnuts and meat pies. "It's amazing," said one satisfied customer. "A couple of ham sarnies and I feel like Superman. The other day my wife made a bread and butter pudding and my trousers practically exploded." Barnsley Chronicle Hot grub The worlds of theft and cookery came together this week with a series of gastronomic robberies. In Reading thieves broke into a local supermarket and stole 48 bottles of soy sauce, whilst in Manchester 120 frying pans were half-inched from the factory where they had been made. Most outrageous, and mouth-watering of all, was the theft of 450 cartons of gravy granules from a lorry on the A452. The lorry had been parked for the night in a lay-by near Leamington when the robbers struck, breaking into the rear of the lorry and making off with the aforementioned cartons as well as 200 boxes of stuffing. "It was mainly horse-chestnut stuffing," explained a police spokesman, "Although it appears that several boxes of sage and onion are involved as well." Police are appealing to the public for help. "If you know of anyone in the Leamington area who's been giving uncharacteristic lavish Sunday lunches, please contact us immediately," said one officer. The Warwick Courier Wings and a prayer A new item was this week added to the already long list of disincentives to living in Reading: flies. Inhabitants of Whitley, on the outskirts of the Berkshire town, have been plagued by vast swarms of unseasonal bluebottles, which have been infiltrating houses and workplaces and defying all attempts to repel them. "There are millions of the damned things," said one local woman. "It's like something out of the Bible. I've tried sprays and special incense sticks, but nothing seems to have any effect. A few nights ago one of them flew into my mouth whilst I was asleep." Experts have traced the problem to a local building development, where earthmovers have disturbed nests of maggots, causing them to hatch early. Steps are now being taken to tackle the nuisance. Not everyone, however, is impressed with the way the situation has been dealt with. "I called the authorities and told them I was having fly problems," said one man, "And the girl at the other end said: 'What, got your thingy caught in the zipper, have you?' It was less than helpful." Reading Evening Post Letter of the Week "Don't you think all this apologising business is getting beyond a joke, especially when the alleged crimes and misdemeanours happened yonks ago? I see that even the Pope is now at it, referring to past deeds by the Roman Catholic Church. If all the major religions follow suit I reckon all the parsons and pastors, rabis (sic) and ayatollahs will have little time left. Haven't we got enough bother without raking over the past looking for some more. It might be an idea to bring in an annual International Apology Week. Perhaps I might then get an apology from Sgt. Bradley, the drill instructor who gave me such hell on the square at Catterick. How about it Sarge? Mind you, by now he's probably waiting for me on the Other Side, ready to shout at me to get my halo on straight (assuming, of course, I get issued with one!) Sorry if this upsets anyone and I'm not just saying that. Or am I?" A. Morrell Lincolnshire Echo.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Make a killing with American Psycho, former Sex Pistol in feud with Fine Line, Woody Allen signs with DreamWorks, Blair Witch dolls a hit in Tokyo, and Jodie Foster and Christian Slater on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Lions Gate Films are adding a new twist to all the hype surrounding American Psycho. In a deal they're calling "Make a Killing With American Psycho," the Canadian-based distributor and online stock-gaming site the Hollywood Stock Exchange (HSX) will offer real money to virtual investors if the picture grosses more than $20m at the box office. From Thursday, HSX traders will be able to buy 5,000 shares of American Psycho in the form of "Audience Participation Notes" at the price of $1m fake Hollywood dollars per share. If the picture grosses more than $20m in four weeks, shareholders will split $20,000 of the film's profits, courtesy of Lions Gate Films. For each additional $1m the film earns after that, investors will accrue another $1,000 to share. In other words, for investing fake dollars, online players could make real profits.

 Former Sex Pistol Johnny Rotten is feuding with Fine Line Features over its distribution plans for the Sex Pistols documentary The Filth and the Fury. Yesterday's New York Post reports that Rotten complained that Fine Line is doing little to promote the film, forcing him to take matters into his own hands and mount a 'guerrilla' PR campaign.

 Woody Allen has signed a three-picture domestic distribution deal with DreamWorks. The new deal begins with an untitled film that Allen will start in the autumn.

 Infanticide and terrorising hapless teens might not spring to mind as suitable matter for children's toys, but a Japanese toy manufacturer has produced plastic figures based on The Blair Witch Project. The Blair Witch dolls and other movie-related toys, including Planet of the Apes figures, are currently on display at the Tokyo 2000 Toy Fair. Click here for details.

Casting couch

 Jodie Foster and Morgan Freeman are to lend their voices to the DreamWorks feature cartoon Tusker, about a herd of elephants crossing Southeast Asia

 Fox has cast its animated comedy, The Ice Age: Ray Romano, John Leguizamo, and Jane Krakowski will play three prehistoric animals - a woolly mammoth, saber-toothed tiger, and giant sloth - who rescue a human baby.

 Peter and Bobby Farrelly, are once again pursuing their fascination with bodily functions and will be directing the live action elements of Warner Bros' partially animated Osmosis Jones. Touted as InnerSpace meets Being John Malkovich meets Who Framed Roger Rabbit, the comedy is about the battle between germs and the immune system. "Our plates are pretty full, but it's the best script I've seen my whole time in the business," Bobby Farrelly told EW Online. Bill Murray is up for the role of the host body where the film's animated action takes place, and Chris Rock looks set to play the rogue germ warrior. Warner Bros are anticipating a summer 2001 release.

 Jena Malone (Stepmom) is to star in The Dangerous Lives of Altar Boys, to be produced by Jodie Foster and Meg Lefauve through their Egg Pictures. Foster plans to take on a small role as a nun.

 Tim Allen and Christian Slater are negotiating to star in Cletis Tout, a comedy about mistaken identity written and to be directed by Chris Ver Wiel. Slater is negotiating to play an escaped convict who takes on the identity of the title character, who happens to be dead. That plan goes awry when he realises that the previous holder of the name Cletis Tout is slated to be rubbed out by a hitman, a quirky assassin to be played by Allen.

 The duo behind Independence Day and Godzilla are producing Arach Attack, an f/x-driven comedic thriller about a toxic waste spill causes giant spiders to go on a rampage. The picture, said to be budgeted at under $30m, will start shooting in September in Australia. New Zealander Ellory Elkayem will direct from a script he co-wrote with Jesse Alexander.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Today's paper talk put through the wringer, and then left out to dry on a clothes horse
fields.trailText: The Daily Mail Jorg Albertz is set for a £2.5m summer move to Everton after falling out of favour with Rangers coach Dick Advocaat. The Merseyside club have a £13m overdraft, but money from the £20m deal with NTL will be made available to Walter Smith.
fields.body:
The Daily Mail Jorg Albertz is set for a £2.5m summer move to Everton after falling out of favour with Rangers coach Dick Advocaat. The Merseyside club have a £13m overdraft, but money from the £20m deal with NTL will be made available to Walter Smith.

Benito Carbone has denounced tabloid whispers about his £40,000 a week pay demands. The flamboyant Italian forward said: "I am tired of all these lies about me. I am tired of all this talk. People say I wanted £40,000 a week, which is a lie. I am not being greedy."

Sir Alex Ferguson is ready to snatch Millwall's 15 year-old Cherno Samba from under the noses of Liverpool. Samba is a staunch United fan despite being from South London - and is hugely flattered by Ferguson's interest.

The Mirror Tottenham boss George Graham is ready to take a £5m loss on record signing Les Ferdinand - to finance a summer swoop for Chris Sutton. Graham is also keeping tabs on Dynamo Kiev striker Sergei Rebrov and Barcelona's out-of-favour Spanish international forward Dani.

Chris Waddle is the new favourite for the Sheffield Wednesday managers job - after Howard Wilkinson refused to be lured back to Hillsborough. Wednesday chairman Howard Culley is considering asking current reserve team boss Waddle to pair up with caretaker manager Peter Shreeves.

The Express Arsenal boss Arsene Wenger is lining up a £3m bid for Inter Milan forward Mohammed Kallon. Kallon has never started a Serie A match for Inter, but has scored 10 goals in 24 games during his current loan spell at Reggina.

The Sun Newcastle are poised to smash the record transfer fee for a keeper to land Manchester City's Nicky Weaver. Bobby Robson is ready to make a £5m move for the England U-21 star this summer.

webTitle: Willy Wonka and the remake factory

fields.headline: Willy Wonka and the remake factory
fields.trailText: News from the Roald Dahl official site roalddahl.org, which reports that following a meeting with Roald Dahl's widow, Felicity, it can be confirmed that a new version of the classic children's tale Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is to be made
fields.body:
News from the Roald Dahl official site roalddahl.org, which reports that following a meeting with Roald Dahl's widow, Felicity, it can be confirmed that a new version of the classic children's tale Willy Wonka and the Chocolate Factory is to be made.

"Scott Frank is currently working on the script but they're not looking to actually start production until autumn at the earliest. They don't have any of the roles cast yet, but they have decided on who they want to direct: Gary (Pleasantville) Ross", writes 'Kristina'.

As for casting, "The family/estate have final say on the scriptwriter, director, and lots of other details, but the studio gets to pick an 'A' list star to headline the picture. Dustin Hoffman was nixed because he's 'not popular enough'." Rumours that Nic Cage might play the candyman are still just that.

Apparently Dahl hated the 1971 film, starring Gene Wilder. The author had wanted British comedian Spike Milligan to play Willy Wonka, but was overruled.

fields.headline: 'Unputdownable'
fields.standfirst: Forget simply writing a great book - the best way to ensure your tome becomes a bestseller is to secure a juicy quote for the back.  Stuart Jeffries  on the art of the blurb
fields.trailText: Forget simply writing a great book - the best way to ensure your tome becomes a bestseller is to secure a juicy quote for the back. Stuart Jeffries on the art of the blurb
fields.body:
You may not have heard of The Writers, Actors, Artists, Musicians Association, but, by God, you wouldn't want to mess with them. They would send out books to well-known critics accompanied by whatever fee it would take to elicit a favourable quotation to put on the dust jacket. "We sent one man 10 bob with a new book and asked him to say that once one takes up the book one cannot leave it down," wrote Myles na gCopaleen, a Waama functionary.

And, for once, the book was literally unputdownable. "The cover of the volume was treated with a special brand of invisible glue that acts only when subjected to the heat of hands," wrote na gCopaleen. "Short of having his two arms amputated, putting the book down was an impossibility."

Myles na gCopaleen was the pen name Flann O'Brien used when he wrote columns for the Irish Times for 30-odd years until his death in 1966. And Waama? That was his invention, one of those great gags that kept him in drink and his readers in tears for decades.

As was the book-handling service Myles established in his Irish Times column. This service would, for a fee, take the unread books of wealthy but illiterate patrons and maul them in such a way that they would look as though they had been read. The highest grade of service would have forged inscriptions from important people. Thus: "Dear AB, Your invaluable suggestions and assistance, not to mention your kindness, in entirely re-writing chapter three, entitles you, surely, to this first copy of 'Tess'. From your old friend, T Hardy."

O'Brien was one of the greatest comic writers of all time. But don't take my word for it; try those of James Joyce, who said that O'Brien was "a real writer with the true comic spirit". Or Dylan Thomas's: "In the forefront of contemporary Irish writing". These are the quotations on the back of the Picador edition of O'Brien's novel The Third Policeman.

How did O'Brien's publishers come up with these quotes? Did they ply Joyce with expense account luncheons? After all, a quote from a fashionable literary name can add thousands to the sales. If you can get Nick Hornby to write, "I laughed, I cried, I became a Buddhist and had an irreversible vasectomy. Such is the power of this extraordinary book", then you can forget about review quotes or literary awards.

Links between endorser and endorsee are often prosaic: they tend to share agents, or drink from the same bottle of warm Soave at some West End book launch. The trendy debut novel White Teeth by Zadie Smith, for instance, includes a cover quotation from Salman Rushdie, who is represented by the same firm of literary agents. Lucky woman.

Or is she? Does it help a twentysomething literary hipster to be endorsed by some (admittedly Booker-winning, fatwa-enduring) old git, God bless him? Though the endorsement probably better serves Rushdie's interests: it implies that Smith's novel is growing from the bowels of the kind of literature that he devised in Britain a couple of decades ago. It sanctifies his achievement while seeming to celebrate hers.

There is a cost to this cosy celebrity endorsement nonetheless. Many readers are sceptical about the worth of an author's quote on the dust jacket. In literary London, after all, there are rarely three, let alone six degrees of separation between reviewer and reviewed, still fewer between author and endorser. Jamie Holland, for instance, was the PR guy on Jamie Oliver's book The Naked Chef. When Holland's novel One Thing Leads to Another came out recently, it contained this endorsement from Oliver: "An absolute cracker, a great book about mates, marriage and mating."

It must have been difficult for the publishers to decide whether this endorsement would reek of literary incestuousness, or whether, given the Naked Chef's success and (putative) hipness, it would be a good idea.

But when book editors and marketing departments are thrown back on their own verbal ingenuity, there are sometimes delightfully barmy consequences. Consider The Colour of Hope, the novel by Susan Madison to be published by Bantam Press in June. Apart from the 12-copy dumpbins, the streamers, the backdrop posters, the nationwide press campaign that will reach more than 9.5m people and giant cross-track advertising nationwide (hype which makes me want to go to Kazakhstan and live a life of silent contemplation), is the blurb on the front cover:

"All her life, she had feared death by water.

All her life, she had imagined the death would be her own. . ."

Then the killer, though frankly unsourced, cover line:

"Magnificent. Heart-rending. Unforgettable. Out now wherever books are sold."

I raise my hat to the people at Bantam Press for their devotion to plain speaking. Why bother relying on some flaky author to come up with a quote when you can push potential readers' buttons by alluding to books that they may have loved in the past? And so it is with the blurb for The Colour of Hope, which continues thus: "For all those who loved The Horse Whisperer and [The] Bridges of Madison County."

This multiple button pushing is understandable when the reading public is fractured into only occasionally overlapping interest groups. At the same time, it may well mark the insecurity of publishers: it is a kind of carpet bombing which is unlikely, by definition, to miss its target. Consider this blurb, which appeared in a recent issue of The Bookseller:

"Introducing one of Holland's most highly regarded writers, in the tradition of Ian McEwan and Helen Dunmore. A Heart of Stone by Renate Dorrestein."

No matter at all that there is no such tradition - that, rather, the yanking together of these two famous novelists' names will serve only to suggest, perhaps, that Dorrestein's novel is perhaps as kinky as McEwan and Dunmore can sometimes be. If you can read, there will be no way you can miss Madison's book, as the PR campaign schedule explains: "Rights sold in 12 countries to date, including US. Major auctions worldwide - record sums paid. Perfectly timed for summer reading promotions in the media. Backed by a massive campaign that no one can miss." My coach for Kazakhstan, by the way, will be leaving at the end of May.

This marketing strategy implicitly says to the consumer: "You liked A and B? Then you're just the kind of person who'll love C because it's like A would be if it was a bit more like B."

Amazon.com, quite understandably, strives to sell its books this way. But, again, there is a danger: readers can insulate themselves from being exposed to books they would not normally read. It's similar to what's happening on TV: the dominant philosophy is that an interest group must be given more and more of what it wants. Such, lamentably, is choice.

The book marketing game's carpet-bombing techniques can make even those in the industry weary. Publishing News recently interviewed Amy Jenkins, who will be hard to avoid in May when her novel Honeymoon is published. Amy Jenkins? You remember her. She wrote the first series of This Life for the BBC. She got a £600,000 advance for her Honeymoon on the basis of one chapter.

"There will," sighs a weary Publishing News, "be a BBC documentary and plenty of newspaper and magazine mentions, with copious anecdotes on This Life. There will be much talk of growing up with political columnist Peter Jenkins as father and journalist Polly Toynbee as step-mother. Oh and let's not forget the druggy 'lost years' running a stall in Portobello market. Who knows, there may even be time to focus on the book itself."

The book? Nobody will have time for that. Which is why it is imperative that critics' hands are pasted with invisible glue in order to ensure that the reviews of Honeymoon dovetail with the pre-publication hype.

Stuart Jeffries' book Mrs Slocombe's Pussy: Growing Up in Front of the Telly is published by Flamingo at £12.99.

Stuart Jeffries' book Mrs Slocombe's Pussy: Growing Up in Front of the Telly is published by Flamingo at £12.99.

fields.headline: Spacey commits to Shipping News
fields.trailText: Fresh from his Oscar triumph, Kevin Spacey has signed to play the lead in The Shipping News, an adaptation of E. Annie Proulx's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel
fields.body:
Fresh from his Oscar triumph, Kevin Spacey has signed to play the lead in The Shipping News, an adaptation of Annie Proulx's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel of a father and his two daughters building a life in Newfoundland. The film will be directed by another man on a winning streak - Oscar-nominated director Lasse Hallstrom, whose Cider House Rules came away with two awards on Oscar night.

Ron Bass (who won an Oscar for his Rain Man screenplay) and Tom Epperson are screenwriting, and production is slated to begin early next year.

The production has already had more than its fair share of headlines and leading actors come and go. John Travolta was set to star with his wife Kelly Preston but dropped out in June; Billy Bob Thornton was also in talks to star and direct earlier this year.

Variety reports that Columbia had been courting Spacey for the role all month; this is the first project he has committed to since winning the Oscar.

fields.headline: No: 1606 Jeanette Winterson
fields.trailText: No: 1606 Jeanette Winterson
fields.body:
Age: 40

Job description: Misunderstood genius; greatest living author in the English language, etc, etc.

Says who? Erm, Jeanette Winterson. A typical self-analysis from the author of Oranges Are Not The Only Fruit: "No one working in the English language now comes close to my exuberance, my passion, my fidelity to words."

Another piercingly objective insight, please: "I am the only true heir to Virginia Woolf," says Jeanette, who once provided sexual services to married Kensington ladies in return for pieces of crockery.

Sorry I asked. As are the many critics who've felt the blistering heat of Winterson's rage for daring to point out that Oranges has been followed by a fair few lemons.

A sensitive soul, is she? When journalist Nicci Gerrard penned a less than adulatory profile in 1994, Winterson and partner Peggy Reynolds stormed to her home while she was hosting a dinner party and vented their spleens.

And who's offended her now? The true heir of Virginia Woolf has launched a legal action against Mark Hogarth, a Cambridge don who has bought the internet address
www.jeanettewinterson.com.

Because he wanted to preserve her towering literary reputation online? "To make money, basically," Hogarth reportedly told her. He's bought more than 130 others - including ianmcewan.com, iainbanks.com, and joannatrollope.com - and plans to release some of them in return for 3% of gross book earnings.

Has she doorstepped him yet? Not quite. "I can't wait for the polite round of exchanges to harden. I just want to chase him around the common," she says. For the time being she's filed a complaint with Icann, which regulates net names.

Not to be confused with: Nicholas Winterton; God; Virginia Woolf (of whom, as I may have mentioned, she is the only true heir).

Don't say: "Ah, Jeanette. You must be calling about Pass Notes. Why don't you come in and have a cup of tea?"

fields.headline: Hitchhiker's Guide finally gets moving
fields.trailText: A feature film version of Douglas Adams' Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy has been in development hell for almost 20 years. Coming Attractions reports today that things are moving at last
fields.body:
A feature film version of Douglas Adams' Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy has been in development hell for almost 20 years. Austin Powers director Jay Roach has been attached to the project for more than a year now, but there's been little official news beyond that.

Film insider gossip website Coming Attractions reports today that things are moving at last. An anonymous source close to the production has sent in two pictures, one of the prototype design for Marvin the Paranoid Android and another of the prototype version of the Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy.

"The script is pretty much done, but Douglas keeps making changes," the apparently trustworthy source adds. "I can say that the scene from the radio show where Zaphod goes to the Guide's offices will be in there and will resemble that bit out of Men in Black in the alien airport thing. (Although it won't suck!)"

fields.headline: Harry Potter will remain British
fields.trailText: Harry Potter director Chris Columbus has reassured fans of the books that the film will remain British in flavour
fields.body:
Talking to USA Today, Harry Potter director Chris Columbus has reassured fans of the books that the film will remain British in flavour. "It's essential to find a British boy to play Harry. We really have to be incredibly faithful and true to the book. Rowling wrote Harry as a British boy, and it's important we honour the original vision."

Harry Potter's creator, J.K. Rowling, will also act as one of the film's executive producers. On that point, Columbus says, "As much time as she's willing to devote to the project, I would embrace. As the creator of the books, she can really be instrumental in all aspects of the production of this film."

Columbus also revealed that much of the magic in the film as well as various and sundry fantastic entities will be realised via a combination of animatronics with computer-generated images. One scene in particular that involves a Quidditch match - a combination of soccer and basketball played on flying broomsticks - will be "one of the visual highlights of the movie. We will take you places in that match that you've never been before in a theatre."

To pull all this off, the film's budget will be in the $100m range.

webTitle: Byers hits back at BMW notes

fields.headline: Byers hits back at BMW notes
fields.standfirst: German group's four-part Rover plan 'did not involve sale'
fields.trailText: Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers yesterday sought to beat off a concerted attack over his handling of BMW's withdrawal by revealing that six days before the disastrous Rover announcement, BMW executives had discussed with him a package to keep BMW viable in Britain.
fields.body:
Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers yesterday sought to beat off a concerted attack over his handling of BMW's withdrawal by revealing that six days before the disastrous Rover announcement, BMW executives had discussed with him a package to keep BMW viable in Britain.

Mr Byers has been accused of naivity or incompetence in failing to forsee BMW's moves.

In a further attempt to bolster his reputation, Mr Byers also extracted a statement from BMW chairman Joachim Milberg insisting he had never said failure to win a £152m grant aid package would force the company to reconsider its whole investment in Britain.

He had instead told Mr Byers that BMW would have to reconsider its plans to develop the new Rover 30 model at the Longbridge plant in the west midlands. Mr Byers was given the warning by Mr Milberg in a phone call on December 22.

However, former Tory cabinet minister John Redwood claimed BMW's entire UK operations were dependent on the success of the Rover 30.

He claimed that aid was held up because Mr Byers had submitted an invalid regional selective assistance map to Brussels. He said it was to be redrawn the following week, and covered the constituencies of 11 cabinet members.

Mr Byers and the prime minister came under fire also from union leaders who, at a meeting in Downing Street, told Tony Blair to "get a grip" on the level of the pound. John Edmonds, the GMB leader, described it as the number one issue in Britain.

Mr Byers' defence regarding Rover rested on a meeting he had with BMW's British head, Werner Saemann, on Friday March 10 to discuss the company's mounting losses.

The minister asked him directly what BMW intended to do to reduce losses. According to the minutes of the meeting Mr Saemann outlined four possible courses of action: increase productivity dramatically; source more components from overseas suppliers; concentrate on its core business; and cut production on the Rover 25 and 75.

Mr Byers is expected to release the full civil service record of his meetings with and calls to BMW executives.

None of the options involved a sale, said the DTI, even though it has emerged since that the sale proposal was being prepared at a BMW supervisory board meeting the following week.

A DTI source said: "He went through these four proposals, but you might have expected him to outline a fifth - but he did not."

The record suggests the issue of a grant was discussed, and says BMW was concerned by "slippage" in the timetable.

fields.headline: Business divided on euro
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Business support for the euro is slipping, according to a new opinion poll, underlining the struggle the government faces if it opts to join the single currency.
fields.body:
Business support for the euro is slipping, according to a new opinion poll, underlining the struggle the government faces if it opts to join the single currency.

Unlike previous polls, which tend to show a majority in favour of ditching the pound, the latest from the British Chambers of Commerce shows that the business community is now evenly divided.

While 38% favour a commitment to join the euro, 36% want the government to rule out membership for the forseeable future. The fence-sitters have shrunk to 24%.

The BCC has abandoned its policy in favour in principle of joining the euro when the economic conditions are right and is now neutral about membership.

Chris Humphries, director general of the BCC, said: "Compared with other recent business surveys on the single currency, this shows an increasing polarisation of business opinion between pro and anti-euro camps.

"If government wishes to retain the option of joining the single currency after the next election, it must give serious consideration to how it will promote the benefits to the business community which clearly remains unconvinced."

Britain in Europe, the pro-euro lobby group, welcomed the poll, saying that it showed that half of the firms surveyed have started to prepare for possible adoption of the euro.

But Nick Herbert, chief executive of Business for Sterling, the anti-EMU lobby group, said: "This survey is a body blow to the government's pro-euro campaign, another reason why it should cancel its £36bn changeover plan."
