webTitle: We still have a role to play

fields.headline: We still have a role to play
fields.trailText: The pre-school movement was not built by women who believed their place was in the home (Playgroup perils, March 29). The playgroup movement was created by concerned parents who didn't need politicians or experts to tell them that their children would benefit from nursery education.
fields.body:
The pre-school movement was not built by women who believed their place was in the home (Playgroup perils, March 29). The playgroup movement was created by concerned parents who didn't need politicians or experts to tell them that their children would benefit from nursery education. In the absence of state provision, they created their own. Forty years later, there are still hundreds of thousands of parents who feel the same way. About half of them are out at work, but they still welcome the chance to be stakeholders in their children's early development.

A study to be published shortly by the National Institute of Adult and Continuing Education reports on the experiences of more than 140 parents involved in community-based pre-schools in areas of social and economic disadvantage and shows that pre-schools are far more than just nurseries or playgroups. Dr Veronica McGivney says: "They deliver a far more holistic service than just childcare ... are a vital family and community resource ... providing social contact, practical and emotional support, education training and employment opportunities and information, help and advice on parenting, education, health, social security and housing matters."

So why are pre-schools closing? Education Minister Margaret Hodge was sufficiently concerned a year ago to set up a panel of experts to investigate. The panel made 55 recommendations, but the key ones on funding are gathering dust. Could it be that the neat and tidy solution of having all children in school from age three is, secretly, more appealing to education ministers?

The loss of children - and, yes, many parents do feel pressured to take a school place for their four-year-olds (Legal challenge to school start, March 30) - has combined with the impact of the national minimum wage and working-time directive to create a financial shortfall which is killing off nurseries and pre-schools which have been in existence for more than 25 years. It may come as a surprise, but staff in pre-schools do have to be paid. The conception of an entirely volunteer workforce ceased to be a reality, like so many other assumptions in Angela Phillips's piece of invective, 20 years ago.
Margaret Lochrie
Chief executive, Pre-School Learning Alliance

 Angela Phillips's argument might be all very well if the four-year-olds she is referring to were attending nursery schools or classes. But they are not. They are taking up places in school reception classes which do not necessarily meet their needs. Encouraging under-fives into reception classes in large numbers is just another way of providing pre-school education on the cheap.
Christine Guedalla
London

 Playgroups can never compete with the resources of the maintained sector, but they can offer something more valuable. Learning to use limited resources to have fun, improvising joyfully from scrap, can result in far more useful lessons in life and imagination than access to all the latest equipment.

Playgroups are less recognised for the contribution they have made to restoring confidence and building employable skills in women who have left the workforce to have children. Thousands of women (not a few of them MPs) found that joining the local playgroup, receiving training (possibly for the first time since leaving school) and perhaps taking part in the management committee enabled them to go on other education jobs, voluntary sector work or even into politics. Playgroups have often transformed women's lives at a time when they had thought they were at the bottom of the heap.
Frances Ipson
Bradford

fields.headline: Private is not better
fields.trailText: What on earth could have led Lord Currie (Livingstone's tube plan naive, March 29) to conclude private-sector involvement in the London Underground will save taxpayers £2.3bn? The "empirical evidence" in his study does not square with the record of the private sector in the real world.
fields.body:
What on earth could have led Lord Currie (Livingstone's tube plan naive, March 29) to conclude private-sector involvement in the London Underground will save taxpayers £2.3bn? The "empirical evidence" in his study does not square with the record of the private sector in the real world. Consultants Booze Allan demonstrated that Railtrack (whose contractors are bidding to take over the tube) have let the quality of the mainline railway fall below that inherited from the publicly managed BR. Whilst on the Underground itself, privately built trains for the Northern Line were delivered four years late and over budget.

An independent study by University College and Manchester University has recently concluded there was "no evidence" to support the government's assumption of private efficiencies. And prior to the PPP being adopted, London Transport, supported by consultants Lazards and KPMG, ranked the PPP option 14th out of 15 in terms of value for money. Their most favoured option, a public bond issue, was calculated to be £2bn less expensive than the PPP. If the great railway rip-off is not to be repeated, passengers deserve an independent public inquiry to ensure the best funding options are adopted.
Jimmy Knapp
General secretary, RMT

fields.trailText: The number of those who have died in the slaughter of members of Uganda's Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God is expected to exceed the 914 victims of Jonestown, Guyana, the worst cult-related violence in recent times. Many aspects of the story are horrifying - the large number of children who perished - and puzzling - how could hundreds of people have been murdered in a few weeks with so few questions raised? But even before that is clear, there are wider implications.
fields.body:
The number of those who have died in the slaughter of members of Uganda's Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God is expected to exceed the 914 victims of Jonestown, Guyana, the worst cult-related violence in recent times. Many aspects of the story are horrifying - the large number of children who perished - and puzzling - how could hundreds of people have been murdered in a few weeks with so few questions raised? But even before that is clear, there are wider implications. There have been no fewer than eight other cases of cult-related violence in the last decade around the world. Historians of religion believe the increasing incidence is partly caused by the millennium, and partly by unprecedented social, political and economic dislocation. The latter is the obvious context here. The experience of civil war under Idi Amin, the civil war and genocide in neighbouring Rwanda, as well as the scourge of Aids - all these provide fertile ground for recruitment among those who seek the consolation and security offered by a charismatic preacher. Only last autumn, the Ugandan government disbanded two apocalyptic movements.

There is little we can do to prevent such a tragedy being repeated somewhere in the world. This is because it is hard to assess which religious movement will end in catastrophe (a tiny minority) and which is harmless (the vast majority). A draconian crackdown on all such movements is demonstrably impossible and unjust. We need to resist the temptation, evident in many Western liberal democracies, to restrict or persecute innovative religious communities; it is contrary to the right to religious freedom. The only real defence is objective, accessible information. Firstly, it can help break down the cycle of prejudice and persecution which prompts a community to turn in on itself and become violent. Secondly, it is the best guarantor of religious tolerance, helping to calm the panic and hysteria which events such as Aum Shinrikyo and Waco always generate. That makes it all the more shocking that one of the few organisations in the world which provides such information -Inform, at the London School of Economics - exists on a Home Office grant so meagre that it has been unable to develop the website which could be helping thousands in Uganda and all over the world to understand what happened in Kanungu's blaze.

fields.headline: Taunts from the terraces
fields.standfirst:
Football remains plagued by racist abuse
War on racism renewed after Heskey ordeal
The match that reignited the row
fields.trailText: Things get said in the heat of a closely fought match. Players swear, call each other names. Within bounds that goes with the turf. Good referees will not be tempted to intervene just because they hear disparaging references to David Beckham's tonsure or the (latest) colour of Jamie Lawrence's hair. But no referee who cares for the health of football, let alone feels any obligation to society at large, can be deaf to racial abuse, whether delivered by players or "fans". Nor can the authorities and owners behind the sport.
fields.body:
Things get said in the heat of a closely fought match. Players swear, call each other names. Within bounds that goes with the turf. Good referees will not be tempted to intervene just because they hear disparaging references to David Beckham's tonsure or the (latest) colour of Jamie Lawrence's hair. But no referee who cares for the health of football, let alone feels any obligation to society at large, can be deaf to racial abuse, whether delivered by players or "fans". Nor can the authorities and owners behind the sport.

It took time - official moves against racism only came some two decades after black players started making their mark - but lately the Football Association in England, with its cognates in Scotland and Wales, have made progress. Liverpool's Emile Heskey testified to that when he said of his treatment in Barcelona on Wednesday that it did not happen in the Premiership. The racial insults to which Heskey was subjected in Spain tell of the strength of racist currents in international football and how much work the authorities, especially UEFA, still have to do.

Maybe this game, between England's and Yugoslavia's Under-21s, was a one-off. A gaggle of foul-mouthed fans in the stands does not condemn an entire side. But the complacent reaction to the treatment of Heskey by UEFA seemed all too typical of the inertia which grips Swiss-based international sporting bodies when they are ethically tested. UEFA should immediately call the Yugoslavs to account for both players and fans. The stadium's owners need quizzing, too, over the quality of their stewarding. If the English game is better, it is thanks to efforts by fans' groups and the Professional Footballers' Association, later joined by managers, owners and the FA. One of the pledges made by the Kick It Out campaign group was to carry their work into Europe. Wednesday indicates how much there is yet to be done.

webTitle: Life jail for hospital siege man

fields.headline: Life jail for hospital siege man
fields.trailText: A 38-year-old man was yesterday given a life sentence after taking a doctor hostage at gunpoint during a two-day hospital siege.
fields.body:
A 38-year-old man was yesterday given a life sentence after taking a doctor hostage at gunpoint during a two-day hospital siege.

David Collins imprisoned Kingsley Paul, 28, using an imitation pistol after developing a grudge against a consultant at the Withybush hospital in Haverfordwest, west Wales.

Swansea crown court heard how the defendant had an "unreasoning obsession" with consultant Peter Milewski, believing he had misdiagnosed a stomach complaint eight years earlier.

Collins pleaded guilty to false imprisonment of Dr Paul, having an imitation firearm with intent, and threatening to destroy property at the hospital. Judge Michael Burr told Collins he had carried out a "selfish and wicked" act of revenge.

Elwen Evans, prosecuting, said Collins, of Milford Haven, went to the hospital in October last year with a .22 calibre starting pistol.

She said the defendant had nothing against Dr Paul, a senior house officer, and had taken him prisoner only because he had been "in the wrong place at the wrong time".

After taking the doctor hostage Collins tied him to a chair and placed balloons around the room which he said were filled with petrol. The court heard he put candles underneath the balloons and said there could be an explosion if anyone came into the room.

Dr Paul was eventually released with minor injuries 28 hours after being imprisoned.

At one point during the siege 115 police officers were involved, some armed.

Miss Evans said the motivation behind the incident was a grudge Collins held against Mr Milewski since the consultant dealt with him for a gastric problem in 1991.

Tom Crowther, defending, told the court Collins had a personality change and developed monomania, an obsession with one thing, since being treated by Mr Milewski.

fields.headline: A house built on sand
fields.standfirst:
The interim Lords is little improvement

Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: The list of new life peers makes dismal reading. Most names are lacklustre: Sebastian Coe was a distinguished athlete, but not much cop as a legislator. The Conservative party treasurer Michael Ashcroft must be the first peer-to-be whose elevation comes on condition that he deigns to live in the country whose laws he seeks to write. There are some pleasing inclusions. The Labour historian and biographer Kenneth Morgan is one; Matthew Evans, who has kept Faber and Faber an independent-minded publisher, is another. So too is that eloquent advocate of multiculturalism, Bhikhu Parekh. But mostly they are a pretty bland bunch.
fields.body:
The list of new life peers makes dismal reading. Most names are lacklustre: Sebastian Coe was a distinguished athlete, but not much cop as a legislator - yet he wins a seat in our parliament on the whim of his party leader, whom he serves as judo partner and bag-carrier-in-chief. The Conservative party treasurer Michael Ashcroft must be the first peer-to-be whose elevation comes on condition that he deigns to live in the country whose laws he seeks to write. He has survived controversy, so the ermine will be his. Who else? Labour has reversed its previous distaste for the hereditary peerage by recalling seven of the bluebloods, five of whom will take the Labour whip. Thanks to this manoeuvre, it has now recovered one quarter of the hereditary caucus in the Lords it lost last November: quite a feat. There are some pleasing inclusions. The Labour historian and biographer Kenneth Morgan is one; Matthew Evans, who has kept Faber and Faber an independent-minded publisher, is another. So too is that eloquent advocate of multiculturalism, Bhikhu Parekh. But mostly they are a pretty bland bunch.

But what makes this morning's list truly depressing is the headed notepaper on which it arrives: 10 Downing Street. For even though this is the 21st century, and even though we are in the third year of a reforming, Labour government, this woeful practice of prime ministerial appointment to the second chamber continues. Make no mistake, the source of this list - whatever camouflage may be used to disguise the fact - is the office of Tony Blair. We remain governed by a system which allows the executive to handpick one half of our legislature. It is worse than an anomaly; it is an affront to democracy.

The indictment amounts to more than the kneejerk criticism that the Lords is being stuffed with Tony's cronies. As it happens, and as Michael White made clear in yesterday's paper, the upper house has been a far from supine creature since the hereditaries were sent packing. It has rebelled repeatedly, inflicting 10 defeats on the government - with the revolts occasionally led by the very Labourites branded "cronies". The Lords were right to rebel when they defended the right to trial by jury, right again to insist that candidates in London's mayoral election should get a free mailshot to voters. They were wrong, in our view, to defend Section 28. But the problem is not the merits of the rebellions, but the right of the Lords to stage them. In each case, the government has been able to dismiss these challenges from the Lords as illegitimate. Since they are unelected, says Labour, they have no right to hold up the elected Commons.

That suits Labour just fine. Whenever the Lords create trouble, they can be rubbished - even though they sit in an interim second chamber of the government's own making. This is what makes full-blooded reform of the Lords so urgent. As things stand, peers cannot do the job which our system cries out for, acting as a check and balance on the executive. That is not because the wrong people are chosen - as we have seen, one-time cronies can fast become troublemakers. It is because their basis of selection remains so undemocratic. As long as this interim, limbo period remains the Lords will always be dubbed a house of placemen, their challenges to the government waved aside as illegitimate. Yet we need that challenge. To get it, we need to finish the job of reforming our second chamber. That requires not the minimum of elective democracy apparently favoured by Downing Street - but the maximum.

fields.headline: Coroner denounces body mix-up
fields.trailText: A coroner yesterday called for international agreement on postmortem identification procedures, after a cruel muddle over bodies of some of the people killed in the terrorist massacre in Luxor, Egypt, in 1997.
fields.body:
A coroner yesterday called for international agreement on postmortem identification procedures, after a cruel muddle over bodies of some of the people killed in the terrorist massacre in Luxor, Egypt, in 1997.

Roger Whittaker, who recorded three verdicts of unlawful killing at Halifax coroner's court, West Yorkshire, said the confusion that saw families in Britain, Switzerland and Germany receive the wrong bodies in November 1997 was "a matter of much regret and should not be allowed to happen again".

Mr Whittaker said three generations of a family had been machine-gunned to death at the temples of Luxor on what they had described as their "holiday of a lifetime" travelling down the Nile.

Shaunnah Turner, five, who had been allowed time off from her school at Ripponden, near Halifax, died with her mother Karina, 24, and grandmother Joan, 53, as six Muslim fundamentalists fired on a coach party on November 17 1997.

They were among 51 tourists, mostly Swiss, and seven local people killed. All the terrorists died in the siege and gun battle that followed.

The bodies of Joan Turner, a social services coordinator for elderly people, and her daughter, an air stewardess, were misidentified and sent to bereaved families in Switzerland and Germany, whose own relatives' bodies were sent to Yorkshire. Mr Whittaker played a leading role in overcoming red tape in the four countries involved.

The inquest heard that Ms Turner appeared to have died trying to shield her daughter, but a bullet fired only a few yards away from an AK47 shattered the girl's cheek and chest.

Pathologist Michael Green said: "The AK47 is favoured by terrorists and fires bullets at up to 3,500ft per second. It can put a hole through a brick wall at 1,000ft, and is one of the few weapons capable of causing the terrible damage sustained by these three people."

Mr Whittaker said the inquest had almost no new material to consider, because police in Egypt would not release statements from 75 witnesses and the Foreign Office could gather only scant information.

fields.headline: Drummers aim to beat record
fields.trailText: Thousands of drummers will pound out a simultaneous beat across Britain to create the biggest noise the nation has heard, it was announced yesterday. Starting in Londonderry, the drum pattern will spread as different groups join in for a half-hour performance during the BBC Music Live festival in May. The drumming event, Beat This, begins at noon on May 29 and is part of a 24-hour live TV broadcast which will see music dominate schedules on BBC1 and BBC2.
fields.body:
Thousands of drummers will pound out a simultaneous beat across Britain to create the biggest noise the nation has heard, it was announced yesterday. Starting in Londonderry, the drum pattern will spread as different groups join in for a half-hour performance during the BBC Music Live festival in May. The drumming event, Beat This, begins at noon on May 29 and is part of a 24-hour live TV broadcast which will see music dominate schedules on BBC1 and BBC2.

"It will involve every type of percussion you can think of. If they can hit it, they will," said Amanda Lennon, who is co-ordinating the project for the BBC. Between 20 and 30 groups, some featuring up to 500 players, will be featured in the Beat This broadcast, each playing the same basic rhythm. At least 5,000 are already involved.

Ms Lennon added: "It will spread like a mexican wave and keep on going. Each group will bring their own particular slant. We will have dhol and tabla players performing in Sandwell, samba in Manchester, and West African drumming in Bradford.

"We will be going for the world percussion record for the largest number of people playing together. The theory is that wherever you are you will be able to hear the rhythm or take part."

Ms Lennon and her team have been working since September on the drumming project, approaching percussionists and fine-tuning.

Figures who have worked to come up with the drum pattern to be played on the day include Paul Weller's drummer Steve White, classical musician Evelyn Glennie, and Johnny Kalsi of percussion group the Dhol Foundation.

Jools Holland, who helped launch the project in London yesterday, said: "It will probably be the biggest noise the UK has ever known."

webTitle: UK Cypriots asked to save a life

fields.headline: UK Cypriots asked to save a life
fields.trailText: A boy in hospital with leukaemia is hoping Britain's Greek and Turkish Cypriots can come together to give him a chance of life.
fields.body:
A boy in hospital with leukaemia is hoping Britain's Greek and Turkish Cypriots can come together to give him a chance of life.

Kemal Saracoglu, 12, is in desperate need of a bone marrow transplant. He went with his father, Suhar, to the Royal Free hospital in north London because such an operation cannot be done in Cyprus. They hope to find a match, determined by a blood test, among the 500,000 Cypriots in Britain.

The family's hopes have been raised by emotional scenes in the divided island, where hundreds of members of both communities, including the son of Rauf Denktash, president of the Turkish area in the north, have queued in recent days to be tested in the hope of saving a Greek Cypriot boy, Andreas Vassiliou, six, who also has leukaemia.

Thanks to the publicity Kemal's cause has been taken up, and Cypriots on the island are cooperating to try to find a match for him too.

"There is a chance for Andreas on the Greek side and for Kemal on the Turkish side," said Mr Saracoglu at his son's bedside yesterday. "This will be good for our sons, and good for the future."

Cypriots in the UK can contact the Anthony Nolan Bone Marrow Trust, which keeps the register of potential donors, on 0901 8822234.

fields.headline: Nelson's arch
fields.standfirst: New entrance for Chinatown in Liverpool
fields.trailText: After a century and a half of waiting Europe's oldest Chinese quarter yesterday got the traditional archway entrance it deserved.
fields.body:
After a century and a half of waiting Europe's oldest Chinese quarter yesterday got the traditional archway entrance it deserved.

A spectacular arch, which incorporates more than 200 dragons carved into its fretwork and is flanked by two marble lions, now marks the entrance to Liverpool's Chinatown, guarding the city against misfortune and evil.

Built by 16 artists and craftsmen in Shanghai at a cost of £700,000, the arch - at 13.5 metres (nearly 45ft) thought to be the largest outside China - was shipped to Liverpool in six containers and assembled at the top of Nelson Street in accordance with the tenets of feng shui.

"Nelson Street is seen as a river flowing downhill," said Peter Kwok, feng shui consultant on the six-year project. "This needs to be dammed to prevent good luck and fortune flowing away from local businesses."

Dragon dancers performed to bursts of firecrackers as Liverpool's lord mayor, Joe Devaney, joined Chinese community leaders in welcoming the arch.

"The Chinese community now have something that will really draw people into this area," he said. "It is essential that the oldest Chinatown in Europe blossoms once again."

fields.headline: Baby death mother cleared
fields.trailText: A mother cleared of killing her 10-week-old son said yesterday she was delighted that her "nightmare" was over after the judge threw out her case.
fields.body:
A mother cleared of killing her 10-week-old son said yesterday she was delighted that her "nightmare" was over after the judge threw out her case.

Gaynor Thomas, 37, was charged with manslaughter after her son Dominick died from suffocation in March last year.

The prosecution at Chester crown court claimed Miss Thomas deliberately smothered him at her home in Ellesmere Port, Cheshire.

webTitle: Hague's role in parrot case no joke

fields.headline: Hague's role in parrot case no joke
fields.trailText: When Tory leader William Hague, who once appeared as a dead parrot on the front page of a tabloid newspaper, was in court yesterday to give evidence against a constituent accused of smuggling the birds into Britain, the defence barrister could not resist making a rather obvious joke.
fields.body:
When Tory leader William Hague, who once appeared as a dead parrot on the front page of a tabloid newspaper, was in court yesterday to give evidence against a constituent accused of smuggling the birds into Britain, the defence barrister could not resist making a rather obvious joke.

Simon Farrel asked Mr Hague if he was a parrot expert. Was he familiar with Norwegian blues - a reference to the Sun front page which screamed Tories Dead Official, depicting him as the dead parrot of the Monty Python sketch.

"I thought we agreed there weren't going to be any wisecracks," warned Judge Guy Whitburn at Newcastle crown court.

Mr Hague was appearing as a prosecution witness in the case against his constituent Harry Sissen, 61, of Northallerton, north Yorkshire, who is accused of four counts of smuggling parrots and two charges of illegally selling a palm cockatoo and a hyacinthine macaw.

Sissen is alleged to have confessed to Mr Hague during a meeting at the constituency surgery in October 1998 that he had smuggled parrots.

Mr Hague told the court: "He came to see me to ask me to take up his complaint about the activities of customs and excise which had taken birds away from his premises.

"He was emphatic that he had not in general smuggled birds and eggs into the country and that he was not in general guilty of wrongdoing," he said. "But he did say he smuggled three birds from Yugoslavia.

"He said the violence [in that region] was one of the reasons why he had done this as an exceptional act."

The prosecution claims that Sissen smuggled three Lear's macaws and six blue-headed macaws into Britain from dealers in Yugoslavia and the Czech Republic between 1997 and 1998.

Sissen denies all the charges.

The case continues.

webTitle: All change for car registration plates

fields.headline: All change for car registration plates
fields.trailText: It was, said Lord Whitty, an historic day in the history of vehicle registration in Britain. For the first time in more than 40 years, number plates are to have a new format that will make them easier to remember and help the fight against crime.
fields.body:
It was, said Lord Whitty, an historic day in the history of vehicle registration in Britain. For the first time in more than 40 years, number plates are to have a new format that will make them easier to remember and help the fight against crime.

The single-letter prefix to indicate a vehicle's age will run out in September 2001, and yesterday the transport minister unveiled the revised format.

Plates will begin with a two-letter regional identifier (for example, PK indicates a car registered in Preston), followed by a two-digit age identifier, eg 01 for 2001, and then a random-selection three-letter code.

A standard typeface, based on the Charles Wright font, is specified, and use of alternatives will become illegal in March 2001 - the days of the italic plate are numbered.

Motorists will also be allowed to incorporate the European Union flag and the legend GB on the plate's left hand edge, but national flags cannot be displayed.

Lord Whitty rejected a suggestion this represented "creeping federalism", and pointed out that motorists would be able to "celebrate their regional identity".

Cars registered in Scotland will begin with an S, while in a nod to multilingual Britain those registered in Wales will begin with a C.

Plates beginning with a G will hail from DVLC offices in the "Garden of England" (Brighton, oddly, and Maidstone); those from Nottingham and Lincoln will begin with an F to indicate "Forest and Fens", while L will stand for London. Regional expatriates will be able to have their suffix of choice by registering their vehicle with the appropriate office.

Vehicles registered prior to the new system will retain their plates.

The format has the support of the police, who hope it will make vehicle identification more straightforward for officers and public alike.

"It's really good news for fighting crime. Most criminals travel in cars or vans to and from their crimes, and anything that helps a witness identify that vehicle is invalu able," said acting commander Graham Marshall of the City of London police. "There are times when the ability of a witness to identify a vehicle is vital in bringing offenders to justice."

Mr Marshall added that the new plates would also be more easily identified by speed cameras, and would help the public by clarifying the law regarding plates.

The number plate industry is worth between £25m and £30m annually, and the changes in legislation are expected to cost manufacturers £1m to accommodate.

Personal touch name and number

The new number plates system offers some room for personalisation.

The Automobile Association may want to get its vehicles registered at the Anglia region's Peterborough office where the plates would begin AA. Manchester United and Manchester City supporters should register in Manchester and hope for MU or MC.

WC's are available from Bristol (West Country), VD from Worcester (Severn Valley), and BO from Birmingham. FU is not available anywhere - it was left off the list, which appears in full below:

Anglia AA to AY
Birmingham BA-BY
Cymru CA-CY
Deeside DA-DY
Essex EA-EY
Forest and Fens (Notts and Lincs) FA-FY
Garden of England (Maidstone and Brighton) GA-GY
Hampshire, Dorset HA-HY
Luton, Northampton KA-KY
London LA-LY
Manchester MA-MY
North NA-NY
Oxford OA-OY
Preston PA-PY
Reading RA-RY
Scotland SA-SY
Severn Valley VA-VY
West Country WA-WY
Yorkshire YA-YY

fields.headline: Tales from the crypt
fields.standfirst:
Lambeth Palace opens to the public

Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: It has taken 800 years but the Church of England is tomorrow following the trail blazed by Buckingham Palace and stately homes across the country in opening the doors of Lambeth Palace, the London residence of the Archbishop of Canterbury, to the public for the first time.
fields.body:
It has taken 800 years but the Church of England is tomorrow following the trail blazed by Buckingham Palace and stately homes across the country in opening the doors of Lambeth Palace, the London residence of the Archbishop of Canterbury, to the public for the first time.

The church is hoping that up to 80,000 paying customers this summer will enter the 15th century gates of the palace, just across the Thames from the Houses of Parliament, and it has already taken 45,000 advance bookings.

The palace, occupied with varying degrees of discomfort by every archbishop since the reign of King John, will be open to pre-booked customers from Tuesdays to Saturdays until November 4.

If the openings prove a success, they may be repeated in future years.

George Carey, the present archbishop, still occupies a second floor flat at the palace, and though that is not on the tourist route, visitors may be able to catch fleeting glimpses of him as he heads for his office. He told journalists yesterday that he and his wife Eileen feel very much part of the history of the place.

After paying £6 for adults and £4 for children and pensioners, visitors will be able to visit the palace's medieval though newly renovated crypt - reopened yesterday by the Prince of Wales - parts of which date back to the original palace on the site.

That was erected by Archbishop Hubert Walter in 1199 and burnt down by angry monks from Canterbury, fearful that they would be displaced, the next year.

The tour also takes in the Great Hall, guard room and archbishop's chapel.

Among the palace's treasures are the grubby embroidered leather gloves Charles I handed to his friend, the future Archbishop Juxon, on the scaffold in Whitehall in 1649; bibles owned by Archbishop Cranmer at the time of the reformation; and even the shell of a tortoise which was given the run of the place by Archbishop Laud in the 1630s, and which managed to survive until 1750 before being accidentally spiked by a gardener.

fields.headline: Surgeons infected patients with virus
fields.trailText: Around 4,500 former hospital patients are being offered blood tests to find out whether they have hepatitis C, a virus that attacks the liver with potentially fatal results, after two surgeons were found to have unwittingly infected six people.
fields.body:
Around 4,500 former hospital patients are being offered blood tests to find out whether they have hepatitis C, a virus that attacks the liver with potentially fatal results, after two surgeons were found to have unwittingly infected six people.

Last October it was revealed that a surgeon working in gynaecology and obstetrics had infected one of his patients at the Pilgrim hospital, in Boston, Lincolnshire.

A blood sample he had given in 1993 was then checked and proved to contain the virus. Some 1,400 women on whom he had operated since then at hospitals in Boston, Torbay, Exeter and Southampton were contacted. Three were found to have hepatitis C.

The action announced yesterday by the Department of Health is partly an extension of that inquiry back to 1978, the year in which the surgeon started work in the NHS. A further 2,500 patients in 11 hospital trust areas have been told that they may be at risk, including children born by caesarean section.

The investigation is being further broadened to include 2,000 patients of a surgeon in London who is thought to have given hepatitis C to two patients last year.

Patients the surgeon treated at three London hospitals between 1994 and the end of 1999 have been contacted and invited to seek advice and blood tests.

The hospitals are Central Middlesex at Park Royal, and two private hospitals, the Princess Grace, where members of the royal family have been treated, and the Clementine Churchill in Harrow, north west London.

"The chances of a patient being infected with hepatitis C while they receive treatment are very small," said Pat Troop, deputy chief medical officer, yesterday.

The virus is transmitted from blood to blood, so patients can become infected only if their doctor or surgeon cuts him or herself and the blood enters the patient's wound.

But the consequences of infection are serious. Hepatitis C can disappear completely after six months, or lay dormant, or it can attack the liver, causing cirrhosis or cancer.

Treatment is expensive. A Bristol woman who does not know how she contracted the virus and is not in any of the at risk categories - although she has had three major operations in the past eight years - is fighting for a six-month course of drugs costing £4,300 to safeguard the healthy part of her liver.

Avon health authority has put aside only enough money to treat 30 of the 200 local people who need the drugs.

Only four health care workers are known to have been infected with hepatitis C, according to the Department of Health. There has been one previous case in Spain and one in the UK in 1994 which resulted in 300 patients being investigated, but none was found to have been infected.

The present inquiry may lead to a change in the rules. Because the virus had so rarely been passed from doctor to patient, there are no restrictions on health care workers who are carrying the hepatitis C virus treating patients unless they have previously transmitted the infection.

The government's advisory group on hepatitis is examining the problem.

Hepatitis Foundation
British Liver Trust
HepNet

webTitle: Hindley appeal thrown out by law lords

fields.headline: Hindley appeal thrown out by law lords
fields.trailText: Myra Hindley, the moors murderer, is to take her case to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg after her challenge to the home secretary's decision that she should stay in prison for life was decisively rejected yesterday by five law lords.
fields.body:
Myra Hindley, the moors murderer, is to take her case to the European court of human rights in Strasbourg after her challenge to the home secretary's decision that she should stay in prison for life was decisively rejected yesterday by five law lords.

Lawyers for Hindley, 57, argued that the "whole life" tariff was unlawful and should not have been used in her case. But Lords Browne-Wilkinson, Nicholls, Steyn, Hutton and Hobhouse held that the tariff was lawful since the home secretary, Jack Straw, had not ruled out reconsidering the decision in future.

Hindley was convicted with Ian Brady in 1965 of the murders of Lesley Ann Downey, 10, and Edward Evans, 17. In 1987 the pair confessed to involvement in the murders of three other children.

A spokesman for Hindley's solicitors, Taylor Nicholl, said: "We are obviously disappointed by the outcome of this appeal. The judgment makes it clear, however, that the home secretary has a duty to reconsider Myra Hindley's case in the light of her progress in prison and the remorse she has shown by all her conduct, including the volunteering of further confessions in 1987.

"We will be putting representations to the home secretary on that issue. Myra Hindley has served 35 years in prison and we remain committed to securing her release."

The spokesman said the Strasbourg application would challenge the lawfulness of the whole life tariff and would also focus on the fact that the tariff was fixed under a sentencing policy which was more severe than at the time she was sentenced. The European convention on human rights guarantees protection against retrospective punishment.

Lord Lane, then lord chief justice, earlier recommended that she should serve a minimum of 25 years. Whole life tariffs were introduced in 1988 and the tariff was imposed on Hindley in 1990.

The law lords' ruling came less than three weeks after the high court rejected an attempt by Brady to be allowed to starve himself to death. The court held that Ashworth special hospital near Liverpool could lawfully force-feed him.

Relatives of the victims welcomed the decision and called for Brady and Hindley to serve the rest of their lives in prison. Winnie Johnson, 66, the mother of Keith Bennett, to whose murder Brady and Hindley confessed in 1987, said: "I am glad. She deserves to stay in prison for the rest of her life. I don't know why she is wasting her time. It is costing the taxpayers money. She should be left to rot and I hope it takes a long time."

Norman Brennan of the Victims of Crime Trust, which represents the families, said: "These incessant appeals have cost millions, and some of the victims' relatives have never been offered counselling."

Hindley's lawyers had argued that she was the only offender subject to a whole life tariff who was not the actual killer. She acted as an accomplice to Brady, who carried out the killings.

But Lord Steyn said the murders were "uniquely evil". Hindley had been sentenced on the basis of only two murders and the home secretary was entitled to take account of all five.

Hindley and Brady had "abducted, terrified, tortured and killed their victims before burying their bodies on Saddleworth Moor," said Lord Steyn.

"Her role in the murders was pivotal. Without her active participation the five children would probably still be alive today. The pitiless and depraved ordeal of the victims, and the torment of their families, place these crimes in terms of comparative wickedness in an exceptional category."

John Wadham, director of the human rights group Liberty, said: "With politicians constantly competing to be seen to be tough on crime, the chances of a fair and objective decision in such a difficult case are nil." He called for the courts, not government, to decide how long offenders should stay in prison.

Paul Cavadino, director of policy at the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders, said: "Some offenders may have to be kept in prison for life because they continue to pose a danger to the public. But it is wrong to rule out release in advance whatever happens by way of remorse, ageing, infirmity or personal change in an offender."

webTitle: Tories find their dream voter in Asda

fields.headline: Tories find their dream voter in Asda
fields.standfirst:
New election weapon Florida woman meets Mondeo man

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: With the help of pollsters and focus groups, the Tories have calculated whose help they most need to win back to power at the next election.
fields.body:
With the help of pollsters and focus groups, the Tories have calculated whose help they most need to win back to power at the next election.

The result, unveiled yesterday, is Florida Woman - the sort of woman who, in between worrying about standards in the neighbourhood comprehensive, dreams of holidaying on the beaches of Florida.

A portrait began to emerge yesterday. She is between 33 and 55, and is likely to come from East Anglia, the midlands, the London suburbs, or the north or north-west.

She probably lives in a semi or former council property, and drives either an estate, 4x4 or minivan. She and her husband and two children have an income between £20,000 and £50,000. Though the bulk of this may be earned by hubby, who more often than not is a white collar worker or independent tradesman, mum may have a job as well - and mum is the dominant influence in determining how they should vote. That is why she, rather than dad, is the one the Tories are targeting.

They tend to spend their money in Asda, Sainsbury's or Tesco; the rest helps to pay off the mortgage, and provides a bit of money for savings, pensions, and holidays.

Florida woman (or Florrie, as she will no doubt come to be called) comes from a long and not very honoured tradition. There used to be Essex man, a former Labour voter just installed with family, car and mortgage in somewhere like Basildon, who by swinging to Margaret Thatcher in 1979 (along in some cases with his white-stilettoed mate, Essex girl) set off 18 years of Conservative government. Electoral analysis has shown it was nowhere near as simple as that, but the legend has stuck.

Then there was Worcester woman, never a Labour voter before but susceptible to New Labour, especially that nice Mr Blair. She was targeted with conspicuous success at the 1997 election. And there was Mondeo Man, reflecting on his political allegiance while he polished his car on the forecourt of his Barratt home - the sort of convert Labour had to strive hard to cling on to.

In the US, meanwhile, electoral strategists discovered Soccer Mum. Not that she played herself, but she stood on the touchline cheering her children, and might be coaxed into giving her electoral heart to Bill Clinton - which she did in very large numbers.

The Republicans got their revenge with Louise and Harry, worrying in TV ads over Clinton's plans for health care. "There must be a better way," Louise kept saying.

And, perhaps as a sort of John the Baptist for Florida woman, there were Chris and Debbie in the Tories' political broadcasts last year. Debbie, a vivid young thruster and a bit of a termagant, had voted for Major in 1997; Chris, a pathetic wimp, voted for Blair, and Debbie did not mean to let him forget it. "Your mate Blair" she kept saying menacingly whenever some Labour imperfection came up on the news. In the end, Chris succumbed. "He's not my mate," he protested sulkily. He was last seen voting Tory in the Euro-elections.

This is where doubts set in. Can there really be enough households where a Melvyn or Rod is married to an Anthea or Glenys to fuel a Tory come back? Maybe the party's ambitions for fighting its way clear of its present predicament are more limited than one had suspected.

webTitle: Junk food tips scales against racing

fields.headline: Junk food tips scales against racing
fields.trailText: They are podgy, unfit, eat too much junk food, and now they are threatening the future of the sport of kings.
fields.body:
They are podgy, unfit, eat too much junk food, and now they are threatening the future of the sport of kings.

The horse racing industry has started a nationwide search for lightweight recruits following claims that it is suffering from a severe shortage of new jockeys because British youngsters are too big and heavy.

Horse racing officials, led by former jockey Bob Champion, are to tour schools around the country in an attempt to find what they refer to as "light people" following complaints that many British teenagers are too fat for horses.

The industry claims that the shortage in jockeys and stable lads and girls has been brought about because the majority of youngsters are unfit and overweight.

The campaign to find thinner youngsters is the brainchild of Jim Gale, director of the Northern Racing College, based in Doncaster, which specialises in running courses for youngsters keen on pursuing a career in racing.

Mr Gale claims that ideally anyone hoping to work in the industry, either as a jockey or as stable staff, should be aged around 16, weigh under 10 stones, and stand at no more than 5ft 5in.

Over the years, however, Mr Gale claims to have noticed a distinct shortage of young people with such dimensions.

The staff shortage has become so severe that some British stables have started recruiting from abroad. A number have hired staff from Mauritius and eastern Europe, while in America many trainee jockeys and stable hands are from Puerto Rico.

Mr Gale suggests that if youngsters continue to become heavier, then the horse racing authorities might have to try to fatten up the horses so that they will be able to carry larger jockeys.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Best to stay in hospital
fields.body:
Best to stay in hospital

George Best, battling a liver condition in a private hospital, will have to remain there for another week, his doctor said yesterday. The former Manchester United soccer star, 53, was admitted to the Cromwell hospital in Kensington, London, on March 8.

Drummer saves Motown singer

Motown legend Edwin Starr's drummer came to his rescue when he choked backstage during a British concert, it emerged yester day. Starr was performing at Manchester's Opera House on Wednesday when a piece of pear he was eating during a break lodged in his throat. He was saved when drummer Bongo Eddie used a first aid technique.

Cardboard classrooms

Education chiefs in Southend, Essex, are to test the world's first disposable classrooms made out of cardboard at a primary school. Parents are donating cardboard boxes which will make up 90% of the building - the rest will be constructed with traditional materials.

Award for Observer man

Kevin Mitchell of The Observer has been named sports journalist of the year in the Sport England and Sports Writers' Association awards.

fields.headline: Rolling back the years
fields.standfirst: School honours for Jagger
fields.trailText: Rolling Stones singer Mick Jagger returned yesteday to Dartford grammar school in Kent with his former partner Jerry Hall and their children, Elizabeth, 15, and Georgia, eight, to launch a new community arts centre in his name. Also with him on his return to the school he hated as a pupil were his son James, 14, and his parents, Joe and Eva.
fields.body:
Rolling Stones singer Mick Jagger returned yesteday to Dartford grammar school in Kent with his former partner Jerry Hall and their children, Elizabeth, 15, and Georgia, eight, to launch a new community arts centre in his name. Also with him on his return to the school he hated as a pupil were his son James, 14, and his parents, Joe and Eva.

After touring the £2.25m centre, which received National Lottery funding, Jagger posed with a school band playing the Stones classic Brown Sugar.

Pupils decided overwhelmingly to name the centre after the school's most famous former pupil. Jagger said: "Music training in all its forms is a vital part of education."

fields.headline: Loyalist murder committee was 'no hoax'
fields.standfirst:
Jurors award libel damages to Channel 4 programme maker after David Trimble fails to convince them allegation was not credible

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Documentary film-maker Sean McPhilemy won a near-maximum £145,000 in libel damages yesterday when a jury decided that his Channel 4 programme describing a murder committee at the heart of the loyalist movement in Northern Ireland was no "hoax".
fields.body:
Documentary film-maker Sean McPhilemy won a near-maximum £145,000 in libel damages yesterday when a jury decided that his Channel 4 programme describing a murder committee at the heart of the loyalist movement in Northern Ireland was no "hoax".

After six days of deliberation at the end of a nine-week trial in the high court, the jurors unanimously found the Sunday Times had failed to prove, on "the balance of probabilities", that the secret committee of Protestant dignitaries, loyalist terrorists and RUC officers had never existed.

The decision will add force to calls for renewed inquiries into accusations of RUC involvement in loyalist paramilitary killings.

David Trimble, Northern Ireland's first minister and leader of the Ulster Unionists, is one of 19 alleged members of the committee and gave evidence at the trial that the allegation was "simply not credible". Last night he was swift to insist the verdict was not proof that the committee had existed.

Mr McPhilemy was awarded £5,000 less than the £150,000 limit for libel damages.

Outside court he said that it had taken seven years to clear his name, and thanked those who had helped him, and his wife Kathleen and four children for standing by him, through what he called his ordeal.

Channel 4, which commissioned the 1991 programme, The Committee, and transmitted it while acknowledging it was "a risk", said: "This verdict confirms how everyone involved in making the programme acted with integrity throughout."

Times Newspapers Ltd, which faces legal costs of more than £1m, announced it would appeal.

"Nineteen out of 21 alleged members of the committee appeared in court for the Sunday Times. They stated their innocence, and their evidence wasn't challenged," said a spokesman. "In these circumstances, the jury's verdict causes us obvious concerns."

The case was brought by Mr McPhilemy when the Sunday Times published an article in May 1993 accusing his programme of being "little more than a collage of unsubstantiated rumours and fabrications", in which the main source had been paid £5,000 and coached to read scripts.

In court the newspaper admitted it could not prove that the source, Jim Sands, a self-professed liar who later retracted his claims, had been paid, but asserted that Mr McPhilemy, 52, had engaged in a "quite deliberate" deception.

It also alleged he had made "nasty" allegations about respectable people, named in a book based on the documentary as committee members and associates, and published seven years later in America. Some of those named, including Mr Trimble, are engaged in separate libel actions against the book's US distributors.

The documentary and the book arose after the Irish programme-maker decided in 1990 to investigate whether, as the documentary was to put it, "a hidden hand might be guiding the loyalist death squads to their targets".

His suspicion had been aroused by stories about leaked security force montages featuring terrorist suspects, and collusion between the security forces and loyalists - collusion that was confirmed by an inquiry by Sir John Stevens, now the commissioner of the Metropolitan police.

Mr McPhilemey's researcher, Ben Hamilton, met Mr Sands, who claimed he was a member of the Ulster Central Coordinating Committee, a group of 50 to 60 Protestant businessmen, lawyers and pillars of the community that met regularly with paramilitaries such as Billy Wright (former head of the Loyalist Volunteer Force, killed in the Maze in 1997) to plot the murders of republicans and innocent Catholics. Even more disturbingly, the group had the collusion of RUC officers under the name of "the inner force" who would clear the way for such murders, including that of Pat Finucane, the solicitor, in 1989.

The Dispatches special provoked an outcry from Mr Trimble and many others, and an RUC inquiry that pronounced the committee to be "a fabrication".

Last night, the RUC said it would not revise its judgment in light of the verdict.

"This is not a matter for the RUC. Why would we have any comment?" added a spokesman.

fields.headline: Kidneys for sale after £4m win
fields.trailText: A dialysis patient who won £4.1m on the national lottery has been inundated by people trying to sell him one of their kidneys in return for a share in his windfall.
fields.body:
A dialysis patient who won £4.1m on the national lottery has been inundated by people trying to sell him one of their kidneys in return for a share in his windfall.

Dozens of calls were made to newspapers after the story of 26-year-old Mick Taylor, from Halifax, West Yorkshire, appeared yesterday.

He said of the win: "I would exchange my millions for a new kidney. I was more excited when I got my transplant than when I won this money."

The selling of body parts is illegal in Britain and when Mr Taylor was told about the offers he said: "I am willing to wait my turn like everyone else."

Mr Taylor has suffered from kidney disease since he was 11 and has had two failed transplants. He is now on the waiting list for another kidney and has to undergo renal dialysis three times a week.

Despite failed transplants at the ages of 13 and 21 his doctors at St Luke's hospital, Huddersfield, said his third transplant should last a lot longer.

Organisations dealing with dialysis patients were outraged at the would-be donors. Nick Turkentine, head of charity affairs at the National Kidney Research Foundation, said: "I am speechless. I can't believe that people would offer to sell their organs for the chance of some lottery cash.

"What this man was trying to say was that he would give up everything to have his health - he wasn't saying he wanted to buy a new kidney. Words cannot express how we as a charity feel about people trafficking in human organs."

A spokesman for the Transplant Support Service said: "Any commercial trade in organs is strictly prohibited in this country under the Human Organ Transplant Act 1989."

Mr Taylor said no amount of money could buy him another kidney and the most important thing for him was to have another transplant.

He shared Saturday's £12.3m jackpot with two others, and has decided to give part of his winnings to the hospitals where he is treated. "I will be making donations to St Luke's and to the paediatric renal unit at St James's hospital in Leeds," he said.

Last year, 4,794 people were waiting for kidney transplants in Britain but only 1,626 operations were carried out.

webTitle: Record increase in house prices prompts warning

fields.headline: Record increase in house prices prompts warning
fields.trailText: Warning bells were sounded yesterday about the "unsustainable" pace of house price inflation as a survey showed that the average UK property jumped in value by a record amount this month.
fields.body:
Warning bells were sounded yesterday about the "unsustainable" pace of house price inflation as a survey showed that the average UK property jumped in value by a record amount this month.

House prices are rising at their fastest annual rate since 1989, according to Nationwide building society. And the cost of an average home soared by 2.3% during March - the largest monthly rise since it started compiling monthly data in 1991.

This means that the typical property is now worth £79,393 - 16.2% more than a year ago, when the figure was £68,308.

The figures came just 24 hours after Bank of England data showed a surge in mortgage lending.

Nationwide attempted to quell fears of an overheating market by saying that house prices were only back to where it would have expected them to be at this point, suggesting that the risk of an imminent downturn in prices was small.

However, it added that if house price inflation carried on at its current pace for another 12 to 18 months, experience suggested that a rapid slowdown in price growth would follow.

"The longer-term outlook is not without risks," said the society. "The current pace of house price inflation on an annual basis, 16.2%, is not sustainable over the long run."

Alex Bannister, Nationwide's group economist, was keen to dispel any suggestions that the country was heading for a repeat of 1980s-style boom-and-bust. "We don't think the market will get anything like as overheated as it did then. It is not an 80s-style boom," he said. A rapid slowdown in price inflation could mean virtually no growth, or in the worst case, prices could fall, he added.

However, the society's uneasiness could also be detected in its call for homebuyers to "take a cautious view about their borrowing" so that they do not overstretch themselves. Its comments come weeks after the City's top regulator, the financial services authority, warned mortgage lenders that they were lending homebuyers too much money.

The Nationwide's data could increase the likelihood of a hike in interest rates when the Bank of England monetary policy committee meets next week.

Rising house prices have hit the private rental market, according to another survey by Bradford & Bingley estate agents, which says that publicity about climbing property values has prompted growing numbers of existing and potential tenants to turn their attention to buying a home.

"This has led to a temporary weakening in tenant demand, causing a drop in rental values," it said.

webTitle: Noye 'smiled as he fled stab scene'

fields.headline: Noye 'smiled as he fled stab scene'
fields.standfirst: Accused claims self-defence as M25 murder trial opens
fields.trailText: The fiancée of a man allegedly killed by Kenneth Noye in a road rage attack fought back tears yesterday as she described seeing her unarmed boyfriend desperately trying to kick a knife away from Mr Noye's hand before being stabbed in the heart.
fields.body:
The fiancée of a man allegedly killed by Kenneth Noye in a road rage attack fought back tears yesterday as she described seeing her unarmed boyfriend desperately trying to kick a knife away from Mr Noye's hand before being stabbed in the heart.

In a faint voice, with her hands trembling by her side, Danielle Cable told the Old Bailey how Stephen Cameron, 21, stumbled towards her with blood seeping from the two wounds as Mr Noye raced away in his car.

"I saw Steve clutching his chest," she told the jury yesterday. "He said, 'he stabbed me Dan, take his number plate.' I saw blood on his chest. It was dreadful. I was screaming and crying for someone to help me. Then Stephen collapsed on the floor."

Another witness, Alan Decabral, saw Mr Noye smile as he sped from the scene, the court was told.

Ms Cable, 21, was giving evidence yesterday afternoon during the first day of the trial of Mr Noye, 52, who is accused of murdering Mr Cameron on Sunday May 19 1996.

Sitting in the dock in a grey open-neck shirt and matching cardigan, his eyes darting around the room, Mr Noye heard Julian Bevan QC, prosecuting, describe how Mr Cameron's murder shortly after 1pm at the Swanley interchange of the M25 in Kent was born of "anger and pride" following a "punch-up" between the two men.

He went on to describe how within minutes of the attack, Mr Noye, of West Kingsdown, Kent, set about covering his tracks and fleeing the country carrying a briefcase full of cash.

"What he did following this [attack] clearly tells its own story."

Mr Noye, he said, made several calls from his mobile phone to associates and his wife, Brenda, and arrangements were swiftly made to fly him out of the country by helicopter to France and then by private jet to Madrid, Spain, before another trip to the south of the country.

There was evidence, Mr Bevan told the jury, that the car he was driving, a Land Rover Discovery, had been disposed of.

Spanish hideout

Detectives finally tracked Mr Noye to his hideout in Spain in August 1998, the Old Bailey heard.

Ms Cable was flown out with a police escort and identified him as he sat in a restaurant.

Mr Noye's immediate arrest and extradition last May, following several appeals, led her to face him again - the first time since Mr Cameron died - in a tense hearing in front of Mr Justice Latham at the Old Bailey yesterday.

Mr Bevan said the incident which led to Mr Cameron's death and Mr Noye's subsequent escape from the country was sparked by a trivial episode of poor driving.

Mr Noye, he claimed, had swerved in front of a small red van driven by Ms Cable, who had passed her driving test seven months before, as she drove with Mr Cameron to London.

Mr Cameron shook his head in disapproval and when the two vehicles came to a stop at the next set of traffic lights, Mr Noye got out of his car and walked towards the couple, "angry at the way in which that van had been driven".

"Stephen Cameron's decision to get out of that red van and deal with this potentially ugly situation cost him his life."

The men, who did not know each other, became involved in a "violent exchange", the jury was told.

Mr Noye punched Mr Cameron hard in the eye and he retaliated by kicking him, the court heard.

Ms Cable described how she saw Mr Noye, who had a blank expression on his face, fumbling in the pockets of his short-sleeve jacket as if he was trying to find something.

She had pleaded with her boyfriend to get back in the van, but he had told her to stand back.

"He [Noye] broke away from Mr Cameron," said Mr Bevan. "He went towards his Discovery... and it appears he acquired a knife. Mr Bevan said Mr Noye now admitted that he had stabbed Mr Cameron - he had denied being the second driver during the extradition proceedings - but would insist that he had been acting in self-defence.

"It's the crown's case that this stabbing to death of Stephen Cameron was not merely unlawful, it was murder," he said.

As Mr Cameron's life slipped away, Mr Noye was busy on his mobile phone, probably believing that someone had taken down the registration number of his car, the court heard.

Mr Bevan said the Land Rover Discovery driven by Mr Noye had never been found, but offered the jury two intriguing tales.

Witnesses had seen a vehicle similar to Mr Noye's being taken to a car yard owned by one of his friends, Tommy Lee, in Dartford, Kent, where it might have been destroyed. An AA membership card in the name of Kenneth Noye was found there by detectives.

And the day after the killing, a man giving the false name of John Grittins bought a Land Rover Discovery from a dealer in north London, paying £12,000 in cash from a plastic bag. The address the man gave was false and the car was later found outside Mr Noye's home.

During cross-examination by Stephen Batten QC, for Mr Noye, Ms Cable admitted Mr Noye did not look angry when he got out of his car.

He suggested that Mr Cameron had initiated the fight and had had the upper hand.

"Is it the fact that you told the police, and indeed told us, far less than you really saw because you found it, perhaps totally naturally, difficult to admit that any of this was Stephen's fault?"

Ms Cable replied: "No, I don't believe it was his fault at all."

When asked if her fiance had "something of a temper", she said she had never seen it.

Mr Batten asked if she knew about him losing his temper at their engagement party when he urinated on a neighbour's fence and banged on his door.

She admitted that she had seen them fighting.

Mr Batten asked: "Would you say that Stephen was a young man who thought he could take care of himself without too much difficulty?

But he insisted that this should not be seen to be "in any way prejudicial" to the defendant. "It is absolutely vital... that Mr Noye is given a fair trial," he said.

Miss Cable said: "Yes, I suppose he thought he could take care of himself."

The case continues tomorrow.

webTitle: Trimble allies accept legal reform plan

fields.headline: Trimble allies accept legal reform plan
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Northern Ireland peace process received a mild boost last night when allies of David Trimble gave a guarded welcome to a radical report which would transform Northern Ireland's legal system to appeal to nationalists.
fields.body:
The Northern Ireland peace process received a mild boost last night when allies of David Trimble gave a guarded welcome to a radical report which would transform Northern Ireland's legal system to appeal to nationalists.

Fears of a unionist backlash against the report, which called for the removal of royal symbols from Northern Ireland's courts, proved unfounded as Ulster Unionist supporters of the Good Friday agreement made clear they could live with its findings.

The response to the review of the criminal justice system, set up under the Good Friday agreement, was welcomed by the Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson.

The report, likely to be implemented after a six-month consultation period, would introduce sweeping changes to Northern Ireland's legal system to remove what nationalists see as overtly British symbols.

Judges would no longer swear an oath of allegiance to the Queen, and an independent commission would be set up to increase the number of nationalists sitting as judges.

In the most controversial area of the report, all royal symbols would be removed from inside Northern Ireland's courts. However, the Royal Coat of Arms would remain on the outside of existing courthouses and the union flag would continue to fly.

The report's authors underlined their determination to strike a balance between unionists, who see royal symbols as an important sign of Northern Ireland's position within the United Kingdom, and nationalists who regard such symbols as alien.

"We considered the removal of all symbols but felt that this could be misinterpreted as being inconsistent with Northern Ireland's constitutional position," the report said.

"On the other hand, we are conscious that the presence of the Royal Coat of Arms in a prominent position in the courtroom could be regarded by some as inconsistent with the need for court proceedings to take place in a neutral environment."

Their even-handed approach was welcomed by allies of Mr Trimble, the Ulster Unionist party leader.

Duncan Shipley-Dalton, a UUP member of the Northern Ireland assembly, said: "We're quite pleased to see the crown symbols will be retained on the exterior of court buildings so the overall ethos remains British and clearly an integral part of the UK legal system."

His remarks were welcomed by sources at the Northern Ireland Office, who had feared the Ulster Unionist reaction to the criminal justice review would mirror the party's response to the Patten commission's report on the RUC, which also recommended the removal of royal symbols.

Grassroots Ulster Unionists registered their opposition to the Patten commission last weekend by voting to block Sinn Fein from rejoining the Northern Ireland executive if the government implemented the RUC reforms. Mr Trimble disagreed with the vote, although he rejects the key recommendations of the Patten commission.

Ulster Unionist opponents of the Good Friday agreement rejected the criminal justice review.

Jeffrey Donaldson, the UUP MP for Lagan Valley, said: "The review will have the same impact as the Patten report and it could be extremely damaging at this very sensitive time."

Ministers will fear the Donaldson faction, which was strengthened last weekend when it captured 43% of the vote in a party leadership challenge against Mr Trimble, may also try to use the new report to lay down further conditions over the formation of the power-sharing executive.

Unionist opponents were also angered by other key recommendations in the report. These included the setting up of an independent public prosecution service to take over the work of the DPP.

Sinn Fein said republicans would wait to see whether the report delivered a major overhaul of the Northern Ireland justice system.

Main points

Scrap the oath of allegiance to the Queen sworn by new judges and cease the declaration of "God save the Queen" as judges enter court

Establish an independent commission to oversee judicial appointments and an independent public prosecution service to take over the work of the DPP

Remove royal symbols from courtrooms

Allow the use of the Irish language in court

End police patrols at courts

End the wearing of wigs by judges and barristers

Appoint a minister of justice and an attorney general

Increase cooperation with the Irish Republic, allowing prisoners to serve sentences across the border

fields.headline: Telegraph owner drops lawsuit
fields.trailText: The press tycoon Conrad Black has dropped his libel case against Britain's ambassador to Berlin, who had suggested that the Daily Telegraph's coverage of Germany and Europe was biased.
fields.body:
The press tycoon Conrad Black has dropped his libel case against Britain's ambassador to Berlin, who had suggested that the Daily Telegraph's coverage of Germany and Europe was biased.

Mr Black, chairman of the Telegraph Group, decided not to pursue the case, which began when a writ was issued last week after the envoy, Sir Paul Lever, was reported in the German paper Die Welt as saying that "foreign owned" papers, such as the Telegraph, were not interested in telling their readers the "objective truth" but instead promoted an anti-European and anti-German line.

Informing Sir Paul of his decision to stop the legal action Mr Black wrote to thank him for bringing the matter to "so prompt and elegant a conclusion".

"I do accept that the Die Welt interview did not come out as you intended and understand how these problems arise," Mr Black wrote.

Mr Black started the action last Friday even though Sir Paul had apologised for his comments. The newspaper owner had been particularly annoyed because Sir Paul's comments seemed to suggest that Mr Black was not British and so was more interested in getting across a particular point of view than report facts.

At the time Mr Black said: "I am getting a little tired as a British citizen and a long-term British resident of being portrayed by some ill-informed people as a Europhobic foreigner."

fields.headline: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: ITV kicked off the round of spring/summer programme launches this week. Like the summer sales, this is the annual process by which each and every broadcaster tells us what it's got in store for the season - with one subtle difference: we're meant to flock in our millions to view the programmes on offer, not expect cut-price bargains to take away with us.
fields.body:
ITV kicked off the round of spring/summer programme launches this week. Like the summer sales, this is the annual process by which each and every broadcaster tells us what it's got in store for the season - with one subtle difference: we're meant to flock in our millions to view the programmes on offer, not expect cut-price bargains to take away with us.

Headlining the ITV line up is drama: the costume variety with Nicholas Nickleby and the Mayor of Casterbridge both set to grace our screens. But because of the lead-times involved in flounce-tastic numbers like this, we won't see these before the leaves begin to fall this autumn. The ITV version of the Mayor of Casterbridge has already been in the planning for two years (OK, not that long considering it was written 114 years ago). It was put on the back-burner because of a costume drama bottleneck (cue vision of carriages jammed in authentic looking mud-drenched London square) before Alan Bleasdale's Oliver Twist got out of the way at Christmas.

But what will be appearing on ITV this 'season' is Skinner and Baddiel Unplanned. A re-version of the duo's sofa-bound comedic chat show, the programme will put them on the spot like never before. They've promised not to script a single line, leaving their wits to do the talking on cue from the audience.

And to make life even harder for themselves Frank Skinner and David Baddiel are thought to have promised - on their team's lives - not to talk about football. Could be very tricky, considering the show will start just days before this year's Euro 2000 championship. How will they resist the temptation? But then, you'd expect them to have to do something to earn the £600,000 they're reported to have secured for the show.

Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast magazine

fields.headline: Labour panic over poll meltdown
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is bracing himself for Labour's worst electoral performance in nearly a decade at next month's local elections, according to a secret cabinet memo seen by the Guardian.
fields.byline: David Hencke, Nicholas Watt  and Patrick Wintour
fields.body:
Tony Blair is bracing himself for Labour's worst electoral performance in nearly a decade at next month's local elections, according to a secret cabinet memo seen by the Guardian.

Ministers, who are gathering at Chequers today for a pre-general election brainstorming session, have been warned that the Tories are on course to win back control of a series of councils throughout England won by Labour at the height of John Major's unpopularity in 1996.

The memo, written by Hilary Armstrong, the local government minister, and Ian McCartney, the cabinet office minister, comes as the normally loyal Labour leader in local government, Sir Jeremy Beecham, mounts an attack on the way Downing Street is centralising power in Whitehall and belittling the role of councillors.

Complaining of a gung-ho approach in Downing Street and the death of local democracy, Sir Jeremy warns that the government's "frontline first" rhetoric and more ring-fencing of funds "is pushing relentlessly in the direction of government central control".

Sir Jeremy, in a Guardian article intended as a warning shot to Mr Blair, writes: "The belittling of the role of local councillors by government is not confined to local funding decisions. Their role in leading communities and representing the interests of communities is also under relentless attack."

Ministers will be parachuted in to try to whip up support among disillusioned traditional Labour voters before May 4.

The memo candidly admits that the party faces large losses - mainly to the Tories. This is mostly because it will be defending seats won in 1996, one of the best years for Labour when Tory strongholds fell in a prelude to Mr Blair's general election victory a year later. It could lose hundreds of seats in middle England.

The memo calls for a ministerial campaign to combat apathy and mid-term disillusionment, and aims to get big hitters such as David Blunkett, the education secretary, Jack Straw, the home secretary, and Alan Milburn, the health secretary, campaigning prominently in marginal towns and cities. Mr Straw and Mr Blunkett are reported to have offered to go to Labour's most vulnerable areas to rally support by promoting Labour's record on schools and crime.

The Guardian has been told that the fundamental aim is to prevent William Hague getting more elected councillors in local government than the prime minister. If the Tories were to achieve this, it would be a key psychological breakthrough and springboard for rejuvenation. Big gains, after Tory success in last year's European elections and more recently in the Ayr byelection for the Scottish parliament, would help strip the gloss from the Blair administration.

Labour is defending more than 1,550 of the 3,337 seats last contested in 1996. One Labour source said the party would take a pounding. "This year's local elections are the last cycle of seats that came before the general election," the source said. "We will be fighting a vigorous campaign because we believe the Budget has given us a great springboard."

Labour is coy about its hopes, focusing instead on the gains the Tories would have to make to show recovery. If the Tories make 200 gains they will have equalled the 34% they won at last year's local elections. If they notch up more than 400 gains, they could be on course for victory in next year's general election.

Tory central office strategists, who are increasingly alarmed by the party's failure to improve its opinion poll standing, are playing down their chances. One source said that most of the seats up for grabs this year are in urban areas, where the Tories are still struggling to make an impact.

1996 is seen as having been a peak for the Liberal Democrats, who have become a major force in local politics, and they are also braced for losses.
