Big gains, after Tory success in last year's European elections and more recently in the Ayr byelection for the Scottish parliament, would help strip the gloss from the Blair administration. Labour is defending more than 1,550 of the 3,337 seats last contested in 1996. One Labour source said the party would take a pounding. "This year's local elections are the last cycle of seats that came before the general election," the source said. "We will be fighting a vigorous campaign because we believe the Budget has given us a great springboard." Labour is coy about its hopes, focusing instead on the gains the Tories would have to make to show recovery. If the Tories make 200 gains they will have equalled the 34% they won at last year's local elections. If they notch up more than 400 gains, they could be on course for victory in next year's general election. Tory central office strategists, who are increasingly alarmed by the party's failure to improve its opinion poll standing, are playing down their chances. One source said that most of the seats up for grabs this year are in urban areas, where the Tories are still struggling to make an impact. 1996 is seen as having been a peak for the Liberal Democrats, who have become a major force in local politics, and they are also braced for losses.

webTitle: Tories search for more women MPs

fields.headline: Tories search for more women MPs
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: William Hague yesterday gave his backing to a Conservative drive to recruit more women as parliamentary candidates, as it became clear that the party is failing to select women for winnable seats.
fields.body:
William Hague yesterday gave his backing to a Conservative drive to recruit more women as parliamentary candidates, as it became clear that the party is failing to select women for winnable seats.

The Women into Public Life campaign will include "talent spotting" of potential candidates, a national programme of events to encourage women to move into local and national politics, and more advising of prospective women parliamentarians. However, it stops short of introducing quotas.

The campaign, launched yesterday alongside a document called Choices to highlight Conservative policies affecting women, reflects unease among party strategists that it will once again return only a handful of female MPs.

Of the 196 constituencies that have so far selected a candidate for the next general election, only 32 - 16% - have chosen women, and among the party's top 10 target seats only one women is running.

Senior figures in the party acknowledge that it has been left behind by the government in addressing women's issues and must listen to their concerns if it is to win back those whose votes were lost to Labour at the last election.

The drive to add more women MPs to the Tories' current 14, compared with Labour's 101, follows two highly critical reports by Tory-leaning think tanks which said the party was failing women and would be punished at the polls.

Conservative Women, by Tessa Keswick for the Centre for Policy Studies, said too many party members "hanker for the days of the subservient family woman" and urged the leadership to "set out a new strategy based on the full and equal participation of women".

In 1997 the swing from Tory to Labour was higher among women than men, and among women aged 18-35 Labour had a 22% lead.

While electoral necessity will push the Tories to address female concerns - market research has identifed "Florida woman", one who holidays in America, as a key voter to target - they will steer clear of Labour's strategy of defining issues, such as equal pay, which affect women.

Launching Choices yesterday, the shadow education and employment secretary, Theresa May, said the government had wrongly "compartmentalised" women's issues.

The Conservatives plan a "family scholarship" scheme to help women to return to their careers after bringing up children, the extension of closed circuit TV in stations and car parks, and universal testing for HPV, the virus that causes cervical cancer.

fields.headline: The drugs don't work
fields.trailText: John, one of the subjects of Constant Craving (BBC2), used to stop foreplay if it lasted longer than 20 minutes so he could have a cigarette. Addicted to nicotine to the point that he smoked 90 a day, he even devised a method by which he could smoke in the shower. Melanie was a heroin addict with the same compulsion to get a hit. So too DK who smoked cocaine. "The best orgasm you could want to have," was how he described his brand of high. You can't really argue with that kind of hype, but you also have to remember how it makes your genitals shrivel up.
fields.body:
John, one of the subjects of Constant Craving (BBC2), used to stop foreplay if it lasted longer than 20 minutes so he could have a cigarette. Addicted to nicotine to the point that he smoked 90 a day, he even devised a method by which he could smoke in the shower. Melanie was a heroin addict with the same compulsion to get a hit. So too DK who smoked cocaine. "The best orgasm you could want to have," was how he described his brand of high. You can't really argue with that kind of hype, but you also have to remember how it makes your genitals shrivel up.

And not just your genitals. The reward centres in your brain first go wild for cocaine or nicotine or heroin, and then start wilting, so that eventually you're not having fun any more. Your drug of choice, once the bearer of so much pleasure, deprives you of it altogether. An irony of which Sophocles could be mightily proud.

So far, so Grange Hill's Just Say No!, but Constant Craving went further, weaving the stories of Melanie, John and DK with threads of scientific narrative to produce an intricate and fascinating whole. Science documentary at its best, it raised all sorts of questions like "Can you be born an addict?" and "Just how much money does Bill Paterson make from voiceovers?"

Of course, Paterson's soothing tones helped make all the rather complex science digestible and, along with Melanie, John and DK, gave a humanity to what could've been another dullard "boffins do stuff in labs" programme. It was a lesson in how scientific types can raise their profile and combat what a report from a House of Lords' Select Committee said was a remoteness from the public (praise from Caesar indeed, but that's another matter).

Another survey this week revealed that practically every British institution had suffered a drop in public confidence, and Deadly Pursuits (C4) certainly won't have helped the police regain much. Sheena McDonald's investigation into accidents involving police vehicles was positively frightening as it revealed just how much extra training police drivers get (not a lot), how much maintenance police vehicles undergo (even less) and exactly what the police were doing about the haemorrhaging of faith in their ability (less than zero). McDonald's status as a celebrity victim of a police van - on the wrong side of the road doing double the speed limit - certainly compromised her position as a detached journalist but it gave Deadly Pursuits an edge. The most striking moment though came with the image of a windscreen shattered by a web of cracks by the impact of one John Todd. As his sister reeled off his height and weight and hobbies, tears filled her eyes and hope left our hearts.

Which presumably is why we seek cosy safety in the likes of Always And Everyone (ITV). Set in the world's quietest and most tastefully decorated casualty department (all glass bricks and pastel purple - very Anne McKevitt), it has a cast of vaguely familiar folk and not a lot else. With only one patient by the first ad break, the only accidents-waiting-to-happen would be the result of nodding off with a cup of tea in your hand.

To be fair, there could be whiplash due to a head-on collision with a cliche - it was filmed in Manchester so naturally we got a shot of a tram - or contusions to the head due to motifs being hammered home. Just how many times do we need to see Niamh Cusack's coffee cup? Poor Charlie in Casualty barely gets a whiff of coffee when he's on duty, and if he does, it's in a Styrofoam cup. But Christine Fletcher (surely more the name of a prison officer than a nice doctor) has a ginormously huge mug with a cow on it. And there it is again. And again. And once more right at the very end. Still, there wasn't much else going on in St Victor's (Mancunians must be less accident-prone than Holby residents), so perhaps the coffee cup was a blessing. Why, there wasn't even dry humping in the relatives' room.

Buffy The Vampire Slayer (BBC2) returned in typical high-kickin' style. Exiled from Sunnydale, Buffy was still saving the world and battling her own demons. Exuberant in its anti-authoritarianism and developing the adolescence-as-hell metaphor wonderfully, Buffy may seem teen and flip but with lines like "What is hell but but a total absence of hope?" it articulates the fears that come with a loss of faith and a need for safety. Out of the mouths of babes.

fields.headline: Irrepressible!
fields.standfirst: If you grew up in the 80s you might just remember a very strange Japanese action show about a boy monk, his simian protector and friends. As the series is released on video,  Yasue Carter relives the phenomenon that was Monkey
fields.trailText: In the deep dark days of the early 80s, in a TV landscape filled with Cheggars Plays Pop, Swap Shop and Rentaghost, there was one kid's show that seemed to come out of nowhere, a surreally original blend of martial arts, daft humour and abstract-gendered monsters known to its legions of playground imitators as Monkey.
fields.body:
In the deep dark days of the early 80s, in a TV landscape filled with Cheggars Plays Pop, Swap Shop and Rentaghost, there was one kid's show that seemed to come out of nowhere, a surreally original blend of martial arts, daft humour and abstract-gendered monsters known to its legions of playground imitators as Monkey.

It told the story of three exiles from heaven, Monkey, Pigsy and Sandy who had been assigned the task of protecting the curious boy-monk Tripikata on his journey to India to collect the teachings of Buddha and bring them back to China. Every week they encountered various temptations (usually in the form of delectable maidens who would transform into demons once night fell) that would have the three less-than-committed pilgrims attempting to leave their holy path for more earthly delights.

Pigsy with his insatiable appetite for food, wine and the ladies, and Sandy with his relentless pessimism were worthy sidekicks, but the undoubted star of the show was Monkey. Able to pull a giant fighting staff out of the air by simply plucking a hair from his hirsute body, Monkey's most desirable asset was his pink flying cloud, summoned by waving two fingers quickly in front of his mouth. His only weakness is the headband he wears, which Tripikata can tighten by chanting a headache sutra whenever the cheeky ape gets out of hand.

Set to a curious bad-vibe rock disco soundtrack, episodes frequently lurched from one extreme to another, with the heroes battling bizarre Bela Lugosi-style demons one minute, dancing in groovy discos inside giant carps the next, before the adventures were summarised by the narrator and given a philosophical spin.

In Japan, however, Monkey was far from being a cult hit for kids, or a show that parents could not understand and would despair of their children watching. It was one of the few shows that parents would encourage kids to watch, as it was seen as an educational introduction to Buddhist thought and philosophy. It offered a way of introducing Buddhist teachings to the people without having to visit temples or read difficult religious texts. It was a primetime family show, broadcast in 1978 on Saturday nights. Shot on location in China, at a time when the Japanese and Chinese governments had only recently restored diplomatic relations, it was a story as familiar to viewers as say, Pride And Prejudice or Robin Hood. Based on a 16th century Chinese novel, Wu Ch'eng-en's Journey To The West, which was itself based on the real-life journey of a 7th-century monk, Hsuan Tsang to India, it was first translated from Chinese into Japanese nearly 250 years ago and a picture book was printed in 1806. Several film and TV versions had already appeared before, including a film directed by Kishiro Yamamoto in 1940, and a popular cartoon in the 50s from the creator of Astro Boy, Osamu Tezuka.

Its arrival was greeted with great excitement, especially when the cast was announced. All four of the main characters were already well known figures in the Japanese entertainment world, and, like the Batman series in the US, popular character actors took guest villain spots.

Monkey was played by the multi-talented Masaaki Sakai. He was the vocalist with 60s mod icons The Spiders, (Electronic Grandmother, Monkey Dance, Sad Sunset etc) and continued after the band split as a successful solo artist, releasing a version of Monkey's theme tune, before moving onto traditional Japanese folk music in his later career. After Monkey he presented a cookery show, Here's The Kitchen; Superhuman Coliseum, featuring guests with unusual talents (a Tarrant On TV favourite); a health advice show called Aruaru; as well as starring in Shinano No Columbo, a detective show, and some historical dramas.

Sakai wasn't the only pop star. Mild-mannered Sandy was played by Shiro Kishibe who was in another popular 60s group called the Tigers, one of The Spiders' main rivals in the Group Sound scene. Both bands have since been featured on compilations of Japanese pop released in Britain, like GS We Love You and Monster Go Go. Kishibe has since left acting for a career in table tennis.

Pigsy was played by Toshiyuki Nishida, a well known actor and comedian who frequently plays honest, good hearted buffoons and is still acting today, in films like The Silk Road, Dream Of Russia and Heavenly Sin.

The enigmatic Tripitaka, who was responsible for countless arguments over his gender, was in fact played by a woman, Masako Natsume. She was a very popular teen idol who had starred in films like Onimasa and Shousa as well as TV dramas and appeared in a campaign for top Japanese cosmetic company Kanebo before landing the boy monk role. In 1985 she died from leukaemia at only 27. All of Japan was devastated by her death, and she remains a popular figure, with memorabilia still selling well every year.

Monkey volumes one and two will be available on video from Monday

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText:
Ben-Hur
(William Wyler, 1959)
9pm, TCM

A lavish three-and-a-half hour remake of a silent version of Lew Wallace's stodgy novel, starring Charlton Heston as Ben-Hur. It's a heroic tale, with the sombre, reflective scenes such as those in the leper colony as memorable as the more celebrated battle of the galleys and the chariot race. Stephen Boyd is a wicked, rather camp, Messala; Haya Harareet sweet as Esther. Among the umpteen Oscar winners, Robert L Surtees was one of the most deserving for his vibrant photography.
fields.body:
Ben-Hur
(William Wyler, 1959)
9pm, TCM

A lavish three-and-a-half hour remake of a silent version of Lew Wallace's stodgy novel, starring Charlton Heston as Ben-Hur. It's a heroic tale, with the sombre, reflective scenes such as those in the leper colony as memorable as the more celebrated battle of the galleys and the chariot race. Stephen Boyd is a wicked, rather camp, Messala; Haya Harareet sweet as Esther. Among the umpteen Oscar winners, Robert L Surtees was one of the most deserving for his vibrant photography.

The X Files
(Rob Bowman, 1998)
10pm, Sky Premier

Bowman, a veteran director of the TV series, dumps agents Mulder (David Duchovny) and Scully (Gillian Anderson, pictured) into a dense but pleasantly familiar plot. There are impressive special effects and Martin Landau's conspiracy theorist stokes up the atmosphere. The main problem is the uncertain tone: there's an odd shift from secret-agent heroics to Alien horrors, and the biggest thrill is the pair's will-they-won't-they romance.

Black Rainbow
(Mike Hodges, 1991)
3.50am, FilmFour

More supernatural phenomena: a dark tale of a clairvoyant and a killer. Rosanna Arquette stars as a spiritualist who finds herself able to predict the targets of a black-gloved hitman; the problem is convincing her boozy dad (Jason Robards) and local reporter Tom Hulce of her gift as the villain homes in. Intelligent and well acted, it builds to a very powerful climax.
Paul Howlett

True Believer
(Joseph Ruben, 1989)
11pm, Carlton Cinema

James Woods vibrates with manic intensity as a jaded lawyer, one-time firebrand defender of radical causes, who is persuaded to ditch his usual drug-dealing clientele and take up the case of a young Korean, jailed for a murder he may not have committed. Robert Downey Jr turns in an appealing performance, with comic undertones à la Jason Schwartzman in Rushmore, as the graduate lawyer whose idealism proves too much for Woods to resist, and the ensuing plot machinations are satisfyingly taut.
Camilla Redmond

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Felicity Finch (The Archers' Ruth) investigates other nation's soaps in Tales Of Everyday Folk (11.0am, Radio 4). Her first example seethes with infant opium addiction, blood feuds and unexpected death. The BBC World Service originally aimed New Home, New Life at Afghan refugees in Pakistan. Now it's acquired a huge audience in Afghanistan. Transmitted in Pushtu and Dari, it needs more than 100 actors. Plots reflect perils unknown to Borsetshire, like live ordnance abandoned on the village short-cut.

The young Italian conductor Riccardo Chailly is the star of In Concert (9.0pm, Classic FM), last of the London Symphony Orchestra's six Discovery concerts. The series offers a detailed analysis of each work before it is performed. Tonight's it's Stravinsky's Rite Of Spring, cause of a riot at its 1913 Paris premiere. Now, of course, no one bats an eyelid at its incredibly complex rhythmic patterns and harmonic dissonance.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Maltesers ad says about you
fields.trailText: The ad: A hapless bloke is being badgered by his missus into doing some Hoovering. "Alright, alright, I can do it. It can't be hard," he says, as she retires to the kitchen to wash up. She continues to bark instructions at him, but within seconds he is sitting on the sofa, doing the Hoovering while watching TV. He then spots a bag of Maltesers on the coffee table and uses the Hoover nozzle to pick it up. Soon he has abandoned his housework altogether and is tucking into the chocolates, but he is rumbled as his wife comes back in from kitchen. "Comfy?" she says.

fields.headline: Blair 'balances' Lords with 33 new peers
fields.standfirst: Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair today moves to create greater parity between Labour and the Conservatives in the House of Lords with the appointment of 33 new working peers to the second chamber.
fields.body:
Tony Blair today moves to create greater parity between Labour and the Conservatives in the House of Lords with the appointment of 33 new working peers to the second chamber.

In a step towards the government's pledge to rebalance the once Tory-dominated Lords to reflect parties' share of the vote at the last general election, the new intake will comprise 20 Labour peers, nine Liberal Democrats and four Conservatives.

The new influx, which follows the exit of all but 92 hereditary peers last November, leaves the upper house with almost 700 members. Of those, 202 are Labour, 236 Tory, 63 Lib Dem and 161 cross bench (without party affiliation), plus 26 archbishops and bishops.

Among the new recruits are a clutch of exotically-named aristocrats, including Thomas Orlando Lyttleton (Viscount Chandos); Julian Pascoe Francis St Leger (Baron Grenfell); and Anthony Fitzhardinge Gueterbock (Baron Berkeley).

The three are among five former Labour hereditary peers brought back to the Lords, together with a string of figures from the public sector, academia and trade unions.

The nine Lib Dems - fewer than the 15 the party had sought but almost double the five it was originally offered - include another Tony Greaves, a former councillor in Pendle, Lancashire and an energetic party activist known for his bobble hat and ability to get up the nose of a series of party leaders.

The Tory new intake includes Sebastian Coe, the Olympic gold medal-winning runner and Conservative leader William Hague's chief of staff.

Together, the 29 Labour and Lib Dems peers are regarded as fresh ammunition in Mr Blair's battle to push the repeal of section 28, which bans the promotion of homosexuality by local authorities.

Despite the exodus of the hereditaries, the part-reformed Lords has rejected both the repeal of the clause and a government attempt to push through a compromise of new pro-family sex education guidance for schools, as well as inflicting a string of other defeats on the government this year over issues ranging from the London mayor and Greater London authority elections to the regulation of private hospitals and homes.

webTitle: Dewar accused over '£230m' bill lie' to MSPs

fields.headline: Dewar accused over '£230m' bill lie' to MSPs
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: The Scottish first minister, Donald Dewar, was yesterday accused of misleading MSPs as it emerged the cost of the new Edinburgh parliament will be around four times the original estimate.
fields.body:
The Scottish first minister, Donald Dewar, was yesterday accused of misleading MSPs as it emerged the cost of the new Edinburgh parliament will be around four times the original estimate.

A report into the construction of the building concluded that it could be as high as £230m - more than double the figure quoted by Mr Dewar when he handed control of the project over to a parliamentary group last year.

The first minister has come under sustained cross-party criticism over the building - dubbed Donald's Dome by opposition parties - since the Scottish parliament first sat in its temporary home last May. Many MSPs claimed the choice of site - Holyrood in central Edinburgh - was wrong, but yesterday's report by architectural specialist John Spencely says there is now no option but to build the parliament there. Before the Catalan architect Enrico Miralles won the competition to design the parliament, a cost of £50m was predicted.

But in June last year Mr Dewar told MSPs the figure would rise to £62m - the Spencely report revealed the true cost at the time to be £89m.

The Scottish National Party leader, Alex Salmond, claimed yesterday that Mr Dewar knew this was an underestimate of £27m. "Why did he present false figures for the cost of building the Scottish parliament to MSPs and the Scottish public last June? He has to answer that," said Mr Salmond. Mr Dewar brushed off the allegations and called for "energetic action" to put the project back on track. The current budget for the building is £109m and MSPs will have to decide if they want the project to go ahead with a revised budget of £196m, which Mr Spencer says could be achieved with economies on Miralles's design.

webTitle: Straw faces Labour revolt on secrecy on 'right to know'

fields.headline: Straw faces Labour revolt on secrecy on 'right to know'
fields.standfirst: Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw faces a large scale rebellion next week over plans to give ministers and council leaders the right to ban public access to secret documents - regardless of rights under the freedom of information bill.
fields.body:
Jack Straw faces a large scale rebellion next week over plans to give ministers and council leaders the right to ban public access to secret documents - regardless of rights under the freedom of information bill.

The home secretary's latest proposals have infuriated four of parliament's leading figures who yesterday announced they have tabled changes to his bill when it comes back to the Commons next week.

The rebellion is being led by four Commons committee chairmen - three Labour and the fourth a surprise Tory rebel - who want to strengthen the public's "right to know" under the legislation.

They were expected yesterday to become a rallying point for some 200 Labour rebels who have signed a parliamentary motion demanding stronger legislation to end Whitehall secrecy.

So serious are ministers taking the revolt that Mike O' Brien - Jack Straw's trusted deputy handling open government - is carrying a list of the rebels in his ministerial red box for instant reference.

The four senior rebels are David Davis, Tory chairman of the public accounts committee; Giles Radice, chairman of the Treasury committee; Tony Wright, chairman of the Commons public administration committee; and Robin Corbett, chairman of the home affairs committee. They were joined yesterday by former minister Mark Fisher; Tory freedom of information campaigner, Richard Shepherd and Liberal Democrat constitutional affairs spokesman, Robert Maclennan.

The rebels are particularly angry about Mr Straw's new plan - put into the bill under the guise of offfering more freedom of information - allowing ministers, council leaders and the new London mayor the right of veto over the release of documents. The ban would apply even if the council and ministry had been ordered to release documents by the new information commissioner, Elizabeth France.

Mr Davis yesterday said the secret services were behind Jack Straw's determination to use ministerial vetos.

He cited a three-year fight to release a secret National Audit Office report on overspending by the secret services on their luxurious headquarters. "It took us three years and two governments to get this changed. I suspect the people really behind stopping this were the heads of MI5 and MI6, the cabinet secretary and other top officials. It will be no different under this bill."

The four chairmen are also tabling changes to bill to permit policy options to be released to the public; force publication of background information on safety investigations and allow all commercial secrecy to be tested. Mr Wright cited a recent ban by ministers on naming garages which carried out dodgy MoT tests because "it could damage commercial interests".

fields.headline: Peter Baelz
fields.standfirst: Theologian devoted to his church
fields.trailText: Peter Baelz, who has died aged 76, was a shining light in the church of England for more than 50 years as a priest, academic and, later, as dean of Durham cathedral. The range of his concerns covered prayer, metaphysics, the arts and many aspects of ethics, as well as the ministry and education for it.
fields.body:
Peter Baelz, who has died aged 76, was a shining light in the church of England for more than 50 years as a priest, academic and, later, as dean of Durham cathedral. The range of his concerns covered prayer, metaphysics, the arts and many aspects of ethics, as well as the ministry and education for it.

He was born into a family which had come from Germany on banking business. His parents were non-practising Lutherans; he was baptised a Unitarian and joined the Methodist church while at Dulwich College. From 1941, he read classics at Christ's College, Cambridge, where he came under the powerful influence of Canon Charles Raven, the master, and Canon Ian Ramsey, fellow and chaplain (and later Bishop of Durham).

Baelz also acknowledged a debt to the Student Christian Movement. He was impressed by the beauty of Anglican worship, and decided to throw in his lot with the Church of England. At university, he also won a tennis blue. At that time, most older undergraduates were either medically unfit for war service or were conscientious objectors; Baelz was one of the latter, an unpopular stance not made easier by the fact that his elder brother was an RAF pilot.

He was ordained in 1947, by Bishop Barnes of Birmingham, to a curacy at Bournville, where his work was cut short by an infection of the spine, which kept him in hospital for two years (he suffered back pain intermittently for the rest of his life). After two years at the small parish of Wishaw, Baelz moved back to Bournville as its vicar, "the home," as he described it, "of chocolate and Quakerism, for both of which I acquired a predilection."

His intellectual gifts were recognised by his appointment, in 1960, as fellow and dean of Jesus College, Cambridge, with the additional post, in 1966, of lecturer in theology. His Christian theology and metaphysics was an answer to the fashionable logical positivism.

In 1972, he moved to Oxford as regius professor of moral and pastoral theology, and for eight years he used his gifts to the full, not only in the university but also on many committees concerned with ethical questions. One of these produced, in 1975, the church of England's report, On Dying Well (now being reprinted, with a new introduction, 25 years later).

Baelz also chaired, for 11 years, the church's committee for theological education, which shaped the pattern of clergy training for a generation. His method was one of listening to the evidence, sifting it for key ideas, weighing these against the whole Christian tradition, then drawing conclusions for action. Rhetoric was not his style and he never sought publicity, but he was an impressive preacher.

With reluctance, he moved to be dean of Durham in 1980; he was captivated by the cathedral and considered himself fortunate to be "caretaker" of one of Europe's most beautiful buildings. Convinced of the importance of the arts, he introduced an artist-in-residence each year.

Eight years later, he and his wife Anne, whom he had married in 1950, retired to Llandrindod Wells, in mid-Wales. Baelz joined the town council, whose chairman commented that no doubt he had reached the acme of his career on being appointed chairman of the sub-committee on the future of the Llandrindod Wells signal-box. He happily agreed.

Baelz did not fit into any of the usual ecclesiastical compartments. He adopted for himself a saying of Père Lacordaire, a French Dominican (via Alec Vidler): "I hope to live and die a penitent Catholic and an impenitent liberal." By "Catholic" he meant a worshipping member of the blessed company of all faithful people; by "liberal" he meant using reason as a God-given critical faculty in every department of life. Along with a massive intellect went a warm, humorous and loving personality.

He is survived by Anne and their three sons.

 The Very Rev Peter Baelz, philosopher, theologian and priest, born July 17 1923; died March 15 2000

fields.headline: The new intake - no1
fields.standfirst:
The most famous five new peers

Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText:
Michael Ashcroft
Michael Ashcroft's struggle to convert his billion pound fortune into the kind of respectability that ends in a peerage has been one of the bloodiest in living memory.
fields.body:
Michael Ashcroft
Michael Ashcroft's struggle to convert his billion pound fortune into the kind of respectability that ends in a peerage has been one of the bloodiest in living memory.

Ashcroft, 52, is the son of a civil servant and as a boy lived in Belize, then a British colony but later, as an independent state, to figure largely in his financial dealings. He attended Norwich grammar school.

He was 26 when he borrowed £15,000 to set up a cleaning business that, four years later, he sold for £1m. His talent for deal-making was impressive but made colleagues in the City jealous and nervous. In 1984 he moved his interests to Florida, took over the ADT security firm for £600m, then moved to Belize, attracted by lax banking laws he helped set up.

Throughout his rise he had enemies who said he sailed too close to the wind, though friends describe him as unorthodox. Only when he emerged from the wreck of the Tory defeat in 1997 as donor and treasurer to William Hague, did the fight get really dirty.

The Spectator called him "The Man who Bought the Tory party" and the Times ran articles which hinted that his complex interests were involved in laundering drug money from the Caribbean - suggestions which it denied making when both sides backed down last year over Mr Ashcroft's libel suit.

He has bought a £2m home 200 yards from the Lords and promised to start paying UK taxes again.
Michael White

Matthew Evans
If everyone has a book in them, then the one inside Matthew Evans, chairman of publishers Faber and Faber, at the moment is probably How To Lose Friends And Alienate People.

For a man noted for his charm and ability to smooth the most febrile of egos, his first day as the government's "museums tsar" was unfortunate to say the least. A robust speech to launch the new Museums, Libraries and Archive Commission - which he will head - managed to rub everyone up the wrong way. Museums, he maintained, needed to change drastically or risk turning into the "cultural version of Marks and Spencer". Even institutions at each others' throats over charging united in horror at this interloper who merrily admitted knowing little about them. They were not to know that Evans, a founder of the Groucho Club, has a dry sense of humour.

Evans, of course, was right about the most salient fact, attendances are falling and no one quite knows what to do. The next day, well aware of the upset caused, culture secretary Chris Smith delivered the gentlest of raps on the knuckles. As a publisher, though, few would disagree that Evans is without peer. Irreverent, indiscreet, entertaining and astute, he managed to modernise once fusty Faber without sacrificing its commitment to writing of the highest quality and the writers that produce it.

Twice married, he has a home in the Cotswolds, and a seat on the board of the Royal Court theatre.
Fiachra Gibbons

Sebastian Coe
A peerage for Coe, 43, is reward for his service as deputy chief of staff then private secretary, and judo sparring partner, for William Hague. The Loughborough university-educated middle distance runner was made an MBE in 1982 and OBE in 1990. He became MP for Falmouth and Camborne in 1992, serving as a parliamentary aide to defence ministers and then Michael Heseltine as deputy prime minister, before losing his seat in 1997. He is married with two sons and two daughters.

Janet Cohen
Mrs Cohen, 59, is a leading merchant banker and BBC governor.

A non-executive director and consultant at Charterhouse bank since 1988, she is a Cambridge law graduate and qualified as a solicitor in 1965. She was a senior civil servant for 13 years, before joining Charterhouse. She also became an associate fellow of Newnham College, 1988-91.

Mrs Cohen, married with three children, also enjoys a successful second career as a thriller writer, writing under her maiden name Janet Neel.

Richard Layard
One of the architects of the government's flagship New Deal project to get the long term unemployed back to work, he is director of the Centre of Economic Performance, and professor of economics at the London School of Economics. He is also an adviser to David Blunkett, the education secretary. Foremost among his ideas that the long term unemployed should be given subsidised jobs and training to get them back into the work habit. Since 1991 he has been a policy adviser to the Russian government.

webTitle: Old army buddies close ranks against Pinochet

fields.headline: Old army buddies close ranks against Pinochet
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: After more than 25 years of silent solidarity, elements in the Chilean armed forces are starting to speak out against their former commander in chief, General Augusto Pinochet, directly implicating him in killings during his 17-year dictatorship.
fields.body:
After more than 25 years of silent solidarity, elements in the Chilean armed forces are starting to speak out against their former commander in chief, General Augusto Pinochet, directly implicating him in killings during his 17-year dictatorship.

Until this week, lower military officials had taken the blame for the estimated 3,000 people who were murdered or went missing. Many of the killings were carried out by Gen Pinochet's security police.

Now, in a macabre version of a Latin soap opera, one retired army officer after another has used the midnight television news to reveal details of grisly executions they insist were ordered by Gen Pinochet in the early years of his 1973-90 dictatorship.

They include two notorious incidents: the 1976 car-bombing of the Chilean diplomat Orlando Letelier in Washington and the "caravan of death", in which at least 75 political prisoners were taken from jails throughout Chile in 1973 by an elite squad and executed after torture. The unit was commanded by General Sergio Arellano Stark.

Under interrogation by Juan Guzman, the Chilean judge who is building a case against Gen Pinochet, former general Oscar Haag Blaschke and captain Patricio Diaz Araneda have fingered the former dictator. According to press leaks, Gen Blaschke, who was in the "caravan" squad, told Mr Guzman that he was shown a document naming Gen Stark as the "official delegate of the commander in chief and president of the government [Pinochet]".

The "caravan of death" is the most prominent of the 78 criminal cases being investigated by Chilean justice officials. It forms the basis for moves to have Gen Pinochet stripped of his legal immunity as a senate, the first step towards putting him on trial.

The lawyer for Manuel Contreras, the former secret police chief who is in prison for planning assasinations abroad during the coup years, has warned in a press conference that his client may soon unleash a host of new documents - some expected to link Gen Pinochet directly to killings.

In addition, the Chilean historian Patricia Verdugo has published a damning secret military document in which a senior intelligence officer under Gen Pinochet, Brigadier Pedro Espinoza, claims that he was "pressured to only blame my direct commander [for Letelier's assassination], not allowing me to also hold responsible the president of the republic".

Ms Verdugo says that the document, and others, were sent to her by an anonymous Chilean officer who was troubled by his conscience.

In the document, Brig Espinoza, who is in prison for the assassination, complains that he is paying "a very high and unjust price" for the crime, then alludes to a chain of command through which he received his orders.

The accusations against Gen Pinochet have mounted at such a rate that some worry that he is being transformed into a scapegoat. "I fear that this is part of an operation to cast all the blame on Pinochet so the others involved don't assume responsibility for their participation," said one Socialist congressman, Juan Pablo Letelier, the son of the murdered diplomat.

The repercussions have spread beyond military circles and threaten to wreak havoc in political parties as well. Christian Democrat party leaders are nervous that their role in actively collaborating with the 1973 coup plotters will be exposed by military officers trying spread the blame.

Regardless of whether he is judged by Chilean courts, Gen Pinochet's standing has permanently changed. From his self-proclaimed position as guardian of the rightwing flock, he has become a sacrificial lamb.

In this environment, it is now every man for himself in the military. "Instead of institutional loyalty, these men, most of whom have been retired for 10-15 years, are looking at their biological family," said Ms Verdugo. "They are trying to fix their image with their children and grandchildren."

fields.headline: Lord Dunrossil
fields.standfirst: Nelson Mandela's unlikely champion
fields.trailText: The second Viscount Dunrossil, who has died at 73, was an obscure diplomat on the fringes of the British empire, whose one secret feat came to light in last year's release of Foreign Office records under the 30-year rule.
fields.body:
The second Viscount Dunrossil, who has died at 73, was an obscure diplomat on the fringes of the British empire, whose one secret feat came to light in last year's release of Foreign Office records under the 30-year rule.

In 1964, he was an official observer at the Rivonia trial where Nelson Mandela was jailed for 27 years by South Africa's apartheid regime. Having watched the remorseless tide of African nationalism, Dunrossil recognised Mandela as a potential "man of the future".

"We decided to send him books on history and law and anything that would expand his mind," he recalled. "But we chose them carefully so as not to get either Mandela or the guards, who let the books through, into trouble." Dunrossil also enabled Mandela to study for a University of London law degree, resulting in his own targeting by the special branch - and, eventually, the recorded appreciation of Mandela, whom he never met.

Apart from this, the biggest item in Dunrossil's file was his perception, as governor of Bermuda, of the unseaworthiness of the barque Marques, entered in the Tall Ships Race. It sank with the loss of 19 lives.

Dunrossil's title was inherited in 1961 from his father, the 1950s speaker of the Commons and former Tory MP, WS ("Shakes") Morrison. He received the peerage in 1959, then served as governor general of Australia. He was educated at Fettes and Oriel College, Oxford.

At the Commonwealth Relations Office, he started in the private office of Lord Swinton, was posted as first secretary to Dacca, then East Pakistan, then to Canberra as second secretary. His 1970s posting to Ottawa as counsellor was dull, apart from the kidnapping by Quebec extremists of the British diplomat, James Cross, whose release he helped negotiate. His appointment in 1978 as high commissioner in Fiji, and in 1982 to Bridgetown, were staging posts for his final post as governor of Bermuda (1983-88).

He retired to North Uist in the Outer Hebrides, and more recently sought unsuccessfully election as one of the crossbench hereditaries.

His peerage passes to his eldest son, Andrew Morrison, from his first marriage to Mavis (Spencer-Payne), who had two other sons and a daughter. He also had two daughters by Diana (Vise), who also survives him.

 John William Morrison, Lord Dunrossil, diplomat, born May 22 1926; died March 22 2000

fields.headline: Israel orchestra to play Wagner
fields.trailText: Defying the taboo surrounding the works of Richard Wagner, the Israeli Symphony Orchestra is to perform an overture written by the man who was Hitler's favourite composer, and whose music and anti-semitic writings were a source of inspiration to the Nazi regime.
fields.body:
Defying the taboo surrounding the works of Richard Wagner, the Israeli Symphony Orchestra is to perform an overture written by the man who was Hitler's favourite composer, and whose music and anti-semitic writings were a source of inspiration to the Nazi regime.

Although Israeli Radio's music station has been playing Wagner for more than a year, there is an unofficial ban on live performance of his works.

Given that some 300,000 Holocaust survivors live in Israel, the ISO, which is based in Rishon LeZion, will make its Wagner debut in October with caution.

Instead of a full-scale opera, a brief overture will be played - Siegfried's Idyll, which was written to celebrate the birth of the composer's son. The piece will not be part of the regular concert series and will be performed by an 11-player ensemble.

The director general of the ISO, Ehud Gross, said: "I do respect the people who oppose [Wagner's music], but how many years are people going to impose a ban on people like me? Fifty years is two generations, and something has to happen."

Wagner died before the Nazis came to power in Germany, but his writings on Jewish musicians were much quoted by the Nazis, and his works were performed at Hitler's birthday parties.

Mr Gross argued that the Nazis were equally fond of Beethoven, and played his Ninth Symphony as people were led to the gas chamber.

webTitle: Hackers meet to play 'spot the feds'

fields.headline: Hackers meet to play 'spot the feds'
fields.trailText: About 350 computer hackers from around the world fought off security interrogations, attempts to silence them and an all-around bad image to complete the first hacker convention in Israel yesterday.
fields.body:
About 350 computer hackers from around the world fought off security interrogations, attempts to silence them and an all-around bad image to complete the first hacker convention in Israel yesterday.

The two-day Tel Aviv gathering, which included "hack these sites" and "spot the feds" competitions, was the first such gathering since hackers disabled the Yahoo and eBay sites in February.

At the request of MPs, the police had considered banning the conference, but the attorney general, Eliyakim Rubinstein, gave it the go-ahead.

The police did prevent the organisers publishing a list of Israeli commercial websites vulnerable to break-in.

To compile the list, participants attacked sites offered by Israeli companies. The site owners were confident that no one could thwart them, but were proved wrong. The hackers said that 28% of the Israeli internet was vulnerable.

One of the hackers, John Draper of Freemont, California, said they wanted to put a better face on the practice. "A hacker is developing programs to make them better," he said. "They aren't people who break into computer systems. That's a cracker."

Mr Draper helped to launch the hacker phenomenon in 1971 when he discovered that a toy whistle reproduced the tone needed to open a free telephone line.
AP

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
US rabbis back gay marriage
The largest organisation of US rabbis has become the first major religious body to officially sanction same-sex unions, offering the protection of Reform Judaism to clergy who officiate at such ceremonies.
fields.body:
US rabbis back gay marriage
The largest organisation of US rabbis has become the first major religious body to officially sanction same-sex unions, offering the protection of Reform Judaism to clergy who officiate at such ceremonies.

About 500 members of the progressive Central Conference of American Rabbis decided on Wednesday to back any rabbi's decision to preside over a gay union through "appropriate Jewish ritual", according to a Washington Post report. - Reuters, Washington

Terre'Blanche goes to jail
Hundreds of black onlookers cheered as the South African neo-Nazi Eugene Terre'Blanche surrendered yesterday and began serving a one-year sentence for assaulting a black petrol station attendant in 1996.

A request to appeal against his 1997 conviction was rejected on Monday and Terre'Blanche, leader of the Afrikaner Resistance Movement, arrived on a black horse to give himself up at Potchefstroom, 77 miles east of Johannesburg. - AP, Potchefstroom

23 hurt in Israeli land clashes
At least 23 Israeli and Palestinian Arabs were injured in clashes with Israeli security forces yesterday during protests against the confiscation of land near the Arab town of Sakhnin.

Hundreds stormed an army base being built on expropriated ground west of the town. There were also protests on the West Bank.
Reuters, Sakhnin

Kosovo officer freed from jail
A senior gendarmerie officer freed from jail after being held on suspicion of leaking documents which reveal tension between French commanders and the UN administrator for Kosovo, Bernard Kouchner, will be reassigned, the French defence ministry said yesterday.

Lieutenant-Colonel Jean-Michel Mechain remains under judicial investigation. He denies leaking the documents.
Reuters, Paris

Anger at visit of Austrian leader
Jewish organisations in Switzerland said yesterday that they will join anti-racism and leftwing groups in protests against today's state visit by the Austrian chancellor, Wolfgang Schüssel. The Swiss government has not imposed any diplomatic sanctions against Austria for including the far right Freedom party in its new coalition government.
AP, Bern

French reopen shooting inquiry
An inquiry into the death of the flamboyant French gangster Jacques Mesrine, who was shot dead by Paris police in 1972, was reopened by an appeals court yesterday. Mesrine's daughter, Sabrina, 14 at the time of the killing, claims that her father was not given the chance to surrender.
Jon Henley, Paris

fields.headline: Cult massacre - 81 bodies found
fields.standfirst:
Uganda: special report

First arrest as Uganda death toll rises above 700
fields.trailText: Ugandan police searching for more victims of the cult massacre that has claimed at least 700 lives found a further 81 bodies yesterday, buried in a pit at the home of a former member of the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God.
fields.body:
Ugandan police searching for more victims of the cult massacre that has claimed at least 700 lives found a further 81 bodies yesterday, buried in a pit at the home of a former member of the Movement for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God.

The bodies were exhumed from behind the house of a cult member, Joseph Nyamwrinda, in Roshojwa, in Bushenyi district. The bodies of men, women and children were packed into the grave. Labourers stood among the tightly packed corpses, tied ropes around the victims and hauled them out for examination.

Police also arrested a district official in connection with the fire at the cult's headquarters in Kanungu, western Uganda, where at least 330 of the its followers died.

The assistant resident district commissioner, Robert Mutazindwa, who was formerly in charge of Kanungu, was picked up by the police this week and is being held for questioning. This is the first arrest made in connection with the deaths.

"He is held on speculation about his role in the group. We hope he will come out with evidence to help us in our investigation," said John Kisembo, the inspector general of police.

In an interview broadcast yesterday from London, the Ugandan president, Yoweri Museveni, accused district and regional officials of suppressing intelligence reports on the activities of the cult.

Mr Museveni said last week that he had heard reports that Mr Mutazindwa was a member of the cult and had sup pressed negative reports about it. Those who hold Mr Mutazindwa's title in Uganda also head the district security council.

In Roshojwa, Mr Nyamwrinda's 80-year-old brother, who lived in the same compound and lost 18 relatives, claimed that he had no idea that anything sinister was going on.

"After Joseph joined these people, he just ignored us," he said. "I hated this group."

There were also allegations that Mr Mutazindwa helped the cult attain charity status in 1993 and allowed the school at the Kanungu commune to reopen after it was closed down in 1998, when inspectors found pupils were maltreated, received inadequate nourishment and were subjected to hard labour.

At least 330 people, and perhaps as many as 500, died at the Kanungu fire - an exact figure may never be known as many of the bodies were thought to have disintegrated in the inferno. Another 395 bodies have been found buried in other cult compounds.

The police, who have a 20-strong team based in western Uganda to co-ordinate the case, have been criticised over their investigation. On Monday they exhumed bodies from the garden of one of the cult leaders, Father Dominic Kat aribabo, buried them again, and then had to exhume them once more the next day when the pathologist arrived from the capital, Kampala.

"We are not able to handle cases on this level. We are overwhelmed," the head of the criminal investigations department, Erasmus Opio, said. "We are not able to cope. We would be very willing to receive any help from abroad on this case."

There is still no indication why the cult turned murderous. But the fact that the bodies exhumed from all three sites had been killed within the past two months lends weight to the theory that the group's leaders decided to kill its members when their prediction that the world would end in 2000 failed to materialise.

fields.headline: Turkish MPs veto longer presidency
fields.trailText: The threat of political instability loomed over Turkey again yesterday after the government failed to get parliamentary support to change the constitution following a marathon debate.
fields.body:
The threat of political instability loomed over Turkey again yesterday after the government failed to get parliamentary support to change the constitution following a marathon debate.

The government's constitutional package, defeated in a vote late on Tuesday night, would have allowed one of the hardy perennials of Turkish politics, President Suleyman Demirel, 75, to serve a second term in office.

Government leaders say they fear that if Mr Demirel has to stand down at the end of his term in May, the resulting fight for the presidency could break the coalition government.

"I've been trying for a long time to protect economic and political stability," the prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, said yesterday. "It's a very sensitive balance and this situation makes me concerned."

Mr Ecevit vowed to battle on, however, and said there would be a second vote on the constitutional proposals next week. If it fails, he hinted, he would have to consider the position of the government.

Turkey desperately needs stable leadership at the moment. It is trying to implement a tough, anti-inflationary programme backed by the International Monetary Fund, and it wants to press ahead towards eventual negotiations on entry into the EU.

Long-term goals, however, have given way to fierce short-term bargaining during the past few weeks; in the vote on Tuesday night, many political scores were apparently being settled.

Supporters of President Demirel argue he has a vital role to play as Turkey tries to reform its centralised state system. But his critics have said it is time for a change of leadership.

The president serves a single, seven-year term, but the government wants a new system of two five-year terms, which would allow Mr Demirel to stand again.

Any amendment to the constitution has to be approved by a two-thirds majority in parliament, a level of support the government thought it had. But in a secret ballot, dozens of deputies from the three-party coalition defied their leaders and voted no.

It was an embarrassing set-back for the prime minister who now faces a difficult choice: to try to bring the unruly backbenches into line, or to try to strike a deal with the main opposition group, the pro-Islamist Virtue party.

The constitutional proposal to allow the president to serve two terms had already been "sweetened" by having two other measures tacked on to it: one that would protect the pension rights of members of parliament; and another that would make it harder for the courts to ban a political party.

This was supposed to attract the Virtue party, which is currently facing the threat of closure for being a "focus of anti-secular activities". But it voted against the government's package, seeking stronger constitutional guarantees that it will not be shut down.

As for Mr Demirel, he seems determined to not go quietly. He has cancelled a series of foreign trips to fight for his job. The man Turks know as "Baba", or father, will soon find out just how much loyalty he has left among his unpredictable political family.

The president serves a single, seven-year term, but the government wants a new system of two five-year terms, which would allow Mr Demirel to stand again. Any amendment to the constitution has to be approved by a two-thirds majority in parliament, a level of support the government thought it had. But in a secret ballot, dozens of deputies from the three-party coalition defied their leaders and voted no. It was an embarrassing set-back for the prime minister who now faces a difficult choice: to try to bring the unruly backbenches into line, or to try to strike a deal with the main opposition group, the pro-Islamist Virtue party. The constitutional proposal to allow the president to serve two terms had already been "sweetened" by having two other measures tacked on to it: one that would protect the pension rights of members of parliament; and another that would make it harder for the courts to ban a political party. This was supposed to attract the Virtue party, which is currently facing the threat of closure for being a "focus of anti-secular activities". But it voted against the government's package, seeking stronger constitutional guarantees that it will not be shut down. As for Mr Demirel, he seems determined to not go quietly. He has cancelled a series of foreign trips to fight for his job. The man Turks know as "Baba", or father, will soon find out just how much loyalty he has left among his unpredictable political family.

webTitle: Britain accused of aiding industrial espionage by US

fields.headline: Britain accused of aiding industrial espionage by US
fields.trailText: Britain came under unprecedented pressure from its European partners yesterday to reveal the extent of its involvement in a US-led spying network said to be used for industrial espionage.
fields.body:
Britain came under unprecedented pressure from its European partners yesterday to reveal the extent of its involvement in a US-led spying network said to be used for industrial espionage.

Portugal, the current holder of the European Union presidency, announced it would raise the issue at a forthcoming meeting of interior ministers, despite formal insistence from London that nothing illegal was taking place.

Britain and the US both wrote to the EU's enterprise commissioner, Erkki Liikanen of Finland, to say that they were doing no wrong, but a heated European parliament debate on the Echelon electronic surveillance system left open the possibility that MEPs would demand a formal investigation into the allegations.

And Britain's letter, written by its EU ambassador Sir Stephen Wall, fuelled speculation by referring to "safeguarding the nation's economic well-being" as one of the reasons for which telecommunications could be legally intercepted. But he denied that British facilities were used by other states to gain commercial advantage.

Echelon, established during the cold war and operated by the US, Britain, Canada, Australia and New Zealand, is reportedly capable of intercepting millions of telephone, fax and email messages.

James Woolsey, who headed the CIA from 1993-95, has already admitted what to many had long seemed obvious - that the US secretly collects information on European firms.

He wrote in last week's Wall Street Journal: "That's right, my continental friends, we have spied on you because you bribe. When we have caught you at it, you might be interested, we haven't said a word to the US companies in the competition.

"Instead we go to the gov ernment you're bribing and tell its officials that we don't take kindly to such corruption."

He insisted however that it only targeted firms which violated UN sanctions or offered bribes to gain business.

Jonathan Faull, spokesman for the European commission, called Mr Woolsey's comments an "outrageous slur" intended to justify spying.

Until yesterday, Echelon was a minor issue rumbling along almost unnoticed in the European parliament. But Portugal's surprise decision to raise it in the council of ministers puts it into a different league.

It will alarm British ministers concerned about the image of an either-or-choice between the US or Europe. It will also boost interest in the intelligence services at a time when allegations about Libyan dirty tricks and the loss of laptops by secret agents is attracting unwelcome attention.

"We really don't think its necessary for EU ministers to discuss this," said one Whitehall official. "But we will stand our ground."

Duncan Campbell, the British investigative journalist, has claimed that the US used Echelon to beat the European consortium Airbus to a major plane deal with Saudi Arabia in 1994.

Portugal's interior minister, Fernando Gomes, who said the matter would now be referred to ministers, added that no evidence existed to confirm a 1998 parliamentary report saying European firms lose several billion dollars per year as a result of corporate espionage.

The European parliament is not about to lose interest in the subject. Jean-Claude Martinez, an MEP from the far-right French National Front said during yesterday's debate: "We were told that Austria's Haider was the real threat to the EU. Now we see it is Tony Blair."

Robert Evans, a Labour MEP, said British MEPs would block calls for an investigation.

webTitle: Unveiled: the GM rice that could feed world

fields.headline: Unveiled: the GM rice that could feed world
fields.standfirst:
Extra yields as high as 35% will solve food crisis, say scientific researchers. But critics urge caution

GM food: special report
fields.trailText: Genetically modified rice - which could boost yields by up to 35% and so, it is claimed, solve the world's impending food shortage - has been tested in China, Korea and Chile, scientists revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
Genetically modified rice - which could boost yields by up to 35% and so, it is claimed, solve the world's impending food shortage - has been tested in China, Korea and Chile, scientists revealed yesterday.

Professor Maurice Ku announced the new strain at an international conference in the Philippines and said that it could play a big role in combating hunger. Rice stocks are dwindling and there are fears of famine as the world's population increases. Half the population, including almost all of east and south-east Asia, is dependent on rice.

The new rice was developed jointly by Washington State University and agricultural researchers in Japan.

Mr Ku said genetic material from maize was inserted into the rice, boosting the rate of photosynthesis so the plant was able to produce more sugar and increased grain yields.

First results gave increases in yields of 35%, but he urged caution because the findings were "still very preliminary".

"To perfect it we need to do much more tests, not only in the field but also more transformation with additional traits to further improve it," he said.

The tests used a rice plant developed in Japan, Prof Ku said, and "this cultivar may not be suitable for other areas ... To transfer this trait, we need to do traditional breeding to introduce the genes to the elite commercial varieties. So it will be a few years down the road before we release it to farmers - probably three to five years."

The International Rice Research Institute, based near Manila, said that rapid population growth has caught up with advances in cereal yields. Farmers must consistently produce an extra 6.7m tonnes of rice a year, using less land and less water, just to maintain current nutrition levels. GM technology may help farmers to achieve these targets.

"A 35% jump in yield is a lot," said Paul Christou, a rice expert at the John Innes Centre, in Norwich. "The potential is immense, because we are talking about a crop that is recognised to be a food security crop.

"Rice stockpiles in developing countries have been going down at an alarming rate, and if one considers that almost half the world's population depends on rice almost exclusively for all their nutritional calories, you understand why this could be a very significant opportunity."

Pete Riley, GM campaigner for Friends of the Earth, urged caution when it came to releasing new strains of rice. "There are lots of wild varieties out there and cross-breeding between these and new strains could produce a breed of rice superweeds which would certainly not [be] a benefit," he said.

"We need to carefully assess the nutritional advantages, if any, and possible risks. So far we do not have a robust system of doing this. Experiments have shown that by changing farming methods, using better techniques, yields can be increased by far more than 35%."

Mr Riley brought up an issue that has angered the developing world - who owns the new crops? In India and Bangladesh the idea of having to buy seed each year from giant companies has brought serious resistance to GM techncology.

At a recent conference in Edinburgh of the Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe, GM companies were heavily criticised for not helping the developing world.

All the crops commercially developed so far, such as soya, maize and oil seed rape, have been aimed at rich farmers in the US, Europe and Brazil, adding to surplus stocks rather than feeding the world's hungry, the critics said.

Supporters of genetically modified crops pointed to the potential benefits of another GM rice announced in January, called golden rice because of the colour caused by the modification. This adds vitamin A to the grain - which could cure the vitamin A deficiency of 124m children worldwide. The deficiency causes blindness. Golden rice was developed by the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, by inserting three genes into the rice; these make the plant produce beta-carotene or provitamin A.

The Zurich-based institute says the seeds will be made freely available to farmers in developing countries.

Manju Sharma, secretary of the Indian government's department of biotechnology, said GM rice could have important implications. "A very large proportion of India is dependent on rice," he said. "We would like to improve the nutritional quality to combat a number of deficiencies."

Better living through biology?

Soya

Grown extensively in the US, though not in Britain, soya has been genetically modified to be resistant to herbicides - particularly glyphosate - so that this can be used instead of other methods of controlling weeds. Glyphosate is more effective and less toxic than alternative herbicides.

Maize

The European corn borer caterpillar bores through the ear and the stem of the plant, causing it to topple over or the ear to fall to the ground.

It can destroy up to 20% of the crop in infested regions, and globally it destroys 4% of the crop each year. Previously an insecticide spray was used, but these are only effective during the first three days of the corn borer's lifecycle. Maize has been modified so that the plant produces the BT-protein which kills the corn borer.

Vegetarian cheese

Rennet is an enzyme derived from calves' stomachs and an essential part of making cheese. Some vegetarians object to eating it, so two types of vegetarian rennet have been produced: one using a micro-organism modified with genes from cows, and one produced by increasing the amount of naturally occurring rennet produced by the micro-organism.

There are no genetically modified organisms in the cheese itself.

Potatoes

One sweet potato has already been altered to improve its protein content. Argentinian researchers have created 16 transgenic lines of potatoes designed to resist various combinations of viral, fungal and bacterial diseases.

A consortium of 13 Latin American and European laboratories plans to put an array of six resistance genes into a single tropical potato - though there are fears that this might reduce yields.

Vitamin A rice

Professor Ingo Potrykus of the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology genetically modified rice plants to make beta-carotene, which is converted to vitamin A in humans. The crops are intended for the developing world where 500,000 children go blind each year from vitamin A deficiency. Scientists in Leeds and Belgium are also looking at rice plants which would resist nematode cyst worm attack

Tomatoes

Tomatoes have been modified so that they do not over-ripen. This reduces spoilage and produces a thicker paste, which in turn reduces energy costs, because the heat treatment of the tomato paste is more efficient. Genetically modified tomatoes also do not develop the fungal hyphae which can occur in pastes made from conventional tomatoes.

Cassava

Cassava is the world's third largest source of calories, after rice and corn. Laboratories in California and St Louis in the US; Cali, Colombia, and the international Cassava Biotechnology Network joined forces 10 years ago to create disease-resistant plants and increase yields 10-fold.

Dustbin crops

Teams in Australia and the US want to "fine tune" the genes of plants so that they will soak up toxic metals in polluted soils. Tobacco, rape and even poplar trees have been engineered to grow on mercury-soaked soil. Plants are now in development which will soak up other metals at a tenth of the price of a conventional clean-up.

Bananas

Bananas produce fruit without pollination and are very hard to change by breeding techniques. One Belgian group has introduced resistance genes against the most troublesome fungus.

A US group is trying to engineer bananas to produce antigens so that each fruit would contain natural vaccine against diarrhoea, a major killer in the developing world.

Tobacco

A US biotech company has engineered the plant to produce drugs to treat ovarian cancer. Another group is using tobacco to yield a treatment for non-Hodgkins' lymphoma. Drugs from animal cells cost $1,000 (£627) per gram or more. The same drug from transgenic plants could cost $1-$10 a gram, it is claimed.

- Tim Radford

fields.headline: Whisker riskers dodge stubble trouble
fields.trailText: Mickey Mouse has whiskers and Walt himself had an elegant moustache but until this week Disney's theme park employees had to keep a clean upper lip. But now a memo has been sent to the 12,000 staff at Disneyland in California and the company's four Florida parks telling them that "neatly trimmed moustaches" can be worn.
fields.body:
Mickey Mouse has whiskers and Walt himself had an elegant moustache but until this week Disney's theme park employees had to keep a clean upper lip. But now a memo has been sent to the 12,000 staff at Disneyland in California and the company's four Florida parks telling them that "neatly trimmed moustaches" can be worn.

Walt Disney was determined when he founded Disneyland in 1955 that the "happiest place on earth" would exemplify all that was most wholesome about America. That meant no alcohol and, within two years, no facial hair at a time when the only bearded folk were thought to be beatniks, bums or merchant sailors. For the past 43 years, the edict has been strictly imposed.

Male staff have had to watch their contemporaries try out Clark Gables and handlebars, Zapatas and designer stubble while they kept their upper lips clean. No matter that one of the most popular attractions, the Pirates of the Caribbean, were all hairy chaps, or that Frontierland was based partly on the tales of the moustachioed Mark Twain. For staff, the role model was another park favourite, the clean-shaven Peter Pan.

Even in the 1960s, when Disneyland became a favourite place for people to take LSD and deconstruct Sleeping Beauty's castle, staff stuck by the rule. And in 1989, when Disney acquired the Queen Mary as part of its empire in Long Beach, the first officer was shaved from the list of employees for sporting a moustache.

Then this week staff were summoned to a meeting - "Mickey's roll call" - for the new rule to be explained.

Focus groups had shown managers that not everyone thought a moustachioed person was a drug addict or an anarchist.

"Discussions with our guests showed, not surprisingly, that they feel strongly about the importance of our Disney look and view our cast members as role models for their children," said a memo issued by Disney Attractions president, Paul Pressler.

"It was clear that [guests] felt neatly trimmed moustaches are consistent with what they have come to expect of us."

There will still be no beards, earrings or body-piercing. But the concession is a triumph for those on the Disney staff who always thought the ban was a Mickey Mouse idea.

fields.headline: Hillary Clinton raises record $4m
fields.standfirst: First lady now neck and neck with Giuliani in Senate race
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton capped a successful week in her bid to become a US senator yesterday by announcing that her campaign had raised a record $4m (£2m) in three months.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton capped a successful week in her bid to become a US senator yesterday by announcing that her campaign had raised a record $4m (£2m) in three months.

Campaign staff for Mrs Clinton's race against mayor Rudolph Giuliani in New York said no other candidate had ever raised so much money in the first quarter of an election year.

News of Mrs Clinton's overflowing war chest came on the same day that a poll released by Marist College showed that the Mr Giuliani and Mrs Clinton are running neck and neck as his ratings fell to their lowest level since last October.

The previous record for campaign fund-raising in this race was held by the Republican Oliver North, the Irangate officer, who raised $2.9m in his campaign against Senator Charles Robb, in Virginia.

This dubious precedent did not prevent the Clinton team from pointing out that Mr Giuliani had employed one of Mr North's leading finance consultants, Richard Viguerie, to advise his campaign.

Howard Wolfson, the Clinton campaign spokesman, called the fund-raising success "outstanding".

He said: "Hillary's candidacy has energised people across New York state. While Mr Giuliani has concentrated on tapping into a well-funded network of conservative donors, Hillary has run a campaign focused on issues New Yorkers care about such as education, health care and the economy."

Yesterday's funding revelation marks the lowest point in the Mr Giuliani's bid for the senate seat to date. This week he lost ground in the polls after facing criticism of his handling of the latest police shooting of an unarmed black man.

Mr Giuliani took the unprecedented step of authorising the release of court and police records related to Patrick Dorismond after he was killed by an undercover policeman two weeks ago. His refusal to offer his condolences to the Dorismond family while congratulating the police officers involved was largely blamed for sparking the outrage that led to violent protests at Mr Dorismond's funeral.

A report in yesterday's New York Times also revealed that Mr Giuliani's stance is causing concern among New York police officers.

Half of the people polled by Marist College disapproved of Mr Giuliani's handing of the Dorismond incident.

Friends of Giuliani, the campaign team for the mayor, was not available for comment yesterday. It has not yet been revealed how much the mayor has raised in the first quarter which ends today. Republicans typically raise more than Democrats in New York because of their connections with Wall Street but Mrs Clinton has been assiduously fund-raising since last year.

She has attended investment bank breakfasts and tapped the support of the media and entertainment industry with glitzy fund-raising events.

In a radio interview yesterday, Mr Giuliani played down his slide in the polls, saying his poll numbers were still good, considering the criticism he had faced since the Dorismond shooting. "There are few names I haven't been called in the last 12 days," he said.

Earlier this week, Mr Giuliani also conceded defeat in his battle with the Brooklyn Museum of Art over its showing of the Sensation exhibition of modern art. The mayor had taken offence at a painting of the Virgin Mary adorned with elephant dung.

"There are few names I haven't been called in the last 12 days," he said. Earlier this week, Mr Giuliani also conceded defeat in his battle with the Brooklyn Museum of Art over its showing of the Sensation exhibition of modern art. The mayor had taken offence at a painting of the Virgin Mary adorned with elephant dung.

webTitle: New helmet rules upset Italy's style-conscious youth

fields.headline: New helmet rules upset Italy's style-conscious youth
fields.trailText: A chapter in Italian hedonism closed yesterday when the government obliged motorcyclists to wear helmets, judging the body count of teenagers too high a price for wind-in-the-hair freedom.
fields.body:
A chapter in Italian hedonism closed yesterday when the government obliged motorcyclists to wear helmets, judging the body count of teenagers too high a price for wind-in-the-hair freedom.

Police patrols roved the cities enforcing £70 fines, which seem to have deterred all but a few. Helmet shops reported a rush on stocks and the government declared a victory.

Decades of cherishing Audrey Hepburn's carefree scooting on a Vespa in the film Roman Holiday succumbed to the swelling clamour for a law to end road carnage.

In 1998 motorbikes and scooters were involved in 69,793 accidents, killing 1,185 people and injuring more than 53,000, according to the Italian motoring club ACI. Motorcycle and scooter accidents are the principal cause of death of Italians aged 19 to 24.

Broken glass, metal debris and pools of blood are a common sight on Sunday mornings after another Saturday night trip to the disco has ended in tragedy. About 88% of such accidents occur on city streets.

Under the previous law, helmets were compulsory only for bikers aged 16 or under.

Hailing the new law, which came into force yesterday after being passed in November, the public works minister, Enrico Micheli, said: "Helmets are lifesavers and, frankly speaking, it was incomprehensible that they were only compulsory for minors, as if grown-ups were safe from accidents."

Safety campaigners have striven to promote helmets as cool. Serie A football teams have jogged on to pitches wearing helmets, politicians have strapped them on for photo calls, and pop stars have endorsed the plea.

Nevertheless, surveys show that many young people remain hostile. More than half the 19-year-olds are said to be opposed.

Alessandro Privitera, 17, of Rome, said he would start wearing one.

"But Saturday night is another question. If I get a fine my mother will pay for it.

"None of my friends wear a helmet, especially when we go discoing on a Saturday night. It would ruin our gelled hair."
