fields.headline: Flash in the pan
fields.standfirst: Three years ago, there were 400 ostrich farms in the UK - today most have gone bust. Meanwhile, the big stores have cancelled their orders for hippo burgers and alligator steaks.  Claire Wallerstein on why the Brits are sticking to beef
fields.trailText: It was supposed to be the meat of the 21st century. Enthusiasts predicted a day when the face of rural Britain would be changed forever, with traditional fields of BSE-ridden cattle replaced by flocks of eight-foot tall birds sporting Barbara Cartland eyelashes.
fields.body:
It was supposed to be the meat of the 21st century. Enthusiasts predicted a day when the face of rural Britain would be changed forever, with traditional fields of BSE-ridden cattle replaced by flocks of eight-foot tall birds sporting Barbara Cartland eyelashes.

Ostrich meat, they said, was safe, low in cholesterol and calories, and high in iron. It would be a boon for farmers too, producing five times as much meat per acre as beef.

There was a huge flurry of interest - and plenty of lame jokes over the size of the drumsticks. Delia Smith featured an ostrich recipe on her TV show, and thousands of entrepreneurs shelled out for a paddockful of birds, hoping to make a quick buck.

Supermarkets joined the frenzy, and soon shoppers rummaging in the freezers for lamb chops or sausages could find themselves confronted not only by ostrich burgers, but also alligator steaks and kangaroo curry. Restaurants stocked their larders with locust, squirrel and shark.

Five years on, however, the exotic meat market, like the flightless ostrich, has failed to take off. Two court cases, rumbling on this month, involve ostrich farmers who are accused of duping naive investors out of millions. The farmers claim they were simply financially overwhelmed when the bubble burst.

So what went wrong? Three years ago, there were about 400 ostrich farms in the country with 10,000 birds. Today, there is only a fraction of that number.

One of the country's ostrich pioneers, Bristol caterer Paul Cook, says, "We were hobby farmers: dentists, taxi-drivers, whatever. In the early 90s, fertilised eggs were worth £100. Ostriches can lay 100 eggs a year, so we did our sums and believed we'd by buying brand new Range-Rovers within a year. The reality has been very different. We didn't really know what we were doing - a lot of eggs didn't hatch, and a lot of chicks died."

The breeders' market was soon saturated, and, with birds being sold for slaughter, prices plummeted from £5,000 to just £250 per head. "We had got into it without having buyers for the meat, and there were no UK slaughterhouses licensed to deal with ostriches until five years ago," says Cook. "The government was completely unhelpful - there were no grants to help set up. It's quite tragic. A lot of people have suffered massive financial problems."

Cook remains optimistic - although things are fraught at the moment. "It's the breeding season," he says. "Ostriches are very territorial and run very fast. I've had a couple of narrow escapes. But business is finally picking up. We've started four lines of boil-in-the-bag ostrich meals, as well as burgers and sausages, and we have a lot of repeat orders - we've sold as far afield as Bermuda."

But Paul Manning, who runs The Villager restaurant in nearby West bury-on-Trym, says the exotic boom is over. "We started serving exotic meats about four years ago, but it was a flash in the pan," he says. "There was huge interest at first, although I have to say there was always a lot of resistance to squirrel and locust. Peacock was quite popular, but nowadays we only serve ostrich and kangaroo, and rarely at that."

Manning thinks a major stumbling block was the expense: an ostrich main dish costs around £15, compared with £9 for a much meatier plate of roast beef. "You really need a top chef to cook it too," he adds. "It has to be rare, and is so low in fat that someone cooking it at home could easily ruin it."

The supermarkets have given up too. Tesco pulled both ostrich and kangaroo from their shelves 18 months ago. Spokesman Alan McLaughlin says, "They did well to start with because of all the publicity about BSE, but sales soon fell off as beef bounced back. Apart from the cost, people just didn't know what to do with these meats. Ostrich may taste like beef, but you can't serve it with Yorkshire pudding, can you?"

Most ostrich recipes make avant garde suggestions about thinly slicing it in Madeira sauce with caramelised pearl onions and chanterelles - not exactly household staples in the average British kitchen.

Tesco's experiment with sturgeon was also a flop, as were Waitrose's attempts to introduce tanks of live lobsters. Although Sainsbury still sells American ostrich steaks in 90 stores, alligator and kangaroo have been withdrawn.

Dr Stanley Ulijaszek, of Oxford University's institute of biological anthropology, says the exotic meat disaster is not surprising. "The meat we eat has huge cultural significance," he says. "It's not just a source of nutrition, it's a symbol of identity. British people have a great emotional attachment to beef, despite BSE. I think if BSE did anything, it led to people eating less meat rather than wanting to swap to an animal they're more used to seeing in a zoo."

Vegetarian Society statistics support this view. The society claims 10m people in the UK have given up red meat, and 4m, or 7% of the adult population, are completely vegetarian. This number has doubled over the past decade, with an estimated 5,000 people giving up meat each week.

Food critic Nigella Lawson has a simpler explanation: "Exotic meats have failed because they are disgusting," she says, although she does admit to having a recipe for squirrel casserole. "Ostrich has a vile texture and is horribly sweet and pappy, alligator is like a cross between tuna and pork. Emu is alright, and I once made some lovely kangaroo burgers, but you wouldn't want to eat them regularly. It's only natural that we should prefer meats from our own hemisphere."

Whatever the reasons for the fad's failure, animal welfare groups are pleased. Phil Lymbery of Compassion in World Farming says, "When there is so much concern about domesticated animals being ill-treated at factory farms, I don't think British people want to see these completely ill-suited animals being brought into the farming arena. Ostriches are savannah animals that cover 20km a day in the wild. They don't like being kept in muddy paddocks, and they're not suited for the climate. They are easily frightened and can get stress-related eating disorders and end up eating nails and barbed wire, which can kill them." He says transport for slaughter can also prove difficult, as the birds often topple over inside trucks, injuring themselves. From one shipment of 107 high-value birds sent to Manchester Airport for export, 21 were either dead on arrival or had to be put down, he says.

"Alligators and crocodiles, farmed in the States, are killed using the 'nape stab' method, and can take up to an hour to die," he adds. "It's a grisly business."

Bill Jordan, of Care for the Wild, is concerned about the million wild kangaroos killed in Australia each year by professional hunters, who work by night, using high-powered lamps to disorientate the animals. Although there are up to 9m kangaroos in the country, it is feared that picking off the biggest animals is upsetting the natural balance. Six of the country's other native marsupials have already become extinct.

Ironically, while Europe was importing the meat, it was still banned for human consumption in many parts of Australia, where it was only used for dog food, because kangaroos, killed in the heat of the bush, can harbour the toxoplasmosis bug. Australians also suffer from "Skippy Syndrome", finding it hard to eat their national symbol.

"Wild animals, like crocodiles, don't breed in captivity because of overcrowding and stress, so eggs are being taken from the wild," says Jordan. Other animals suffering to satisfy adventurous palates include sharks, which have their fins chopped off for soup before being cast back in the sea to bleed to death, and huge populations of Bangladeshi frogs - often infected with salmonella - which are exported to the EU.

"Apart from the cruelty of pulling legs off live frogs, endangered species are being put at risk," says Jordan. Being killed for human consumption is surely no picnic for any animal.

But while we can hoodwink ourselves about where our slice of beef or lamb comes from, nobody can anthropomorphise like the soppy old Brits. It will be small comfort to the exotic meat entrepreneurs, but they were scuppered by Bambi, Watership Down and David Attenborough.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15
fields.body:
Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15

Scoffs ,19-20 Kingsmead Square, Bath. Tel: 01225 462 483

Organic. Whole food. Vegetarian. The place reeks of decency. And it is, too; decent. There's a shop selling stuff to take away - breads, cakes, pasties, sarnies. Then there's a superior café where you can take a cup of "exotic" tea or first-rate morning coffee with said cake or croissant. Or tuck into something more substantial at lunchtime, be it homity pie, or lentil and cumin pastie or vegetable pastie for £3.05, a spinach turnover, or jacket potatoes with vegetable curry (a princely £2.85) and mushroom bordelaise. There aren't many frills to the decor, but it's clean, comfortable and mostly wood. And you can always eat out on the pavement when the sun shines.

Quick bites . . . where to eat out in under 15 minutes

The Cooked Meat Shop Bath Market, Bath. Tel: 01225 425 640

Bath chaps, pigs' tails, chitterlings, brawn, hazlet - the Cooked Meat Shop is a tiny museum of Britain's lost charcuterie heritage. It's not much to look at, but never mind the presentation, taste the quality. Of course, there's stuff to pick up and take home - such as serious steak and kidney pies - but there's also stuff to eat on the hoof. There's a big range of pasties: Jamaican (99p), Cornish (99p) and spinach and feta (£1.09) for the vegetarian. There are jumbo sausage rolls and handy sized pork pies (49p). While you're at it, explore the other delights of Bath Market and help keep a traditional food centre in business.

webTitle: My abusive brother is using my relationship with my father to get even

fields.headline: My abusive brother is using my relationship with my father to get even
fields.trailText: After several years of putting up with my eldest brother's verbal abuse, I could endure no more. Once again, I had asked him not to phone me when he had been drinking - he did and I lost my temper completely. We haven't spoken since. However, since my mother's death seven years ago I am my father's prime carer. My brother is obviously angry that I choose not to see him any more and, to upset me, is using my relationship with our father as a means of getting back at me.It puts a strain on both my dad and myself, and is causing deep distress to him. I have no more left in the tank for my brother, so please no advice on forgiveness - I've done that too many times! Any suggestions?
fields.body:
After several years of putting up with my eldest brother's verbal abuse, I could endure no more. Once again, I had asked him not to phone me when he had been drinking - he did and I lost my temper completely. We haven't spoken since. However, since my mother's death seven years ago I am my father's prime carer. My brother is obviously angry that I choose not to see him any more and, to upset me, is using my relationship with our father as a means of getting back at me.It puts a strain on both my dad and myself, and is causing deep distress to him. I have no more left in the tank for my brother, so please no advice on forgiveness - I've done that too many times! Any suggestions?

Alcohol is to blame

Your brother may be angry because he feels that you are preventing him from being included in a loving family environment, especially when you are the only family he has left following the death of your mother.

However, the real barrier to him taking an active role in this family is his apparent misuse of alcohol. He probably knows this to be the case, which only fuels his anger further - and this anger is aimed at those he cannot relate to on any other level. Anger is a powerful tool - to vindicate how he feels about being "isolated" and "rejected" by you. It also serves as a powerful weapon, to punish you for your behaviour, even when it is distorted by the use of alcohol.

Alcohol can become a catalyst for abusive behaviour - although it should not excuse it. It took me several years to discover this home truth, following years of abuse by an ex-partner. I still get pangs of guilt, even now, but I now know that I was not responsible for his behaviour.

I dare say that your brother knows what it will take to build a positive and stable relationship with you. He may need professional help to overcome this obstacle, but it is his job to seek that help.

Please talk it over with your father, if possible, as he should know how you feel about your brother's behaviour. You both may be a tremendous support to each other in this matter.
Name and address supplied

Meet on your terms

The image I get here is of a mother coping with a naughty little boy. You put up with your brother's behaviour, tried to forgive him, supported him through thick and thin. Then, as many parents do, you snapped - but unlike a parent, you didn't simply send him to his room. You cut off from him completely.

As many children do, your brother's now running a number - you don't specify what. He's doing this not only to "get back at you" as you suggest, but also to "get you back", to re-engage you in the dance of anger and recrimination that you've both been running for years. If you respond in the old way - even under the guise of protecting your father - you'll get dragged back into the old relationship and find yourself repeating all the old patterns. If you do what you've always done, you'll get what you've always got!

The answer is to act differently. As far as your father is concerned, support him as much as you can. But as far as your brother is concerned, use basic child-handling strategies. Contact him by letter, stating clearly what you expect from him - civility, no verbal abuse, no drinking when with you - and say that if he's prepared to keep to these rules, then you'll be prepared to speak to him and meet him. At the first sign that he breaks the rules, you'll back off again.

Then put this into practice - hard though it will be - rewarding "good behaviour" rather than paying attention to bad behaviour. It could be that your brother will start to realise that if he can behave like an adult, he'll be able to have a mature, adult relationship with you.
Susan Quilliam
Agony aunt for Teletext, FHM and That's Life magazine

Next week

My father, who is now in his 80s and suffering from emphysema, was brought up as a Catholic. He was schooled in a monastery - a fairly brutal experience which put him off setting foot in a church for the next 50 years.

However, as his health has deteriorated he has returned to his Catholic roots. He prays every day, and has become extremely agitated over not having had me baptised as a child. He is terrified he may inadvertently have condemned me to hell, and is now desperate for me to see a priest and be christened.

I am a 30-year-old woman, who not only finds it impossible to believe in any institutionalised god, but is also repelled by many of the things the Catholic church has done in the past, or stands for today.

Should I stick to my beliefs or go through with this to make an old, sick man happy?

If you respond in the old way - even under the guise of protecting your father - you'll get dragged back into the old relationship and find yourself repeating all the old patterns. If you do what you've always done, you'll get what you've always got! The answer is to act differently. As far as your father is concerned, support him as much as you can. But as far as your brother is concerned, use basic child-handling strategies. Contact him by letter, stating clearly what you expect from him - civility, no verbal abuse, no drinking when with you - and say that if he's prepared to keep to these rules, then you'll be prepared to speak to him and meet him. At the first sign that he breaks the rules, you'll back off again. Then put this into practice - hard though it will be - rewarding "good behaviour" rather than paying attention to bad behaviour. It could be that your brother will start to realise that if he can behave like an adult, he'll be able to have a mature, adult relationship with you. Susan Quilliam Agony aunt for Teletext, FHM and That's Life magazine Next week My father, who is now in his 80s and suffering from emphysema, was brought up as a Catholic. He was schooled in a monastery - a fairly brutal experience which put him off setting foot in a church for the next 50 years. However, as his health has deteriorated he has returned to his Catholic roots. He prays every day, and has become extremely agitated over not having had me baptised as a child. He is terrified he may inadvertently have condemned me to hell, and is now desperate for me to see a priest and be christened. I am a 30-year-old woman, who not only finds it impossible to believe in any institutionalised god, but is also repelled by many of the things the Catholic church has done in the past, or stands for today. Should I stick to my beliefs or go through with this to make an old, sick man happy?

fields.headline: Secret councils
fields.standfirst:
Local authorities are conducting more of their business in private, encouraged by ministers

Freedom of information: special report
fields.trailText: Local authorities are conducting more of their business in private, encouraged by ministers.
fields.body:
Outraged by constant criticism of "fat-cat" councillors awarding themselves huge pay rises, Cardiff's civic rulers hit back with the ultimate weapon: they launched their own 140,000-circulation newspaper and ordered town hall departments to withdraw all job advertising from the local press.

The tit-for-tax exercise was designed, naturally, to portray the council in a positive light and to correct "misrepresentations" in the Welsh media. There was one small problem. The decision, like so many in local government these days, was taken in secret. It was presented to the city council by a ruling elite - Cardiff's new civic cabinet - as little more than a fait accompli. Several brave Labour councillors, bitter critics of the leadership, protested vigorously. Like the public, everyone in the city hall outside this eight-strong elite was kept in the dark.

Cardiff has certainly done itself no favours with a £58,500 pay package for the lord mayor-cum-council leader, Russell Goodway - making him Britain's highest-paid councillor - and allowances for councillors overall now topping £1m annually. Eight rebel members were suspended from the Labour group for daring to voice concern - then reinstated after a party appeal panel ruled in their favour. Three of Cardiff's four constituency Labour parties have howled in protest. Local MPs, including the Welsh first secretary Rhodri Morgan and his wife Julie, are outraged. Now the Welsh assembly has threatened to intervene.

But Cardiff's leaders have a point when they ask why they have been singled out for such hostile treatment from senior party figures as well as Cardiff's evening paper - which carried a large, front-page cartoon of Mr Goodway in a "wanted" poster, with his crime billed as "refusing to listen".

The truth is that ministers, so keen to criticise councils like Cardiff for whipping up hostile publicity against the party, have actively encouraged town hall secrecy and "fat-cat" salaries in their much-vaunted modernising agenda for town halls. Now it is rebounding badly on them as local papers throughout the country complain of secret and often far-reaching cabinet decisions taken in town halls. Old committees were generally open to the press and public, and agendas were published at least three days in advance. Councillors' salaries are rising dramatically, too.

Although a few councils make an attempt to open up cabinet meetings, I have discovered only one authority - the London Borough of Harrow - which actively encourages people to turn up to its meetings, presenting them with bulky reports each month on council policy. Harrow's council leader, Bob Shannon, wonders why other authorities now take so many decisions in private. "What have they got to hide?"

Quite a lot, apparently. Around the country, councillors and senior officers - supported, it seems, by the local government minister, Hilary Armstrong - argue that admitting the public to cabinet meetings would inhibit free discussion and, presumably, slow down the decision-making process. Far better, it seems, to publish reports of cabinet meetings after the event - when decisions have been taken and electors have little chance of influencing policy except at the ballot box.

Such a redefinition of local democracy fills many Labour councillors with horror, which is why they're starting to rebel - with good reason. Courtesy of cabinet government, they're now consigned to a toothless, backbench role, with little access to key policy papers.

The Campaign for Freedom of Information, supported by backbench Labour councillors, MPs, and editors around Britain, is pressing for amendments to the local government bill, now before parliament. The bill will take the modernising agenda significantly further forward - forcing councils to hold referendums on elected mayors, "streamlining" decision making further and, ominously, concentrating power in even fewer hands.

It was, of all people, Margaret Thatcher who steered through a private members' bill in 1960 forcing councils to open up all meetings to the press and public. Committee meetings followed. Updated by another Tory MP in 1985, it became a benchmark for freedom of information, with outsiders getting access to key council papers three days before meetings. "We are now finding a Labour government removing the rights Mrs Thatcher gave us," says Andrew Ecclestone of the Campaign for Freedom of Information.

Only five years ago the Department of the Environment, which is driving through the latest reforms, commissioned research from the Policy Studies Institute which found that the 1985 act had ensured a "basic level of openness and accountability" in local government, while councils had no trouble implementing the legislation. The department welcomed the study.

Ministers driving through these reforms - ironically, the man in overall charge, John Prescott, has publicly voiced his scepticism - are not welcoming criticism from within their own party, but they know it won't go away. As key councillors prepare for a confrontation over elected mayors, the battle could only be starting.

webTitle: Mobile players must bid high or lose face

fields.headline: Mobile players must bid high or lose face
fields.standfirst: In two weeks the telecoms licence auction will be over - and that's when the trouble could start
fields.trailText: In two weeks the telecoms licence auction will be over - and that's when the trouble could start
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's auction of the next generation of mobile phone licences reached a point of hysteria yesterday as the total bids passed the £8bn mark with no sign of competition abating among the 13 contenders. The concern being expressed about the enormous sums being thrown at the five licences is the risk that one of the winning telecoms consortiums may default.

Those dismissive of such a notion should look at the US. A similar telecoms auction last year had to be stopped and rerun because companies could not afford to pay for the licences they had won.

In Britain there is a psychological game among the bidders: none want to be remembered as the first to pull out because they could not afford to bid higher.

"There's a lot of face saving going on, and I believe it has escalated out of all control," said Nicky Scott, of consultancy Ovum. "The bids have gotten ridiculously high and if we get into a situation where operators can't afford to pay for them than it's back to square one."

The government originally pencilled in revenues of at least £500m from the auction. But not even in the Treasury's wildest dreams had a potential £10bn been imagined; that amount of cash would pay for 40 new hospitals or two new deal programs or give everybody in the country £166 in cash.

What has surprised pundits is the accelerating cost of the licences. Several auction rounds are undertaken daily whereby bidders must raise each new offer by at least 5%.

Yet in the past few days bids have taken leaps of more than 5% - a sign of desperation, according to some analysts. Fraser Pearce, telecoms consultant at Fletcher Research, said: "I think we are going to see the start of people dropping out now. It's a bit of shock that everybody is still in there as those people are valuing those licences at incredible levels."

In the bidding are the existing incumbents - Vodafone, One2One, BT CellNet and Orange.

Each has deep pockets and is expected to win. Losing is not an option, given the serious ramifications for stock market values and customer bases. Orange is perhaps the only one in doubt because it will be sold by Vodafone after the auction.

The new bidders are Canada's TIW; Spain's Telefonica; NTL Mobile, backed by France Telecom; WorldCom; the Virgin-led consortium SpectrumCo; Crescent Wireless, a vehicle for Global Crossing; Nomura subsidiary Epsilon; OneTel, backed by media moguls Kerry Packer and Rupert Murdoch; and Eircom subsidiary 3GUK.

The process is in its fourth week, and yesterday the bids totalled £8.3bn. The highest was lodged by Vodafone at £1.83bn, with seven bidders tied in an offer of £1.55bn for another licence.

Britain has always auctioned telecoms licences. The auction process is the preferred model of the European Union - even though other European countries, such as Spain, have chose to go down the beauty contestant path.

Cynics insist that the beauty contestant method does not raise as much for a government's coffers as the auction model. Hence other countries such as Germany and Japan - having seen the money raised in the UK - now seem as if they might go down the auction route when they sell off their spectrum for third generation mobile phones.

However, those eyeing the UK's move should consider the American experience.

In April last year, the US government raised $4bn from one auction of mobile phone licences. But it was forced to embark on the whole auction process again after many of the winners defaulted on their payments. The sum it raised the second time around was $412.8m, or one tenth of the original amount.

"There's no reason to say it couldn't happen again," Ms Scott said. "It could happen, or we could see the third generation mobile networks rolled out very slowly because of the high prices paid for licences."

Another risk attached to such high fees for licences is that consumers will end up bearing the cost, with handsets being exorbitantly expensive.

There is also danger for the telecom operators themselves as there is still considerable uncertainty over the potential level of public demand for third generation mobile phones. Because new phones can be linked to high speed networks they promise to deliver video streaming, live internet connection and the capacity to perform simple computing tasks. However phones on the GPRS network, which begins operating in the summer, will also offer internet access and video services, albeit of poorer quality. The rolling out of third generation mobile networks is likely to cost billions of pounds.

Sean Johnstone, a telecoms industry analyst at SG Global Equities, expects that the winning bidders will have to pay for their licences by spreading the cost over some 20 years. "They are going to have to look at matching the cost of the licences to the revenues they generate over a period like that," he said.

The auction process is expected to be wrapped up within the next two weeks. However, when the five successful bidders are announced there really can be only one winner - and that is the Treasury.

 Watch the bids come in at www.spectrumauctions.gov.uk

webTitle: Brown has £6bn to play with before election

fields.headline: Brown has £6bn to play with before election
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown has almost £6bn to allocate to government departments before the next election on top of the £3.1bn already given to health in the Budget, a Treasury official told MPs yesterday.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown has almost £6bn to allocate to government departments before the next election on top of the £3.1bn already given to health in the Budget, a Treasury official told MPs yesterday.

Adam Sharples, who oversees public expenditure, told the Treasury committee that the chancellor intended to top up spending by £9bn in 2001-02, the final 12 months of the current three-year spending programme.

With £3.1bn already allocated to health, that left Mr Brown with £5.9bn still to be distributed, Mr Sharples told Edward Davey, the Liberal Democrat MP for Kingston and Surbiton.

The departmental allocations are expected to be announced in the summer, when the chancellor publishes his second three-year spending programme, the first year of which overlaps with the third year of the current one.

Defending the Budget against City accusations that extra spending will put upward pressure on inflation and interest rates, Gus O'Donnell, the Treasury's head of macroeconomic policy, said that its impact on monetary policy would be small.

He insisted that the Bank of England monetary policy committee had been fully briefed on the chancellor's plans at this month's meeting, when rates were left on hold. The overriding aim of fiscal policy was to hit the chancellor's targets of keeping the debt-to-GDP ratio below 40% and the current budget in surplus. This year the Treasury found that the fiscal position was better than required to hit the targets; hence the loosening of policy.

Mr O'Donnell said that the government's revenue forecasts were deliberately cautious, as it was easier to ease than tighten fiscal policy.

Nicholas Macpherson, the Treasury's deputy director for welfare reform, was challenged by David Ruffley, Conservative MP for Bury St Edmunds, on how it intended to score proposed new benefits for children and pensioners, as a spending increase or negative taxation.

Mr Macpherson said it was too early to say.

fields.headline: Focus  CGU and Norwich Union
fields.trailText: The City looks to be warming to the Norwich Union/CGU merger even if many of the former's retail investors remain unhappy about the "no premium" terms of the merger. Some institutions weren't overjoyed there was no cash on the table either.
fields.body:
The City looks to be warming to the Norwich Union/CGU merger even if many of the former's retail investors remain unhappy about the "no premium" terms of the merger. Some institutions weren't overjoyed there was no cash on the table either.

Yesterday shares in both firmed - in sharp contrast to the rather shell-shocked appearance of much of the rest of the market. Norwich Union gained 12p to 427p while CGU shares rose 7p at 876p

The cheerier approach to the merger is timely. Both sets of shareholders are due to vote on the offer today. The latest uptick was helped by a circular from Merrill Lynch and followed helpful comment from SG Securities earlier in the week.

Though the merger will create Britain's biggest insurance group - with premium income and investment sales of £26bn and an expected cost savings of £250m a year - the yardstick by which it will be measured will be its performance outside the country, particularly in Europe.

Conventional wisdom has it that the British insurers should do well in Europe. By and large they have well stocked product portfolios and the private pensions market is much more developed in Britain than in other big European economies.

Consolidation is in the air and there are some big players out there including the likes of Allianz, Axa, Generali and Aegon. Some have already come shopping in Britain - notably Axa with its purchase of Guardian Royal Exchange.

Shareholders willing, the question now is whether CGNU, as the merged entity will be called, can successful take on the Europeans. The UK group certainly looks to have the critical mass and the promised disposal of CGU's property and casualty business in the US should help keep the focus of the business in the right place.

But though it could reasonably claim premier league status in Europe, investors will be looking for the group to become one of the driving forces behind cross-border change in the insurance sector, not simply a spectator.

fields.headline: P-commerce market hots up
fields.trailText: E-commerce is old hat, say the technology seers. It's p-, that is, portable commerce that counts. And the company which has been reaping the benefit of such sentiment? Handheld computer expert Psion.
fields.body:
E-commerce is old hat, say the technology seers. It's p-, that is, portable commerce that counts. And the company which has been reaping the benefit of such sentiment? Handheld computer expert Psion.

From October last year to the beginning of March, the shares rose 6,000% - topping £70. David Potter, Psion's founder, is one of only two British techonology billionaires. In the last month the only way has been down for the Cambridge-based company. Yesterday the shares dropped 731p to close at £38.69.

The reason? Other p-rivals. One firm that appears to have spooked Psion shares is its American rival, Palm.

The Californian company doubled its sales in Europe last year, passing Psion in market share - and dealers noted comments from Palm warning of rising costs that would lead to operating losses for several quarters.

If Palm's flashy new gadgets will hit the American company's bottom line then what, wonder analysts, will have they in the pipeline to steal a lead over Psion?

Along the horizon lie bigger beasts threatening to bite chunks out of Psion's markets. One of largest predators in the new technology jungle, Microsoft, has long eyed Psion. In 1998, an infamous Bill Gates memo cited Psion among a handful of companies that could challenge Microsoft's supremacy.

Psion's ace up its sleeve is its 30% share in the software consortium, Symbian. Backed by Psion, Ericsson, Nokia, Motorola and Matsushita, Symbian is adapting Psion's operating system, Epoc, into a platform for web-surfing handheld computers and mobile phones.

These "p-devices" will outsell PCs in a couple of years, reckon analysts, with a billion unit sales per year predicted by 2002. So if they all use Psion's Symbian-based system, the British company will realise investors' hopes.

Those dreams may be scuppered by Mr Gates. Microsoft's alternative platform - with its Windows-based operating language - was launched in December.

Yesterday's tie-up between BT, AT&T and Microsoft will also have done little to calm jittery nerves.

fields.headline: Wickes targeted in £285m hostile bid
fields.trailText: The privately-run Focus Do It All DIY chain yesterday tabled a hostile £285m bid for rival retailer Wickes. The 375p-a-share cash bid, backed by venture capital group Duke Street Capital, prompted a 49% jump in Wickes' shares. They closed up 133.5p at 402.5p.
fields.body:
The privately-run Focus Do It All DIY chain yesterday tabled a hostile £285m bid for rival retailer Wickes. The 375p-a-share cash bid, backed by venture capital group Duke Street Capital, prompted a 49% jump in Wickes' shares. They closed up 133.5p at 402.5p.

Bill Archer, the chief executive of Focus Do It All - which operates 210 DIY outlets - said the bid was "not opportunistic and represents full and fair value". But Wickes chief executive Bill Grimsey, who has hauled the group back to financial respectability after an accounting scandal four years ago, described the offer as "wholly inadequate" because it failed to recognise the "value and potential inherent in Wickes".

He added that FDIA was trying to "snatch the benefits of the store renewal strategy and investment of recent years on the cheap" and urged shareholders to reject the offer.

Mr Archer, who founded the Focus group in 1987 as Choice DIY, said a takeover would give the enlarged group £1bn turnover and the financial muscle to compete with B&Q and Homebase - the two biggest DIY chains. It would have 339 stores and 11% of the market - only fractionally less than Homebase. "The whole retail sector is consolidating," he said. "Consumers want best prices, best service and best value."

He said he had approached Mr Grimsey with his takeover plan eight days ago and was "disappointed" to have been rebuffed.

Focus Do It All, which made profits of £25.4m last year, was formed in 1998 from the merger of Focus with Do It All - a disastrous joint venture between WH Smith and Boots that left both retailers nursing large losses.

Duke Street Capital had backed the Do It All acquisition and now owns 59% of FDIA. If the deal goes through the venture capitalists will own some 74% of the enlarged group.

Wickes was largely written off by investors in 1996 when £50m of accounting irregularities and an investigation by the Serious Fraud Office looked likely to sink the company. The shares plummeted from 846p to 133p in a year.

But Mr Grimsey, who was recruited in November 1996 as chief executive to save the company, has turned out to be a Mr Fixit for the group.

He had been managing director of the group's building supplies operation but, since taking the helm from Henry Sweetbaum when the fraud emerged, has given the entire DIY group a semblance of financial prosperity.

Mr Grimsey has regained the market's confidence, putting in place the building blocks to restore margins, sales and costs. At the start of this year he boasted that the group was finally out of the woods.

The company is halfway through a five-year renovation process which involved £50m of spending last year on distribution and warehousing and the overhaul of 35 stores. Before yesterday's intervention the group said it was planning to spend a similar amount this year upgrading 30 more stores.

News of the bid galvanised the share prices of other DIY groups. Kingfisher, which owns B&Q, added 17.5p to 515.75p and RMC Group, which owns the Great Mills DIY chain, closed up 55p at 780p. RMC is understood to be ready to sell off Great Mills.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: This is fast turning into a week FTSE 100 followers would prefer to forget. After three modest declines in a row, the index lost a substantial 153 points yesterday and is not far short of a 300 point deficit on last Friday's close.
fields.body:
This is fast turning into a week FTSE 100 followers would prefer to forget. After three modest declines in a row, the index lost a substantial 153 points yesterday and is not far short of a 300 point deficit on last Friday's close.

It was very much a case of rounding up the usual suspects - telecoms, media and technology stocks were depressed by the overnight fall on the Nasdaq and the mood was scarcely improved when Wall Street started the trading day by turning lower.

Even though the Dow Jones was back in positive territory by the time the London market closed and the Nasdaq had headed south again, the mood remained sombre. The Techmark 200 index was down more than 300 points in sympathy with the US "new economy" market. Those looking for brighter spots had to turn to the "old economy" sectors.

GKN added 22p to 784p, BAT was up 13p at 311p, while Diageo picked up 19p to 468p. Railtrack 's call for more cash saw its shares steam ahead, gaining 54p to end the day at 745p.

Big oil firms remained in demand, building on the outcome of Wednesday's Opec deal, with Shell up 10p at 496p and BP Amoco adding 19p to 542p.

The market responded well to the news that Royal Bank of Scotland had sold the Gartmore fund management business, acquired when it took over National Westminster, to the US firm Nationwide Mutual for just over £1bn. The bank's shares added 28p to 880p.

Barclays shares were 21p higher at £16.93 after news that Morgan Stanley had lifted its price target for the stock to £18.

There was even a ripple of takeover excitement with RMC picking up 55p to 780p in the hope that the surprise bid for Wickes - up 123p to 380p - from the privately owned Focus Do It All would crystalise the value of its Great Mills DIY business.

Rentokil Initial was up rather more modestly on news of its offer for the Copenhagen listed Ratin, gaining 2p to 160p.

But among hi-tech stocks ARM Holdings fell 383p to £37.69, Logica lost 259p to £20.08, while Baltimore Techologies slumped £10.70 to £85.27.

Among telecoms BT was unable to pick up ground on the back of the multi-media deal with AT&T and Microsoft and ended 70p lower at £11.52. Vodafone Airtouch was down 8p at 347p.

Media stocks were also unsettled. BSkyB fell 139p to £16.59, still suffering from Wednesday news of a £340m share placing. Reuters slipped 89p to £13.16, while Pearson was off 235p at £20.61.

webTitle: Nationwide fearful as house prices soar

fields.headline: Nationwide fearful as house prices soar
fields.trailText: Warning bells were sounded yesterday about the "unsustainable" pace of house price inflation as a survey showed the average UK property jumped in value by a record amount this month.
fields.body:
Warning bells were sounded yesterday about the "unsustainable" pace of house price inflation as a survey showed the average UK property jumped in value by a record amount this month.

House prices are rising at their fastest annual rate since 1989, said Nationwide building society. And the cost of an average home soared by 2.3% during March - the largest monthly rise since it started compiling monthly data in 1991.

This means the typical property is now worth £79,393 -16.2% more than a year ago, when the figure was £68,308.

The figures came just 24 hours after Bank of England data showed a surge in mortgage lending.

Nationwide attempted to quell fears of an overheating market by saying house prices were only back to where it would have expected them to be at this point, suggesting that the risk of an imminent downturn in prices was small.

But it said that if house price inflation carried on at its current pace for another 12 to 18 months, past experience suggests that a rapid slowdown in price growth would follow.

"The longer-term outlook is not without risks," said the society. "The pace of house price inflation on an annual basis, 16.2%, is not sustainable."

Rising house prices have hit the private rental market, according to Bradford & Bingley estate agents, which says climbing property values has prompted tenants to turn their attention to buying a home.

webTitle: Rangers to float as it chases global glory

fields.headline: Rangers to float as it chases global glory
fields.trailText: Rangers football club, on track for its 49th Scottish premier league title, announced plans yesterday to float the business on the stock market and disclosed that talks are under way with a number of potential media investors.
fields.body:
Rangers football club, on track for its 49th Scottish premier league title, announced plans yesterday to float the business on the stock market and disclosed that talks are under way with a number of potential media investors.

The Glasgow club, listed on the unregulated Ofex market, also announced immediate plans to raise £53.1m through an issue of new shares, including a £20m cash injection from South Africa-based Scottish businessman Dave King who will become a director of the club. Mr King, a financial services tycoon who regularly caddies for golfer Gary Player, is a lifelong Rangers fan.

The money from the rights issue will be used to eliminate debt running at £40m, buy new players and develop the Rangers academy for bringing on young footballers.

Chairman David Murray, who owns 62% of the club, said further cash from flotation would go into building Rangers as a global brand. "Manchester United has shown us the way," he said. "We have 750,000 supporters in the UK alone and only 120,000 make it to Ibrox. We have the second biggest merchandising arm in the country with sales of £12m and becoming a plc is a natural progression." Cash will also be used to develop leisure facilities at Ibrox.

Mr Murray said offers are on the table from three media companies that could result in a Rangers pay television channel and internet-based business.

NTL, the club's shirt sponsor, could be among the potential investors although in the past the cable company has been careful not to upset local sensibilities by also sponsoring neighbouring Celtic.

If Rangers secures a media investor, it will be the second Scottish club to do so, following Scottish Media Group's acquisition of a stake in Hearts.

The one for three rights issue will push out more than 15m new shares at 345p each. Mr Murray is taking up £9.3m worth. Turnover at the club in the last six months of 1999 increased by almost 40% to £29.8m while profits were £112,000.

fields.headline: Smith & Wesson safety deal backfires
fields.trailText: The US government is investigating signs that the gun industry may be exacting its revenge on Smith & Wesson for the handgun manufacturer's decision to agree to safety curbs.
fields.body:
The US government is investigating signs that the gun industry may be exacting its revenge on Smith & Wesson for the handgun manufacturer's decision to agree to safety curbs.

Smith & Wesson, which is owned by Tomkins, the British conglomerate, unleashed a storm of protest among dealers, distributors and consumers when it broke ranks with the industry by agreeing to wide-ranging curbs on the manufacture and control of handguns two weeks ago.

Although anti-gun protesters objected to the legal amnesty offered to the company by the government as a result of the deal, rivals feared the agreement opened the door to increased regulation and had put them over a barrel in their own legal negotiations.

The furore, which includes the threat by one of America's largest distributors not to work with Smith & Wesson, has led to a government inquiry into potentially anti-competitive practices.

Richard Blumenthal, the Connecticut attorney general, said: "Smith & Wesson is under absolutely unprecedented pressure, both financial and personal within the gun industry, with threats that are almost violent in nature, and I have heard the fear that it could be put out of business."

Ken Jorgensen, a Smith & Wesson spokesman, said the company had not yet seen sales suffer as a result of its agreement with the government. However, the company, has set up special phone lines to deal with consumers wanting to voice their views.

He said the agreement had received a very emotional response.

Charlton Heston, the head of the National Rifle Association, said the agreement was a step towards gun control, which infringes an American's constitutional rights to bear arms.

He said: "Smith & Wesson is a good company and a fine, old American name, but they're owned by the Brits. I don't really relish the idea of the Brits telling us how to deal with one part of our Bill of Rights. I thought we settled that in 1776."

Dealers, in particular, have objected to a code of conduct Smith & Wesson agreed with the government that would require them to do background checks on potential buyers among other things. It has also agreed to install gun locks and other child-safety devices on all weapons and to introduce new technology within three years so that only authorised users can fire handguns.

In exchange for the deal, the government promised to withdraw about 30 lawsuits against the company, which claimed redress for the cost of gun violence.

webTitle: CBI tells Blair to curb unions

fields.headline: CBI tells Blair to curb unions
fields.standfirst: TUC says business protests too much
fields.trailText: Business leaders last night issued a warning to Tony Blair not to cave in to growing union demands for more employment protection legislation.
fields.body:
Business leaders last night issued a warning to Tony Blair not to cave in to growing union demands for more employment protection legislation.

Frustrated by the sympathetic attention they are receiving in the media and government, Digby Jones, the director general of the Condeferation of British Industry, said: "Now is the time for the unions to stop ratcheting up their claims."

His comments, while directed principally at the TUC, were also meant for the prime minister's ear. With the next election approaching, the CBI is becoming increasingly concerned that new demands for paid parental leave and the automatic right for mothers to return to work on a part-time basis may find their way into Labour's manifesto, further increasing employers' costs.

CBI sources point to the three lobby briefings which followed the announcement in the Budget that Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers was to review maternity and parental leave as a possible indication of the government's thinking.

Mr Jones, who has criticised the Budget for increasing public spending and doing nothing to help manufacturing cope with the strong pound, complained that after the introduction of the minimum wage and new union rights legislation, business was already having to cope with the most radical overhaul of labour market regulation for 20 years and did not want any more obstacles to wealth creation.

"Remember that business has frustrations too," he told the annual dinner of the north west CBI in Manchester. We have had to embrace a raft of new regulations over the last three years, including measures we opposed, like the right to statutory union recognition.

"Even worse, some regulations, in particular the working time directive, were poorly drafted and unclear. Others, in particular the parental leave directive, were bought in too quickly, leaving firms without time to prepare.

"Now we need to put the debate behind us, not reopen issues before the ink is dry. The unions should join the business drive to create wealth rather than trying to add more pages to a statute book already stifling enterprise."

TUC general secretary John Monks said: "Digby Jones protests too much. People need protection at work because too many employers still think that treating staff badly is a route to business success.

"If all employers practiced the partnership road praised by Mr Jones there would be much less need for detailed legal rules. It would be easier to take employer lobbying seriously if they did not automatically oppose every extension of employee rights at first and then, like the minimum wage, end up supporting them once they are in force.

"We would agree that some rules like working time are far too complex. But employers refused to sit down with unions in a spirit of social partnership to work out how they would apply to Britain - the route used in most other EU countries."

fields.headline: Dagenham woes deepen
fields.standfirst: Ford chief takes tough stance
fields.trailText: Ford's restructuring plans in Europe will not be affected by fears of public rows with governments or unions, Ford president and chief executive Jack Nasser said yesterday.
fields.body:
Ford's restructuring plans in Europe will not be affected by fears of public rows with governments or unions, Ford president and chief executive Jack Nasser said yesterday.

Public opinion would not affect the company's busi ness decisions, Mr Nasser told the Wall Street Journal Europe while in Sweden to open a new crash-test centre at Volvo, part of the Ford empire.

Mr Nasser said he believed much of the recent public outcry directed at BMW - for its decision to sell Rover - was driven by a desire for better information about corporate plans.

He said a number of ideas were under consideration, including producing Mazda cars, in which Ford has a controlling 33% stake, in the US company's European plants. webTitle: Selfridges expands into three more cities

fields.headline: Selfridges expands into three more cities
fields.trailText: Selfridges, the department store group, yesterday announced plans to open new outlets in three more UK cities and set out details of a vast Selfridges centre and tower it hopes to build at the back of its flagship Oxford Street store.
fields.body:
Selfridges, the department store group, yesterday announced plans to open new outlets in three more UK cities and set out details of a vast Selfridges centre and tower it hopes to build at the back of its flagship Oxford Street store.

Last month the group signed an agreement for a new store in Birmingham's Bull Ring city centre redevopment. The midlands store, due to open in 2003, will be the group's third outlet. Its Manchester store opened 18 months ago.

Yesterday chief executive Vittorio Radice said he would be targeting Glasgow for a fourth store, and would then look for prime locations in Newcastle and Bristol.

Mr Radice said he had made contact with 20 property developing companies keen to work with the store group on its plans for a new retail, leisure, commercial and residential complex at the back of the London store.

The site is occupied at present by the Selfridges Hotel and a car park which would be demolished.

The store group, which has just remodelled the Oxford Street store at a cost of £93m, does not intend to pump its own cash into the new project but would take extra retail space from the development.

"There is still a long way to go to realise the full potential of this site", said Mr Radice. "It has tremendous possibilities".

The talks with developers - which include British Land, the property group which has built a 13% stake in the store group - centre on a a new London tower in the middle of the new complex.

Selfridges' expansion comes in the midst of the toughest retail trading period in years.

But the upmarket store, which has spurned potentially more lucrative own-brand merchandise to model itself as "the house of brands", has profited despite the problems facing its rivals.

Its shares have outperformed the rest of the retail sector by 30% in the past year and yesterday the group announced annual profits up from £13.9m to a better than expected £27.6m.

Recent like for like sales, which exclude the impact of extra space, are up 10% in London and an impressive 18% in Manchester, which turned in a £1.3m profit in its first year.

The shares rose a further 4p to 249p as analysts gave the group's ambitious expansion plans their approval.

fields.headline: Gartmore falls to Americans for £1bn
fields.trailText: Nationwide Mutual, a US investment group, yesterday emerged as the surprise victor in an auction for Gartmore, the large British fund management group which is the first major part of NatWest's business to be sold after the bank's acquisition by Royal Bank of Scotland.
fields.body:
Nationwide Mutual, a US investment group, yesterday emerged as the surprise victor in an auction for Gartmore, the large British fund management group which is the first major part of NatWest's business to be sold after the bank's acquisition by Royal Bank of Scotland.

The £1.03bn price tag was higher than many had expected but Nationwide Mutual was forced to dig deep to see off competing offers and said it had been looking for a fund management acquisition for 18 months so was prepared to "bid aggressively".

The US group - which will see its funds under management almost double to $200bn (£125bn) with the acquisition - was quick to try to stabilise the business by promising that Gartmore's senior management would remain unscathed.

Paul Myners, the executive chairman of Gartmore who also chairs the Guardian Media Group of which the Guardian newspaper is a part, said: "This is a very positive outcome for Gartmore's clients and staff. Our business is going from strength to strength and the only factor holding us back has been the recent uncertainty over our ownership."

Despite the cloud cast over its future first by the prospect of being subsumed into Legal & General then by hostile takeover bids for its parent NatWest, Gartmore produced a strong performance last year. However, the group, acquired by NatWest from Banque Indosuez in 1996, suffered in 1997 and found it hard to shake off a reputation for lacklustre returns.

Mr Myners said Gartmore was now in the final rounds to pick up new institutional investment business thanks to its stabilised ownership.

Paul Hondros, head of Nationwide's asset management business, said he was confident the company was not overpaying. "We can see the business momentum, we have the benefit of three weeks due diligence and we have come away with conviction that the performance of 1999 will be repeated and sustainable."

webTitle: ITV shortlists ad-men to succeed Eyre

fields.headline: ITV shortlists ad-men to succeed Eyre
fields.trailText: The search for a successor to Richard Eyre, who quit as chief executive of the ITV Network Centre last October, is understood to have reached its final stages.
fields.body:
The search for a successor to Richard Eyre, who quit as chief executive of the ITV Network Centre last October, is understood to have reached its final stages.

The centre, which commissions and schedules programming, is understood to have narrowed the field to three, each with a strong advertising background.

They are Richard Hytner, chief executive of advertising agency Publicis; Peter Littlewood, a British marketeer working for Mars confectionery in the US; and Dominic Proctor, who runs a media buying agency, Mindshare. A decision could be reached in the next few weeks.

Chief executive of ITV is considered a challenging job because of the need to balance the demands of the three very different personalities run ning the largest companies, United News & Media, Granada and Carlton.

The future of the network is also unclear, with the three companies vying for control of ITV. United News and Carlton have agreed a merger but Granada has indicated that it is mulling an offer for either of the two. The entire affair is now in the hands of the competition commission.

Most analysts also expect the upcoming Broadcasting Act to allow the formation of a single ITV company which would impact on the role of the network centre.

Whichever wins the job will though find ITV in reasonably robust form. The controversial move of News at Ten has resulted in the network recording its first gain in peak time market share for seven years.

Coronation Street, the Granada soap opera now in its 40th year, is pulling in record audiences and Who Wants to be a Millionaire has been a notable audience winner.

ITV is also fresh from its first victory over the BBC in the Christmas ratings war for 15 years. Much of the success, say commentators, has been put down to ITV's director of programming, David Liddiment.

Mr Eyre left ITV after two years at the Network Centre, to head Pearson Television, which produces ITV regulars including The Bill, This is Your Life and Wish You Were Here.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Volex group to cut 325 jobs
Power cables group Volex is to cut 325 staff over the next year after switching production abroad. The cuts will all fall at the group's factory in Leigh, near Manchester, which makes power cords for domestic appliances including kettles and PCs.
fields.body:
Volex group to cut 325 jobs
Power cables group Volex is to cut 325 staff over the next year after switching production abroad. The cuts will all fall at the group's factory in Leigh, near Manchester, which makes power cords for domestic appliances including kettles and PCs.

Around 250 staff will remain at the factory following the move.

Ken Hooper, the firm's finance director, said: "Because of pricing pressures in the UK and in Europe, we have been resourcing some of our manufacturing to our factories in south-east Asia and investing in automated equipment."

Lonrho Africa faces loss
Trading group Lonrho Africa yesterday reported a steep fall in operating profit and warned that markets remained tough, but said it had made "considerable" progress in its goal of becoming a focused distribution company.

The group said the disposal of its hotels arm was at an advanced stage and sale of its cotton and timber units were proceeding. It also said the sale its Farmer's Choice food business in Kenya would go ahead and had received an offer from management for its 50.6% stake in the John Holt distribution business in Nigeria.

Icahn moves on Nabisco
Corporate raider Carl Icahn said yesterday he was prepared to buy 100m shares of Nabisco Group Holdings Corp as part of his fourth attempt to take over the food company.

In a letter to Nabisco's board of directors, Mr Icahn offered to pay $13 (£8) per share in a move that would raise his stake in the firm to 40%.

He said he was prepared to launch the offer if the Nabisco board agreed to certain conditions.

Maiden profits decline
Outdoor advertising firm Maiden Group said yesterday a tough first half dragged pre-tax profit lower last year but business was on the mend and the group planned to make some acquisitions this year.

Maiden Group said it would kick off with three regional acquisitions in its core large format sector and was also looking to take its business into other parts of Europe.

Pilkington sees turnaround
British glass maker Pilkington said yesterday turnover from continuing operations was now growing for the first time in three years and said it would sell most of its Technical Glass Products unit for £50m.

fields.headline: Verdict quashed after 19 years
fields.trailText: A man who was jailed 19 years ago for the murder of a betting shop manager in Liverpool was freed yesterday by the court of appeal when his conviction was quashed with immediate effect.
fields.body:
A man who was jailed 19 years ago for the murder of a betting shop manager in Liverpool was freed yesterday by the court of appeal when his conviction was quashed with immediate effect.

John Kamara, now 44, from Toxteth, Liverpool, was convicted in 1981 with Raymond Gilbert of the murder of John Suffield, who was stabbed during a bungled robbery.

During the trial Gilbert changed his plea to guilty. Even though Mr Kamara continued to profess his innocence he was found guilty. But evidence emerged that another man confessed to police in 1987. Doubts were also cast on the fairness of Mr Kamara's identity parade, and a bundle of 201 statements were not disclosed to the defence during the trial.

Mr Kamara's case was transferred to the criminal cases review commission three years ago.

Mr Kamara's younger brother Philip said after the ruling: "Justice has come right, but why did it take 20 years when he could have been out 12 years ago?"

In a statement via his solicitor, Mr Kamara said: "I am delighted that this dreadful miscarriage of justice has been righted after such a long time. It has not quite sunk in yet. Now I want to go away somewhere quietly to start rebuilding my life."

Michael Baxter, assistant chief constable of Merseyside police, said: "We will study the reasons behind this judgement very closely to establish whether it highlights any issues that affect police procedures in Merseyside."

fields.headline: Bruce Bernard
fields.standfirst: Picture editor and writer whose passionate eye honed a sharp response to the images of a century
fields.trailText: Bruce Bernard, who has died aged 72, was an alarming, angry, affectionate and singular man. Picture editor, photographer and writer, he was one of three brothers and two sisters; his younger, self-destructive brother Jeffrey was the author of the infamous Low Life column in the Spectator, and the subject of Keith Waterhouse's play Jeffrey Bernard Is Unwell, while his elder sibling, Oliver, is a poet, translator of Rimbaud and Apollinaire, and veteran campaigner against the siting of nuclear weapons in East Anglia.
fields.body:
Bruce Bernard, who has died aged 72, was an alarming, angry, affectionate and singular man. Picture editor, photographer and writer, he was one of three brothers and two sisters; his younger, self-destructive brother Jeffrey was the author of the infamous Low Life column in the Spectator, and the subject of Keith Waterhouse's play Jeffrey Bernard Is Unwell, while his elder sibling, Oliver, is a poet, translator of Rimbaud and Apollinaire, and veteran campaigner against the siting of nuclear weapons in East Anglia.

Bruce may have been a stalwart of a dying bohemia, but he achieved far more than he squandered in Soho's white nights and black afternoons.

His father was an interior designer and scenic designer for opera, who survived the sinking of the torpedoed Lusitania in 1915. His mother was a singer. Bruce was shunted around a number of boarding schools, finishing his education at Bedales. Somewhere on the way, aged about 14, he first met Lucian Freud, who became a life-long friend.

He went on to St Martin's School of Art, but left, drifting round the corner to Soho, in the 1950s the most cosmopolitan and lively part of London. He worked as a scene-shifter and in sporadic white-collar jobs, but most of all he found his milieu among artists and writers, meeting Francis Bacon for the first time in 1949.

He went on, by a devious, accidental route, to become picture editor for a part-work, the History Of the 20th Century, for Purnell. He moved to the Sunday Times magazine as picture researcher in 1972, soon becoming picture editor, a post he held until 1980. Here, he produced Photodiscovery, a personal history of the photograph, which became a much-sought-after book.

His eye for photographs, and his belief that the photographic image was at least the equal of the paintings he admired, led him to have the best, and most analytic, response to photography I have encountered.

He had a shrewd, passsionate eye, and was possessed of one of the most acute bullshit detectors I have ever encountered. For a long time, I was a bit afraid of him. In the early 1980s, we lived in the same house beside the British Museum, and at first I was more aware of the sounds of nightly pacing, and Beethoven booming through the floorboards, than of the near-invisible Bruce.

One night I ended up in his room, filled with photographs, Lucian Freud etchings and piles of books. We'd drink, and he'd stand in the centre of the room, arms to his side - just as Freud has him in his later portraits - Britten and Pears's setting of William Blake's Rose Thou Art Sick booming round the room.

Having left the Sunday Times, Bernard went on to be picture editor for the Independent magazine, then in its heyday, and worked on a marvellous book about Van Gogh, Vincent By Himself, which juxtaposed Van Gogh's paintings and drawings with excerpts from the letters to Theo Van Gogh, and a book about paintings of the Virgin Mary. His short articles (often produced pseudonymously - Joe Hodges and Deirdre Pugh being favourite monikers) were terse, unaffected by art or photography jargon and, in the manner of the painters he admired, hard-won.

He travelled, he disappeared to his studio (from whence, no paintings or drawings ever emerged), he continued to drink in Soho and to chronicle, in photography, the life about him - and, in particular, his friendships with Bacon, Frank Auerbach, Michael Andrews and Freud, with whom he sometimes used to breakfast at the Savoy. Yet it would be a mistake to see Bernard as a figure whose life was bounded by Soho. I discovered he was a great friend both of Don McCullin, and also of Robert Mapplethorpe. His curiosity about images, whatever their source, whatever their medium, was voracious, critical and driven by a passionate understanding of their power.

Bernard was sometimes depicted, in Michael Heath's hilarious and bitter Private Eye cartoon chronicle of Soho barflies, the Regulars, as Napoleon. He could be dismissive, curmudgeonly, not so much difficult as impossible. At the same time, his silent presence could be immensely reassuring in times of difficulty, and his enthusiasm for what he believed in was truly infectious. He had huge fallings-out - notably with Francis Bacon, about whom Bruce was making a book shortly before the artist's death. Suddenly, for no good reason, Bacon pulled the plug. He also fell out with his brother, Jeffrey; it was a continuing theme of their relationship.

As well as compiling the definitive survey of the work of George Rodger, co-founder of Magnum, and curating an exhibition of the work of photographer John Deakin for the Victoria and Albert Museum, Bernard went on to curate a photographic exhibition for the Barbican gallery in 1994 and to show his own photographs. His portraits of Leigh Bowery and Lucian Freud (about whom he produced an excellent, image-based monograph), Francis Bacon in the studio doorway, Euan Uglow trapped by the string sight-lines which measure the space of his studio, are incredibly powerful. The photographer John Riddy says that, for him, Bernard's portraits of British artists are the only one's to escape cliché.

Bernard captured not just famous men, but also their self images, their anxious presences. Last year, while he was still actively engaged in compiling the Bruce Bernard Photography Collection for the James Moores Foundation, he had a great success with Century, a huge compilation of photographs published by Phaidon, featuring 10 images a year for 100 years. It is a definitive and endlessly fascinating pictorial account of the past hundred years. Right to the end, Bernard continued to work.

I last saw him, with his companion, the artist Virginia Verran, two weeks ago, as they were returning from photographing Leon Kossoff. Ill with cancer, looking like a frail, plucked bird, he never lost his enthusiasm for life or his compulsive fascination for images. His sense of what was good and bad art, good and bad photography had an almost moral dimension, but one which was entirely personal, and thoroughly ethical.

 Bruce Bernard, picture editor and photographer, born March 21 1928; died March 29 2000

fields.body:
Anthony Trewavas: When populations outgrow their food resources the result is starvation, the worst of all tortures, according to Amnesty International.

We all know the harrowing pictures of tiny children, dead from starvation and disease, adults skeletal in appearance.

The greatest problem facing mankind today is its own population growth. Alongside global warming, it will test ingenuity to the limit.

Some will say the world produces enough food already; it is merely politics or distribution that is the problem.

They may well be right. We are currently 6bn in number and we could feed 6.4bn. But only the most unrealistic could suppose that the north will freely distribute two-thirds of its farming bounty to the south. It is simply much easier for scientists to persuade plants to yield greater harvest than it is for any of to us to persuade people to share the world's resources equally.

But it is not so much the current population as the growth that is truly frightening. Every year it inexorably increases by 84m extra souls: we will be 8.4bn by 2025.

"More mouths to feed translates into a need for half as much more new rice than what is eaten today, comments M Houssain, an economist with the International Rice Research Institute in the Phillipines. "The figures are frightening."

Norman Borlaug, father of the green revolution - the surge in yields that started in the 60s - puts it more starkly. Recognising that richer populations eat more meat (and cattle are fed grain), he projects cereal demands as nearly doubling by 2025.

We managed increases of this order before. From 1960 onwards, rice and wheat yields increased two and a half fold, thanks to some clever plant breeding by the International Rice and Wheat Institutes. The green revolution turned potential disaster countries like Mexico, India and China into cereal exporters. It oversaw a doubling of the world population and fed most of it, without the massive starvation predicted by doomsayers.

The green revolution came at a price: dependence on intensive agriculture and fertilisers, some land degradation; but would anyone exchange these for starvation of billions?

The green revolution also saved wilderness. Unesco has pointed out that 4,000 years of cultivation in India resulted in the production of 6m tons of wheat in 1947. Production last year was 12 times higher.

By not using traditional agriculture, we have saved 50m hectares (249m acres) of forest from the plough. To feed the growing population our hands are tied and our options limited. Increased yield must come from increasing biological yield, not from ploughing up wilderness.

Dangerous burdens have already been placed on the ecosystems on which we all depend. In the unstable and more extreme climate which is coming our way, more diversity in agricultural technology is necessary to help stabilise our food supply.

We can dismiss organic agriculture as a serious contender to feed 8bn. Even organic growers estimate the best they can do as feeding 3bn, and that would require turning all the useable soils of the world into farmland, with its diminished biodiversity.

Genetic improvement (sometimes called genetic manipulation) represents the new string to our bow. This new agricultural technology increases the diversity in technology, essential to help stabilise our food security; it will also increase yields yet again on the same acreage of land.

Moreover it is much faster in constructing new crops than traditional breeding. The new rice announced today is genetically improved to push yields up by 35%. Because it is increased biological yield, impact on mother earth will be kept to a minimum.

The new rice was created through public research and should be available to all. For developing and third world countries, it is life and death.

• Professor Anthony Trewavas is a plant biologist at the Institute of Cell and Molecular Biology, University of Edinburgh.

Dr Sue Mayer: GM "super rice" could play a major role in tackling world hunger, we are told. Genetically modified for improved photosynthetic ability, its yields could be increased by a massive 35%. Surely this is the end to starvation and we should hang out the banners. However, some awkward questions remain.

First, what are the major causes of hunger? And can a new rice variety solve them? There seems to be agreement that poverty and inequality, war and economic instability are the major causes of malnutrition. There are enough calories to go round but they are not distributed properly.

Education and sanitation are often inadequate, and tackling them can make dramatic differences.

Thailand has seen falls of 90% in maternal death rates and a reduction in the proportion of underweight children from 50% in 1982 to 10% in 1996 through political and social commitments to ending undernutrition, largely through community-based initiatives. Some of the improvements are threatened by the financial insecurity of south-east Asia, and that will not be cured by super rice.

Second, could there be any problems with the rice itself? If a GM crop is intended for mass consumption, most people would agree it will have to face some serious safety assessments.

At the recent OECD conference in Edinburgh, debate focused on the need to find adequate safety testing mechanisms for unintentional changes, and the need to develop such systems is urgent. There are also environmental and agricultural issues that need to be addressed.

If the genes for increased photosynthetic ability are passed to weedy rice varieties (which exist in close proximity to paddy fields and can cross freely with rice) and they get a 35% boost in growth, super weeds will be a reality and any benefits may be short-lived

And because this is obviously a major change to the way in which the rice behaves, it could make the rice crop itself more weedy. Excitement must therefore be tempered with caution.

This raises a question about how this new rice variety will be marketed? Even though it was developed in the public sector, the biotechnology industry in the developed world is desperate to get some good PR, and super rice will now be promoted around the world.

Having nothing beneficial to offer consumers in the north, the industry has been forced to use poverty and malnutrition as a justification for its continued existence.

All the major multinationals are investigating systems of controlling - and gaining maximum profit from - their patented crops, through the linked use of a chemical supplied by the same company.

They are prospecting for useful genes in the south to patent and use in the north. There is active development of GM crops in the north to create substitutes for crops such as palm oil and cocoa, which are traditionally grown in the developing world. This has the potential to threaten the export markets of these countries and cause serious economic hardship.

While we are told about the advantages that super rice may bring, little mention is made of other GM crop developments which may increase inequalities and threaten food security, not improve it.

Genetic modification is not the only way to increase yields in rice. Other recent reports showed how crossing a cultivated rice with a weedy rice caused similar dramatic increases in yields. Changes in cultivation practice can also make a big difference. GM super rice is clearly not the only solution available.

So super rice is unlikely to save the world. Its role, if any, is likely to be minor, as underlying inequalities can only be addressed by a shift in political and social attitudes. Finding solutions at a local level, consulting with communities and letting them determine the best way to a balanced diet is crucial. Let's not use the horrors of malnutrition to justify a whole technology.

• Dr Sue Mayer is director of GeneWatch UK, an independent policy research group which monitors developments in genetic technologies. Web site: www.genewatch.org
